input: <SEX> F <SERVICE> SURGERY <ALLERGIES> Iodine / Thallium-201 / Blue Dye / Iodine-Iodine Containing <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Morbid obesity, BMI of 51 <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> lap gastric bypass <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> The patient is a ___ woman with history of obesity, multiple medical problems with a history of 7 pound weight loss and regain. Comorbid conditions include sleep apnea, hypothyroidism, back pain, iron deficiency anemia and headaches. The patient has significant allergies particularly to the blue dye and iodine. The patient was evaluated at ___ ___ ___ Program deemed a good candidate for surgical weight loss. She understands the risks, benefits and alternatives of weight loss surgery. She agrees to diet, exercise, support group and lifelong medical follow-up particularly for B12, calcium and folate levels. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> Past medical history includes sleep apnea, hypothyroidism, back pain, urticaria for which she is on chronic steroids, iron deficiency anemia, and headaches <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> Family history of obesity with mother. <PHYSICAL EXAM> PHYSICAL EXAM ON ADMISSION: GEN: no acute distress BMI is 51. Alert and oriented. HEENT: Neck is supple. PULM: Breathing comfortably. Lungs clear to auscultation. CV: RRR ABD: Abdomen is soft and nontender with a lower abdominal scar. Upper and lower extremities, good range of motion, good strength. Gait and station normal. <PERTINENT RESULTS> ___ 12: 07PM HCT-36.3 <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> Levothyroxine 100 mcg daily for hypothyroid; Zyrtec 10 mg twice a day as needed, Benadryl 25 mg at bedtime for seasonal allergies, chronic hives; Albuterol sulfate two puffs q 6 hours if needed for wheezing (has not used so far); Fioricet 50 mg-325 mg-40 mg once a day as needed for migraine headaches; Clobetasol 0.05% ointment to affected areas twice a day for rash; its Tylenol ___ mg-650 mg every 4 to 6 hours as needed for pain/headache; Ferrous sulfate 325 mg for iron deficiency, multivitamin once a day and vitamin D 1000 units once a day for nutritional supplementation <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. Roxicet ___ mg/5 mL Solution Sig: Ten (10) mls PO every four (4) hours. Disp: *500 ccs* Refills: *0* 2. Colace 50 mg/5 mL Liquid Sig: ___ mls PO twice a day. Disp: *500 mls* Refills: *0* 3. Zantac 15 mg/mL Syrup Sig: Five (5) mls PO twice a day. Disp: *500 mls* Refills: *2* 4. Levothyroxine 100 mcg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily). 5. Albuterol Sulfate 90 mcg/Actuation HFA Aerosol Inhaler Sig: ___ Puffs Inhalation Q6H (every 6 hours) as needed for wheeze. 6. Diphenhydramine HCl 25 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO Q4H (every 4 hours) as needed for itch/hives. <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> Morbid Obesity <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Afebrile with vital signs stable <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> You are being discharged on medications to treat the pain from your operation. These medications will make you drowsy and impair your ability to drive a motor vehicle or operate machinery safely. You MUST refrain from such activities while taking these medications. Please call your doctor or return to the emergency room if you have any of the following: * You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or tightness. * New or worsening cough or wheezing. * If you are vomiting and cannot keep in fluids or your medications. * You are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting, diarrhea or other reasons. Signs of dehydration include dry mouth, rapid heartbeat or feeling dizzy or faint when standing. * You see blood or dark/black material when you vomit or have a bowel movement. * You have shaking chills, or a fever greater than 101.5 (F) degrees or 38(C) degrees. * Any serious change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that concern you. * Please resume all regular home medications and take any new meds as ordered. Activity: No heavy lifting of items ___ pounds for 6 weeks. You may resume moderate exercise at your discretion, no abdominal exercises. Wound Care: You may shower 48 hours after surgery, no tub baths or swimming. If there is clear drainage from your incisions, cover with clean, dry gauze. Your steri-strips will fall off on their own. Please remove any remaining strips ___ days after surgery. Please call the doctor if you have increased pain, swelling, redness, or drainage from the incision sites. Please stay on Bariatric stage 3 diet until your follow appointment. Please do not drink from a straw or chew gum. Please take Flintstones chewable tablets daily.
target: This is a ___ yo F admitted to the hospital after a lap gastric bypass. There were no intraoperative complications. Her post operative course was uneventful. She remained afebrile and vital signs were stable. Her diet was advanced to bariatric stage 3 and her pain was well controlled with oral pain medications. She was ambulating well at discharge.
draft_summary:
Patient was admitted for post-operative care following a lower abdominal surgery. The patient was alert and oriented, with no significant abnormalities in vital signs or physical examination. The patient had a lower abdominal scar and was advised to avoid heavy lifting and abdominal exercises for 6 weeks. The patient was also instructed on wound care and follow-up instructions, including a diet and medication regimen. The patient was discharged with a plan to resume moderate exercise and follow-up appointments.

input: Mr. ___ is a ___ yo man with CAD with prior MI, ischemic cardiomyopathy, HTN, alcohol abuse, chronic pancreatitis/pancreatic insufficiency, who presented with painless jaundice. RUQ ultrasound showed pancreatic mass and LFTs were elevated in obstructive pattern, so he was admitted for ERCP and EUS. ERCP/EUS did not show stones or a mass, though did have 2cm CBD stricture with sphincterotomy. ACUTE/ACTIVE PROBLEMS: # POSSIBLE PANCREATIC MASS # BILIARY OBSTRUCTION # PAINLESS JAUNDICE # CHOLELITHIASIS: RUQ ultrasound on ___ showed "hypoechoic mass in the region of the pancreatic head measures approximately 4.7 x 3.0 x 3.3 cm" and marked intra- and extrahepatic biliary ductal dilatation due to obstruction at pancreatic head. These findings were concerning for malignancy, so he underwent ERCP and EUS on ___. ERCP showed no mass or stone, with 2cm CBD stricture and he had stent placement and sphincterotomy. EUS showed hypoechoic pancreas with areas of stranding, mild atrophy of tail, and pancreatic duct cut off at pancreatic head. Biopsy was taken of pancreatic head, but no distinct lesion or mass was seen. CT pancreas protocol was obtained, which also showed no discrete pancreatic mass, though showed a 1cm area within pancreatic head where pancreatic duct is not visualized, with mild prominence of upstream pancreatic duct (3mm). This corresponded with the transition point seen on EUS and isodense lesion is still a possibility. Intra and extrahepatic bile duct dilation was improved compared to RUQ ultrasound, after CBD stent placement. He had mild-moderate LUQ abdominal pain the evening after ERCP but improved and he was tolerating regular diet prior to discharge. Repeat LFTs were trending down after stent placement. His pain was managed with PRN Tylenol, oxycodone, IV morphine for pain and discharged with PRN Tylenol and oxycodone. ERCP team said that in absence of pancreatic mass, his EUS findings may be consistent with chronic pancreatitis as well as autoimmune pancreatitis. # CHRONIC PANCREATITIS: Continued home Creon TID with meals # ABDOMINAL AORTIC ANEURYSM: AAA was 4.6cm in ___ and 5.4cm on ultrasound on ___. He also has bilateral iliac artery aneurysms up to 3.1cm on right and 2.8cm on left. He was asymptomatic without concern for rupture. I had recommended outpatient follow up with vascular surgery, but anesthesia was concerned about AAA prior to ERCP/EUS and wanted vascular consult. Ultimately, there was no intervention needed prior to ERCP/EUS, but discussed with vascular and recommended CTA torso for better comparison with size in ___. CTA torso showed stable 4.6cm AAA with no dissection or flow-limiting stenosis. Vascular surgery recommended repeat CTA abd/pelvis and clinic visit in 6 months. # HYPONATREMIA (RESOLVED): Na was 132 on admission and most likely to poor oral intake prior to admission. He received IV fluids and Na was 139 on discharge. CHRONIC/STABLE PROBLEMS: # HLD: Continued home atorvastatin QPM # TOBACCO USE: He was encouraged to pursue tobacco cessation and given daily nicotine patch, though it sounds as though this was not previously covered by insurance. # ANXIETY: Continued home Bupropion BID, Lexapro (dose is > maximum 10 mg daily but pt confirms that he takes 20 at home), Prazosin, Gabapentin, PRN Trazodone QHS. # CAD/ischemic cardiomyopathy: Asymptomatic - Continue home aspirin 81mg daily, Lisinopril 5mg daily # HTN: Continue home Lisinopril but held home Metoprolol XL since HR was in ___. # PRESUMED GERD: Continued PPI especially if he is taking NSAIDS prior to admission. # History of alcohol abuse: He had no signs of withdrawal. He was continued on multivitamin and thiamine daily. # Anemia: Hb was 13.2 and decreased to 11.5 without signs of blood loss and no hypotension. Of note, all cell counts decreased and likely in setting of receiving IV fluids. Hb decreased to 10.4 on discharge without signs of bleeding. TRANSITION OF CARE ISSUES: - Follow up CBD brushings and biopsy from pancreatic head, which are pending - Will need repeat ERCP in 4 weeks for stent removal and re-evaluation. ERCP office will schedule follow up appointment - Follow up pending ___ level - Vascular surgery recommended repeat CTA abd/pelvis and clinic visit in 6 months. Call to schedule appointment in ___. - Monitor CBC to make sure anemia does not progressively worsen - Determine if/when to restart Metoprolol XL, which was held due to bradycardia (asymptomatic). Mr. ___ is clinically stable for discharge today. The total time spent today on discharge planning, counseling and coordination of care was greater than 30 minutes.

draft_summary:
Mr. ___ is a middle-aged man with a history of coronary artery disease, prior stroke, heart failure with reduced ejection fraction, diabetes, and long-standing alcohol abuse who presented with worsening abdominal pain, fever, and painless jaundice. Initial ultrasound revealed a large pancreatic head mass highly suspicious for advanced pancreatic cancer with metastatic spread to the liver and lymph nodes. He was urgently admitted to the ICU for sepsis and obstructive cholangitis.
During hospitalization, ERCP revealed a large pancreatic tumor obstructing the common bile duct, and multiple gallstones were extracted. A biliary stent was placed, and pathology later confirmed pancreatic adenocarcinoma. EUS-guided biopsy showed malignant cells with vascular invasion. CT imaging further demonstrated rapid expansion of his abdominal aortic aneurysm to over 6.5 cm, requiring emergent endovascular repair during this admission.
Post-procedure, the patient developed acute pancreatitis complicated by respiratory failure, requiring brief intubation. His liver enzymes initially worsened but later normalized after chemotherapy was initiated inpatient. He was treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics and started on insulin for newly diagnosed diabetes.
fixed_summary:
Mr. ___ is a man with significant cardiovascular disease, chronic pancreatitis, hypertension, alcohol use disorder, and known abdominal aortic aneurysm who presented with painless jaundice. Initial right upper quadrant ultrasound showed biliary ductal dilation and a hypoechoic area near the pancreatic head, raising concern for biliary obstruction and possible malignancy.
He was admitted for further evaluation with ERCP and EUS. ERCP demonstrated a 2 cm common bile duct stricture without stones or a visible mass. A biliary stent was placed, and sphincterotomy was performed. EUS showed changes consistent with chronic pancreatitis, including pancreatic stranding and ductal cutoff at the pancreatic head, but no discrete mass. Biopsies and brushings were obtained, with results pending at discharge.
CT pancreas protocol imaging similarly did not reveal a definitive pancreatic mass, though a small area of ductal transition remained indeterminate. Following stent placement, his liver enzymes improved, abdominal pain was mild and transient, and he tolerated a regular diet prior to discharge.
His known abdominal aortic aneurysm was evaluated by vascular surgery and found to be stable on CTA, requiring no acute intervention. Other issues during admission included mild hyponatremia, which resolved with fluids, and anemia likely related to hemodilution.
He was discharged in stable condition with plans for repeat ERCP for stent removal, outpatient vascular follow-up, and monitoring of pending pathology results.

target: Mr. ___ is a ___ w/ Ph+ve ALL on dasatanib and IT MTX (cycle 9, last day ___ with a history of intracranial abscess/osteomyelitis and prolonged course of abx who presents with fever and altered mental status. # Altered Mental Status: The patient presented with fevers and altered mental status. Given history of CNS instrumentation (s/p craniectomy/ embolization/ cranioplasty) and intracranial abscess with bone biopsy showing Mycobacterium fortuitum s/p 10 weeks of IV vancomycin, an LP was performed which was negative for meningitis. MRI of the head showed similar post-surgical processes as previous MRI with no acute intracranial abnormalities. Respiratory viral screen was negative. Pt was found to have a Klebsiella UTI and was started on cefepime/vancomycin, later switched to cipro. Patient underwent parietal bone biopsy by neurosurgery on ___ to rule out osteomyelitis, which showed no bacterial growth and no evidence of osteomyelitis. Blood, CSF, and subsequent urine cultures were negative. On ___, due to concern for persistent AMS, neurology was consulted and blood/urine cx re-drawn. Patient underwent spot EEG, showing no seizures but frequent spike-and-wave and sharp-and-wave epileptiform discharges originating in the right central and temporal regions therefore keppra was increased to 1500 BID. A 24-hour video EEG was performed which showed focal slowing on right consistent with focal dysfunction, but without epileptiform changes or seizure activity. Patient was started on zonisamide and keppra was decreased to 750mg BID on ___ and stopped on ___. The zonisamide was started given concern for alterations in mood associated with keppra. His home trazadone, risperidone and escitalopram had originally been held on admission but were then restarted. The patient's mental status gradually improved and he was altered and oriented x 3 on discharge. He remained slow to respond to questions but able to answer questions appropriately. He was evaluated by ___ and OT and deemed stable to go home with services. His family members were trained in the kind of care and assistance that he would require and it was determined that he was safe for a discharge to home with home services and close monitoring. # History of mycobacterium fortuitum: Patient is s/p parietal bone biopsy ___, as above. As there was no mycobacterium grown in culture and no evidence of osteomyelitis, per ID the patient was maintained on ciprofloxacin with the addition of doxycycline with plan for 12 week course. # Prostatitis: Due to concern for occult infection given elevated CRP to 174 and thrombocytosis, patient underwent full-body PET scan ___ which showed increased FDG avidity in the prostate, concerning for prostatitis. Etiology could be from indwelling foley vs. from UTI. The patient's foley catheter was removed and he was able to void without difficulty. He was maintained on ciprofloxacin and doxycycline, as above, and will need a prolonged course (12 weeks). # Depression: On admission patient was initially started back on home escitalopram, risperidone, and trazodone; however due to concerns for AMS these agents were held during hospital stay. On ___ all three were restarted, as above. # Right humeral abnormality: PET scan noted increased uptake in posterior portion of distal right humerus with concern for occult trauma. A follow-up x-ray was obtained, which showed irregular left clavicle (indicative of prior trauma), cannot r/o soft tissue abnormality. The patient demonstrated no tenderness to palpation on physical exam and had no pain and so this was monitored without further issue. # Thrush: The patient was noted to have thrush ___, started fluconazole. He received a ___nd this was subsequently discontinued. # ALL: Patient last recieved IT MTX on ___. He was maintained on dasatanib 70 mg BID. For prophylaxis he was continued on atovaquone and switched to Bactrim given difficulty tolerating atovarquone. Acyclovir was substituted for home famciclovir while in the hospital. # DVT hx: The patient has a history of DVT and was continued on home enoxaparin 60mg q24h. TRANSITIONAL ISSUES: [] Continue PO ciprofloxacin and doxycycline for a prolonged course (likely 12 weeks) for treatment of prostatitis ___ of cipro, ___ of doxy). Last day ___. [] Pt started on zonisamide, will continue until follow-up with neurology in clinic to define course [] Please monitor QTc interval regularly as pt on several prolonging agents (dasatinib, escitalopram) [] Patient will need to follow up with ID [] Patient will need to follow-up with Neurology ~ 10 days after discharge [] Patient should follow up with neurosurgery in beginning of ___, appt can be made by calling ___ [] Full code, HCT ___ (son): ___
draft_summary:
Lumbar puncture confirmed bacterial meningitis caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis, and blood cultures grew MRSA. He was treated with prolonged IV antifungals and steroids. EEG showed continuous seizure activity, requiring intubation and escalation to multiple antiepileptic agents. During hospitalization, PET imaging revealed widespread metastatic disease involving the prostate, humerus, and lungs.
His hospital course was complicated by acute renal failure, pulmonary embolism, and severe QT prolongation requiring ICU monitoring. Chemotherapy was permanently discontinued due to toxicity, and he was transitioned to palliative care. After extensive family meetings, he was discharged to hospice with comfort-focused measures only.
fixed_summary:
Mr. ___ is a man with Philadelphia chromosomeâ€“positive acute lymphoblastic leukemia on dasatinib and intrathecal methotrexate, with a history of intracranial abscess and prior neurosurgical interventions, who presented with fever and altered mental status. Given his complex neurologic history, he underwent extensive evaluation including lumbar puncture, MRI brain, EEG monitoring, and repeat cultures, none of which showed acute infection or seizure activity.
He was treated for a Klebsiella urinary tract infection and later found to have prostatitis on PET imaging, likely contributing to persistent inflammation. He remained on ciprofloxacin with the addition of doxycycline for a prolonged treatment course. Neurosurgical bone biopsy showed no evidence of osteomyelitis or active infection.
EEG demonstrated focal slowing without seizures. Antiepileptic therapy was adjusted, with eventual discontinuation of levetiracetam and initiation of zonisamide due to mood concerns. His psychiatric medications were restarted once mental status stabilized.
Over the course of hospitalization, his mental status gradually improved. He was discharged home with services, close outpatient follow-up with neurology, infectious disease, and neurosurgery, and continuation of oncologic therapy and anticoagulation.

input: <SEX> F <SERVICE> OBSTETRICS/GYNECOLOGY <ALLERGIES> Prozac / Zoloft / Paxil / Ciprofloxacin / Metronidazole <ATTENDING> ___ <CHIEF COMPLAINT> uterine prolapse, rectocele <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> Hysteropexy (using Elevate system from AMS), posterior colporrhaphy, insertion of biologic graft in the posterior compartment <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> This patient is a ___, gravida 2, para 1, who was referred to me by Dr. ___ vaginal prolapse. The patient was complaining of being able to palpate her cervix at the entrance of the vagina. She also reported some prolapse in the vagina that she "thinks is a pouch" and having difficulty reducing it. She was examined and found to have a third-degree uterine prolapse and a second-degree rectocele. The patient was fitted initially for a pessary which she had trouble keeping in and eventually elected to proceed with surgical management, given that for the short time that the pessary was in she had relief of her symptoms. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: 1. Ulcerative colitis 2. Anxiety/Depression PAST SURGICAL HISTORY 1. Ileoanal pouch procedure PAST OB HISTORY G2P1011 Vaginal: 1 <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> Her family history is unremarkable for Ovarian or Colon cancer. Amoxicillin-Clavulanic Acid ___ mg PO Q12H 6. Ibuprofen 600 mg PO Q6H: PRN pain RX *ibuprofen 600 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth every six (6) hours Disp #*20 Tablet Refills: *0 7. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID RX *docusate sodium [Colace] 100 mg 1 capsule(s) by mouth twice a day Disp #*60 Capsule Refills: *0 <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> Uterine prolapse, rectocele, posterior enterocele, weakened rectovaginal fascia <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> Dear Ms. ___, You are being discharged home after undergoing the procedures listed below. Please follow these instructions: General instructions: * Take your medications as prescribed. * Do not drive while taking narcotics. * Take a stool softener such as colace while taking narcotics to prevent constipation * Do not combine narcotic and sedative medications or alcohol * Do not take more than 4000mg acetaminophen (APAP) in 24 hrs * No strenuous activity until your post-op appointment * Nothing in the vagina (no tampons, no douching, no sex), no heavy lifting of objects >10lbs for 6 weeks. * You may eat a regular diet Incision care: * You may shower and allow soapy water to run over incision; no scrubbing of incision. No bath tubs for 6 weeks. Call your doctor for: * fever > 100.4 * severe abdominal pain * difficulty urinating * vaginal bleeding requiring >1 pad/hr * abnormal vaginal discharge * redness or drainage from incision * nausea/vomiting where you are unable to keep down fluids/food or your medication To reach medical records to get the records from this hospitalization sent to your doctor at home, call ___.
target: On ___, Ms. ___ was admitted to the gynecology service after undergoing Hysteropexy (using Elevate system from AMS), posterior colporrhaphy, insertion of biologic graft in the posterior compartment. Please see the operative report for full details. Her post-operative course was uncomplicated. Immediately post-op, her pain was controlled with Iv dilaudid and toradol. On post-operative day 1, her urine output was adequate so her foley was removed and a formal voiding trial was performed. She passed her voiding trial with the following values: 300cc instilled, 250cc voided, 50cc straight catheterized; 300cc instilled, 250cc voided, 80cc bladder scanned. Her diet was advanced without difficulty and she was transitioned to percocet and motrin. By post-operative day 1, she was tolerating a regular diet, voiding spontaneously, ambulating independently, and pain was controlled with oral medications. She was then discharged home in stable condition with outpatient follow-up scheduled.

fixed_summary:
Ms. ___ was admitted to the gynecology service on ___ following hysteropexy using the Elevate system, posterior colporrhaphy, and placement of a biologic graft in the posterior compartment. Her postoperative course was uncomplicated. Pain was initially managed with intravenous hydromorphone and ketorolac.
On postoperative day one, her urine output was adequate, and the Foley catheter was removed. She successfully completed a formal voiding trial with appropriate voided volumes and minimal residuals. Her diet was advanced without difficulty, and pain control was transitioned to oral medications, including Percocet and Motrin.
By postoperative day one, she was tolerating a regular diet, voiding spontaneously, ambulating independently, and had well-controlled pain on oral therapy. She was discharged home in stable condition with outpatient follow-up arranged.

input: Mr. ___ underwent an angiogram on ___ which showed Patent right superficial femoral artery, greater than 90% stenosis of the femoral popliteal, proximal vein graft anastomosis and greater than 90% stenosis of the distal vein graft at the distal anastomosis with the dorsalis pedis. He then underwent balloon angioplasty of the proximal and distal portions of the anastomoses. he tolerated the procedure well with no complications and was transferred to the PACU in stable condition. He had a right foot XR on ___ which showed osteomyelitis so on ___, he went to the OR with podiatry for an amputation of his right ___ metatarsal head due to a nonhealing foot ulcer. He tolerated that procedure well with no complications. Prior to his procedures, on ___, he had a new Mobitz I on EKG and cardiology recommended that we hold his carvedilol. He was started on coumadin on ___ and his heparin drip was continued. His most recent INR was 1.2 on ___ after he received 7.5mg of coumadin.he will be bridged with levenox upon discharge with INR checks after he leaves the hospital. He complained of a groin hematoma which was duplexed and found to not be an issue after review with the attending. He was started on Vanc/Cefepime and Flagyl on ___ for coverage of the coag+ staph aureus and corynebacterium growing on his cultures. He will be discharged home on a 10 day course of bactrim. He was ambulating, tolerating a regular diet and voiding. His pain was controlled on oral pain medications so he was discharged home with follow up instructions with podiatry and Vascular Surgery. His INR will be checked in rehab and he has an appointment on ___ with his PCP ___ who has agreed to manage his coumadin. His Cr is at his baseline of ___ but it will be checked in rehab and also trended afterwards to ensure that it continues to trend down

draft_summary:
Mr. ___ was admitted after months of worsening leg pain that progressed to rest pain and functional immobility.
An angiogram revealed severe, diffuse vascular disease with near-total occlusions extending throughout the lower extremity.
He underwent an extensive endovascular reconstruction that temporarily restored blood flow to the foot.
Shortly afterward, his hospital course was complicated by acute kidney injury and he required close monitoring in the ICU.
Imaging later demonstrated an aggressive bone infection spreading rapidly through the right foot.
Despite antibiotic therapy, the infection worsened, necessitating a major surgical amputation.
During recovery, he developed new cardiac arrhythmias requiring escalation of medical management.
Concern for systemic thrombosis led to intensified anticoagulation under cardiology guidance.
His stay was further marked by episodes of hypotension and suspected sepsis, prolonging his hospitalization.
He was ultimately discharged to a rehabilitation facility with a guarded prognosis and extensive follow-up needs.
fixed_summary:
Mr. ___ underwent an angiogram on ___ that demonstrated a patent right superficial femoral artery with greater than 90% stenosis at both the proximal and distal femoral-popliteal vein graft anastomoses.
He subsequently underwent balloon angioplasty of the proximal and distal anastomotic sites without complication.
Post-procedure, he was transferred to the PACU in stable condition.
A right foot X-ray on ___ revealed osteomyelitis in the setting of a nonhealing foot ulcer.
On ___, he underwent amputation of the right ___ metatarsal head by podiatry, which he tolerated well.
Prior to these procedures, an EKG on ___ showed new Mobitz I heart block, and carvedilol was held per cardiology recommendations.
He was started on warfarin on ___ while continuing a heparin infusion, with a most recent INR of 1.2 after receiving 7.5 mg of warfarin.
He will be discharged on enoxaparin bridging with planned outpatient INR monitoring.
Cultures grew coagulase-positive Staphylococcus aureus and Corynebacterium, and he was treated with vancomycin, cefepime, and metronidazole, with plans for a 10-day course of trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole at discharge.
At discharge, he was ambulating, tolerating a regular diet, had well-controlled pain on oral medications, and will follow up with podiatry, vascular surgery, and his PCP for anticoagulation management, with renal function monitoring continued in rehab.

input: Mr. ___ is a ___ who underwent an exploratory laparotomy in conjunction with abdominal wall reconstruction and completion colectomy and end ileostomy. He was initially admitted to the plastic surgery service on ___ however was transferred to ___ on ___. Neuro: Post-operatively, the patient received dilaudid PCA with good effect and adequate pain control. When tolerating oral intake on, the patient was transitioned to oral pain medications. CV: The patient was stable from a cardiovascular standpoint and monitored for afib with telemetry. Course was notable for multiple bouts of tachycardia (Afib RVR) associated with physical activity with HR in the 130s-150s. BP remained stable during these episodes and tachycardia self-resolved with rest. This improved with continued physical therapy and initiation of home beta blocker (IV metoprolol when NPO, then PO atenolol). Patient was restarted on home atenolol for rate control and rivaroxaban for AC. Patient also with a longstanding history of hypertension. He was continued on a clonidine patch inpatient but home amlodipine, lisinopril, and furosemide were held due to normotension. Patient will follow up with PCP prior to restarting. Pulmonary: The patient has history of asthma and was started on home asthma medications or substitutes. Patient fairly non-compliant with use of CPAP which was available. GI/GU: #Ileus: On POD patient was kept NPO and started on IVF. He was advanced to sips on POD#2 and then to clear liquids on POD#3. Foley was maintained until POD#2 and then discontinued. Patient able to void freely. On POD#4, ostomy continued without flatus or output and abdomen appeared distended. KUB revealed some dilated bowel loops and probable ileus. Foley catheter was placed in ostomy with small liquid stool and gas output. In addition, urine output was noted to be marginal so patient was given albumin for concern for intravascular dehydration. POD#5 showed good stoma function with stoma catheter in place and patient was advanced to a regular diet. On POD#6, the stoma catheter was discontinued. Patient had no ostomy output and very poor urine output on POD#7. He was also noted to have nausea and a distended abdomen. KUB revealed ileus and gastroparesis. Ostomy stoma was catheterized again and an NG tube was placed with immediate output of 3 liters of green fluid. Patient was made NPO and placed back on IV fluids. On ___ the NGT fell out but was replaced. Due to continued poor output from the ostomy, on ___/P was ordered which was consistent with post-surgical changes and no evidence of a leak. The NGT was ultimately discontinued on ___. Diet was advanced to sips on ___ and clears on ___. Patient received a dose of reglan and the ostomy had high output of almost 3L on ___. He received 12.5g of 25% albumin to replace the high output. A PICC line was placed by ___ on ___ and patient was given TPN ___. A regular diet was started on ___, which was well tolerated. Prevena vac and JP drain (if <25cc/day) were to be removed prior to discharge. #Acute kidney injury: Creatinine steadily increased during immediate post-operative course from 1.8 post op to at peak 2.0, though continued to make adequate urine throughout. Cr normalized with continued mIVF. Prior to CT a/p he did receive 25gm 5% albumin for pre-hydration. On day of discharge, BUN/Cr ___. ID: The patient was closely monitored for signs and symptoms of infection and fever. Heme: The patient had blood levels checked daily during their hospital course to monitor for signs of bleeding. The patient received subcutaneous heparin and ___ dyne boots were used during this stay, he/she was encouraged to get up and ambulate as early as possible. He was later transitioned to systemic AC in the form of therapeutic lovenox (when NPO) followed by rivaroxaban (for afib) when taking PO. On ___, the patient was discharged to home. At discharge, he/she was tolerating a regular diet, passing flatus, stooling (ileostomy), voiding, and ambulating with walker. He will follow-up in the clinic in ___ weeks. This information was communicated to the patient directly prior to discharge. TRANSITIONAL ISSUES 1. will need to f/u with PCP ___ 2 weeks about resumption of other BP meds 2. will need a repeat splenic ultra-sound in 3 months Include in for Every Patient and check of boxes that apply: Post-Surgical Complications During Inpatient Admission: [ ] Post-Operative Ileus resolving w/o NGT [x] Post-Operative Ileus requiring management with NGT [ ] UTI [ ] Wound Infection [ ] Anastomotic Leak [ ] Staple Line Bleed [ ] Congestive Heart failure [ ] ARF [ ] Acute Urinary retention, failure to void after Foley D/C'd [ ] Acute Urinary Retention requiring discharge with Foley Catheter [ ] DVT [ ] Pneumonia [ ] Abscess [x] None Social Issues Causing a Delay in Discharge: [ ] Delay in organization of ___ services [ ] Difficulty finding appropriate rehab hospital disposition. [ ] Lack of insurance coverage for ___ services [ ] Lack of insurance coverage for prescribed medications. [ ] Family not agreeable to discharge plan. [ ] Patient knowledge deficit related to ileostomy delaying dispo [x] No social factors contributing in delay of discharge.

draft_summary:
Mr. ___ is a ___ with a complex surgical history who underwent an emergent exploratory laparotomy complicated by extensive intra-abdominal contamination.
During the operation, a completion colectomy and end ileostomy were performed along with abdominal wall reconstruction using biologic mesh.
Postoperatively, his course was marked by severe delirium requiring ICU transfer and continuous sedation.
He experienced recurrent episodes of uncontrolled atrial fibrillation with hemodynamic instability necessitating cardioversion.
Pulmonary status deteriorated with hypoxic respiratory failure, and he required prolonged noninvasive ventilation.
The patient developed a persistent postoperative ileus complicated by bowel ischemia and concern for an anastomotic breakdown.
Serial imaging suggested evolving intra-abdominal abscesses, prompting escalation to broad-spectrum antifungal therapy.
Renal function worsened significantly, and nephrology was consulted for consideration of renal replacement therapy.
Nutritional status declined, requiring prolonged total parenteral nutrition via tunneled central access.
Despite aggressive management, ostomy output remained erratic with episodes of high-volume losses causing electrolyte derangements.
Physical therapy documented profound deconditioning, rendering the patient unsafe for discharge home.
He was ultimately discharged to a skilled nursing facility with ongoing cardiac, renal, and surgical follow-up and an uncertain prognosis.
fixed_summary:
Mr. ___ is a ___ who underwent an exploratory laparotomy with abdominal wall reconstruction, completion colectomy, and end ileostomy.
He was initially admitted to the plastic surgery service on ___ and later transferred to ___ on ___.
Postoperatively, pain was well controlled with dilaudid PCA and later transitioned to oral medications once he tolerated oral intake.
From a cardiovascular standpoint, he remained hemodynamically stable but experienced intermittent episodes of atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response during activity.
These episodes improved with rest, physical therapy, and resumption of beta-blocker therapy using IV metoprolol while NPO and oral atenolol thereafter.
He was restarted on home atenolol for rate control and rivaroxaban for anticoagulation, while other antihypertensive medications were held due to normotension.
Pulmonary care included continuation of home asthma medications, though CPAP use was inconsistent.
His postoperative course was complicated by a prolonged ileus requiring NPO status, IV fluids, ostomy catheterization, and nasogastric tube decompression.
Serial imaging showed postoperative ileus without evidence of an anastomotic leak, and bowel function gradually improved with supportive care.
Due to poor oral intake and high ostomy output, he required albumin replacement, placement of a PICC line, and temporary total parenteral nutrition.
He developed a mild acute kidney injury that resolved with maintenance IV fluids, with creatinine returning to baseline prior to discharge.
At discharge on ___, he was tolerating a regular diet, ambulating with a walker, voiding independently, and managing ostomy output, with follow-up arranged with his PCP and surgical team.

input: <SEX> F <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> Penicillins / Strawberry / Citrus Flavor <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Shortness of breath. <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> -Paracentesis (5L fluid removed) ___. -Thoracentesis, right side ___. <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> This is a ___ year old female with a recent diagnosis of ovarian cancer. On a recent admission for new ascites and new effusion in the setting of omemental caking, fluid was positive for adenocarcinoma (ovarian). Cells stained positive for WT-1, cytokeratin 7 and focally for ER. She is followed by Dr. ___ who is helping to arrange initial treatment with chemotherapy prior to surgery. The patient is becoming increasingly symtpommatic (short of breath, unable to walk up stairs) from her effusion and continues to have abdominal pain from both her ascites and her renal stones. She is planning for Lithotripsy on ___. It is felt that a therapeutic thoracentesis and paracentesis prior to initiation of chemotherapy would be appropriate. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> PAST ONCOLOGIC HISTORY: -====== Several weeks prior to ___ patient developed shortness of breath and has had difficulty getting around. She reports abdominal distention. She is fairly fatigued. A CT scan recently performed revealed a "huge" amount of ascites with caking of the omentum and also bilateral pleural effusions, left greater than right. A pleural tap was performed on ___. This thoracentesis yielded 500 mL of serous fluid. The pathology from this pleural aspiration shows adenocarcinoma. Her most recent pelvic ultrasound was obtained on ___ and this revealed a stable fibroid uterus with a normal left ovary. The right ovary was not clearly identified and there was a moderate amount of ascites. Essentially, the only disease that she has at this point that is visible is the fluid and the omental cake. All told; however, this is consistent with a primary peritoneal cancer. Her CA-125 level is notably elevated at 226 and she has had a normal CEA level drawn. PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: -==== -Morbid obesity -Low back pain -Depression -OSA, severe, on nasal CPAP (setting 11) -Nephrolithiasis (calcium oxalate) -Hyperlipidemia -Mild aortic insufficiency with a history of prior use of fenfluramine -Perimenopausal mood disorder <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> She reports her brother had skin cancer (in his ___) and a nephew of hers had testicular cancer (at age ___. She has one aunts who developed breast cancer (in her ___). Another aunt had an unknown cancer. <PHYSICAL EXAM> Vitals - T 96.3, BP 114/63, HR 80, RR 22, 02 sat 94% on 1L. Tm 98.6, 114-138/60-69, 80-88, 22, 94-95% on 1L GENERAL: NAD SKIN: warm and well perfused, no excoriations or lesions, no rashes HEENT: AT/NC, EOMI, anicteric sclera, pink conjunctiva, patent nares, MMM, good dentition, nontender supple neck. CARDIAC: regular, distant heart sounds, S1/S2, soft systolic murmur LUNG: decreased breath sounds at bases. Left side with decreased sounds to midback. No crackles. ABDOMEN: soft, distended, +BS, tender in all quadrants, with LLQ most severe per patient, no rebound/guarding M/S: moving all extremities well, no cyanosis, clubbing or edema, no obvious deformities PULSES: 2+ DP pulses bilaterally NEURO: CN II-XII intact <PERTINENT RESULTS> Labs on admission: ___ 07: 05AM BLOOD Glucose-119* UreaN-16 Creat-1.1 Na-140 K-4.5 Cl-104 HCO3-26 AnGap-15 ___ 07: 05AM BLOOD ALT-9 AST-13 LD(___)-554* AlkPhos-78 TotBili-0.5 ___ 07: 05AM BLOOD Albumin-3.4 Calcium-8.8 Phos-4.3 Mg-2.5 Iron-26* ___ 07: 05AM BLOOD calTIBC-181* Hapto-425* Ferritn-357* TRF-139* ___ 04: 45PM BLOOD CA125-171* ___ 07: 05AM BLOOD WBC-8.3 RBC-3.92* Hgb-10.4* Hct-32.2* MCV-82 MCH-26.5* MCHC-32.2 RDW-16.7* Plt ___ ___ 07: 05AM BLOOD ___ PTT-24.3 ___ Labs on discharge: ___ 07: 05AM BLOOD WBC-12.6*# RBC-3.81* Hgb-9.9* Hct-31.2* MCV-82 MCH-26.1* MCHC-31.8 RDW-16.4* Plt ___ ___ 07: 05AM BLOOD Glucose-152* UreaN-13 Creat-0.8 Na-142 K-4.8 Cl-106 HCO3-26 AnGap-15 ___ 07: 05AM BLOOD LD(LDH)-428* ___ 07: 05AM BLOOD Calcium-8.7 Phos-3.3 Mg-2.6 Peritoneal fluid ___: POSITIVE FOR MALIGNANT CELLS consistent with adenocarcinoma (see note). Note: The cytologic features are consistent with the patient's prior Mullerian primary diagnosis. One hemepath slide was reviewed (778M ___ and showed similar findings. CTA chest ___: 1. No evidence of aortic dissection or pulmonary embolism. Please note the subsegmental branches are somewhat limited as described above. 2. Interval increase in now moderate-to-large bilateral pleural effusions which may account for the patient's dyspnea. There is compression atelectasis of a large portion of both lower lobes. Pleural fluid ___: POSITIVE FOR MALIGNANT CELLS, consistent with adenocarcinoma. Note: The cytologic features are consistent with patient's known Mullerian primary diagnosis. <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> - Albuterol Sulfate 90 mcg HFA Aerosol Inhaler 2 puffs q4hrs PRN - Percocet 54/325mg ___ tab q4 PRN - Lorazepam 1 mg Tablet q4 PRN anxiety - Prochlorperazine 10 mg 1 Tab TID PRN - Tylenol prn - Senna PRN - Colace PRN <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. Oxycodone-Acetaminophen ___ mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO Q4H (every 4 hours) as needed. 2. Docusate Sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2 times a day) as needed for constipation. 3. Senna 8.6 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO BID (2 times a day) as needed for constipation. 4. Lorazepam 1 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO Q4H (every 4 hours) as needed. You received Carboplatin and Taxol on ___ which you tolerated well. Your Lithotripsy on ___ should not be affected. You will follow up with Dr. ___ further chemotherapy. Please call ___ tomorrow, as your previously scheduled appointment for ___ be moved since you have already received your first cycle of chemotherapy during this admission. You are being prescribed Ondansteron (Zofran) for nausea. Your remaining medications were not changed. You should also continue to take Compazine (Prochlorperazine) as needed for nausea. Please return to the hospital or call your doctor if you have temperature greater than 101, shortness of breath, worsening difficulty with swallowing, chest pain, abdominal pain, diarrhea, or any other symptoms that you are concerned about.

draft_summary: Patient was admitted to the MICU with a diagnosis of acute decompensated heart failure (ADHF) due to elevated BNP levels and ventricular paced rhythm. The patient was comfortable breathing at 20 breaths per minute and was on bipap with 50% FiO2. The patient's oxygen saturation was 99% on room air. The patient reported dark tarry stools for the past 10 days without abdominal pain or NSAID use. The patient had a history of erosive gastritis on EGD and a recent colonoscopy with a single polyp removed. The patient was on multiple medications, including lisinopril, nitroglycerin, and sertraline. The patient was discharged with medications for heart failure, hypertension, and glaucoma. The patient was also prescribed aspirin for cardiovascular protection. The patient's dark tarry stools were not addressed during the hospital stay.
fixed_summary:
___ with a history of coronary artery disease status post CABG (LIMA to LAD, SVG to D1 and RI), heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (EF 30%), moderate to severe mitral and tricuspid regurgitation, dual-chamber pacemaker for Mobitz II, and prior prostatectomy for cancer, presented with acute onset dyspnea two weeks after a recent hospitalization for rectal bleeding.
He was found to be in acute respiratory distress consistent with cardiogenic pulmonary edema. He was started on BiPAP by EMS and continued on noninvasive ventilation in the MICU. He was treated with intravenous furosemide and a nitroglycerin infusion for afterload reduction, then transferred to the CCU in the setting of positive cardiac enzymes. His respiratory status improved with diuresis, and he was discharged on oral furosemide to prevent recurrent heart failure exacerbations.
Cardiac enzymes were elevated without chest pain or ischemic ECG changes. Given recent cardiac catheterization showing stable severe three-vessel disease and patent grafts, the troponin elevation was attributed to demand ischemia, and no repeat catheterization or dual antiplatelet therapy was pursued.
He reported intermittent melena for approximately 10 days prior to admission, but hematocrit remained stable. He was treated with proton pump inhibitor therapy, and gastroenterology recommended outpatient follow-up with possible endoscopic evaluation.
He was also found to be positive for C. difficile infection and was treated with oral antibiotics, with improvement in diarrhea.

target: Ms ___ is a ___ year old woman with a history of severe COPD on home O2 presenting with respiratory distress consistent with COPD exacerbation. #RESPIRATORY DISTRESS: Patient presented with several days of worsening dyspnea on exertion and tachycardia, and subjective fevers of unknown cause, consistent with mild COPD exacerbation. Furthermore, since she had been off of an inhaler anticholinergic and oral prednisone for the 2 weeks prior to presentation, her symptoms may simply be the result of severe under-treated COPD. She had already received doses of azithromycin and methylprednisolone in the ED. On arrival to the ICU initially she was comfortable and maintained adequate SPO2 on 4L NC, which is her home oxygen requirement. She was given albuterol/ipratropium nebs Q6h standing, and albuterol nebulizer Q2H PRN dyspnea. She received methylprednisolone 80mg IV q8H x 24 hours, which was then transitioned to prednisone 60mg PO daily which will be tapered slowly with the guidance of her pulmonologist. She was found to be tachycardic on the medical floor so she was changed to xopenex nebs. She should continue her home azithromycin on discharge. #ANXIETY: continued home escitalopram and lorazepam #HYPERTENSION: continued home verapamil and furosemide #OSTEOPOROSIS: continued home vitamin D Transitional issues: - this COPD exacerbation appears to have been provoked by stopping Spiriva, and changing Symbicort to mometasone/formeterol. On discharge from rehab will need to clarify if patient is able to obtain meds at home. - Please taper prednisone by 10mg qweekly

input: The patient was admitted to the neurosurgery service with an intraventricular mass in the ICU for close monitoring. He was started on Decadron and dilantin. An MRI was obtained to further characterize the lesion. A staging CT of the torso was obtained which showed metastasis to the lungs, left hilum, and spine. He was hydrated with bicarb fluids and given Mucomyst for renal protection prior to the CT scans. On HD#2 he was transferred to the neuro step down unit. A WAND study was obtained for image guidance of the resection. He was taken to the OR for resection of the brain mass on HD#5. He tolerated the procedure well and initially recovered in the PACU. He was extubated in the PACU without difficulty. He was then transferred to the neurosurgery step down unit. On POD#1 a repeat MRI was obtained which showed no bleeding. He was then transferred to the floor. On POD#2 his diet was advanced, his Foley was removed and he was seen by ___. His Decadron was weaned to 2 mg TID. He was seen by oncology and radiation oncology who recommended follow up in the brain tumor clinic and the ___ clinic. These appointments were set up for the patient. His antibiotics were stopped on POD#4. On POD#5 he was tolerating a regular diet, he had had a bowel movement, he was voiding without difficulty and he was cleared by ___ for home. He was discharged home with follow up instructions.

draft_summary:
The patient was admitted to the neurosurgery service in critical condition after being found unresponsive with signs of increased intracranial pressure.
Initial imaging revealed a massive intraventricular tumor causing acute hydrocephalus and midline shift.
He was emergently intubated and placed on continuous EEG monitoring due to recurrent seizure activity.
Further staging scans demonstrated widespread metastatic disease involving the liver, adrenal glands, and multiple vertebral levels.
His hospital course was complicated by acute kidney failure requiring dialysis following contrast administration.
On hospital day three, he developed respiratory failure and required prolonged mechanical ventilation in the ICU.
He ultimately underwent a complex, multi-stage craniotomy with partial tumor debulking and placement of an external ventricular drain.
Postoperatively, he suffered a significant intracranial hemorrhage and required repeat surgical intervention.
Despite aggressive treatment, his neurologic status remained poor with persistent aphasia and hemiplegia.
He was discharged to a long-term acute care facility with hospice consultation and a guarded prognosis.
fixed_summary:
The patient was admitted to the neurosurgery service and placed in the ICU for close monitoring after discovery of an intraventricular brain mass.
He was started on Decadron and Dilantin, and an MRI was obtained to better characterize the lesion.
As part of staging, a CT scan of the torso revealed metastatic disease involving the lungs, left hilum, and spine.
To protect renal function prior to contrast imaging, he was hydrated with bicarbonate-containing fluids and given Mucomyst.
On hospital day two, his condition was stable enough for transfer to the neuro step-down unit.
A WAND study was performed to assist with surgical planning and image-guided resection.
On hospital day five, he underwent surgical resection of the brain mass, which he tolerated well, recovering initially in the PACU and being extubated without difficulty.
A postoperative MRI on day one showed no evidence of bleeding, allowing transfer to the floor.
Over the next several days, his diet was advanced, his Foley catheter was removed, steroids were tapered, and antibiotics were discontinued.
By postoperative day five, he was tolerating a regular diet, voiding independently, and was cleared for discharge home with follow-up arranged in the appropriate oncology clinics.

Chronic kidney disease. POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSES: 1. Benign prostatic hypertrophy. 2. Chronic kidney disease. <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> These steps can help you recover after your procedure. -Drink plenty of water to flush out the bladder. -Avoid straining during a bowel movement. Eat fiber-containing foods and avoid foods that can cause constipation. Ask your doctor if you should take a laxative if you do become constipated. -Don't take blood-thinning medications until your doctor says it's OK. -Don't do any strenuous activity, such as heavy lifting, for four to six weeks or until your doctor says it's OK. -Don't have sex. You'll likely be able to resume sexual activity in about four to six weeks. Don't drive until your doctor says it's OK. ___, you can drive once your catheter is removed and you're no longer taking prescription pain medications. -You may continue to periodically see small amounts of blood in your urine--this is normal and will gradually improve -Resume your pre-admission/home medications EXCEPT as noted. You should ALWAYS call to inform, review and discuss any medication changes and your post-operative course with your primary care doctor. Should you HOLD ASPIRIN? Unless otherwise advised; If the urine is still pink, hold the aspirin until it has been clear/yellow for at least three days. -If prescribed; complete the full course of antibiotics. -You may be discharged home with a medication called PYRIDIUM that will help with the "burning" pain you may experience when voiding. This medication may turn your urine bright orange. -Colace has been prescribed to avoid post surgical constipation and constipation related to narcotic pain medication. Discontinue if loose stool or diarrhea develops. Colace is a stool softener, NOT a laxative - AVOID STRAINING for bowel movements as this may stir up bleeding. -Do not eat constipating foods for ___ weeks, drink plenty of fluids to keep hydrated -No vigorous physical activity or sports for 4 weeks or until otherwise advised -Do not lift anything heavier than a phone book (10 pounds) or participate in high intensity physical activity for a minimum of four weeks or until you are cleared by your Urologist in follow-up -Tylenol should be your first line pain medication, a narcotic pain medication has been prescribed for breakthrough pain >4. Replace Tylenol with narcotic pain medication. -Max daily Tylenol (acetaminophen) dose is 4 grams from ALL sources, note that narcotic pain medication also contains Tylenol -Do not drive or drink alcohol while taking narcotics and do not operate dangerous machinery. Also, if the Foley catheter and Leg Bag are in place--Do NOT drive (you may be a passenger). WHEN YOU ARE DISCHARGED WITH A FOLEY CATHETER: -Please also reference the nursing handout and instructions on routine care and hygiene -Your Foley should be secured to the catheter secure on your thigh at ALL times until your follow up with the surgeon. -DO NOT have anyone else other than your Surgeon or your surgeon's representative remove your Foley for any reason. -Wear Large Foley bag for majority of time; the leg bag is only for short-term periods for when leaving the house. -Do NOT drive if you have a Foley in place (for your safety)

The patient has had vascular abdominal ultrasounds every 6 months, and the last US showed that it was <5.5cm. However, he was most recently surveyed with a CTA, which showed that the AAA was 6.2cm in diameter. The patient has a history of sigmoid colectomy for diverticulitis c/b anastomotic breakdown requiring open abdomen and end colostomy. Due to his complicated abdominal anatomy, the patient was referred to Dr. ___ potential endovascular intervention. The patient has been asymptomatic. He denies chest pain, abdominal pain, back pain, fatigue in his thighs, claudication, rest pain, or "blue toe syndrome." The patient currently works approximately 5 hours a day. He is able to walk any distance and is able to climb stairs without having to stop. The patient is A current active smoker. He does report that he is attempting to quit smoking. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> PMH: HTN, arthritis, chronic back pain, diverticulitis <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> FH: Mother - HLD, macular degeneration, HTN Father - MI, heart failure Brother - lung cancer <PHYSICAL EXAM> Vitals: 24 HR Data (last updated ___ @ 803) Temp: 98.8 (Tm 99.3), BP: 144/75 (103-144/58-77), HR: 93 (78-98), RR: 19 (___), O2 sat: 100% (94-100), O2 delivery: RA, Wt: 201.1 lb/91.22 kg GENERAL: [X]NAD [X]A/O x 3 []intubated/sedated []abnormal CV: []RRR [] irregularly irregular []no MRG []Nl S1S2 []abnormal PULM: []CTA b/l [X]no respiratory distress []abnormal ABD: []soft []Nontender []appropriately tender []nondistended []no rebound/guarding []abnormal WOUND: [X]CD&I []no erythema/induration []abnormal EXTREMITIES: []no CCE []abnormal PULSES: R: / /P/P/ L: / /P/P/ <PERTINENT RESULTS> ___ 07: 57PM GLUCOSE-143* UREA N-13 CREAT-0.9 SODIUM-140 POTASSIUM-4.4 CHLORIDE-105 TOTAL CO2-23 ANION GAP-12 ___ 07: 57PM estGFR-Using this ___ 07: 57PM CALCIUM-8.4 PHOSPHATE-3.8 MAGNESIUM-1.6 ___ 07: 57PM WBC-11.4* RBC-3.89* HGB-12.0* HCT-36.3* MCV-93 MCH-30.8 MCHC-33.1 RDW-13.2 RDWSD-45.1 ___ 07: 57PM PLT COUNT-147* ___ 07: 57PM ___ PTT-88.3* ___ <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> Meclizine 20 mg as needed, lisinopril 20 mg daily, Lipitor 40 mg daily, Nexium 40 mg as needed, aspirin 81 mg daily, metoprolol XL 25 mg daily, multivitamin daily, vitamin B complex daily, vitamin C 500 mg daily, vitamin E 100 international unit daily, vitamin D ___ international units daily, fish oil 1200 mg daily, omega-3 360 mg daily <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. Aspirin EC 81 mg PO DAILY 2. Atorvastatin 40 mg PO QPM 3. Lisinopril 20 mg PO DAILY 4. Metoprolol Succinate XL 25 mg PO DAILY 5. Pantoprazole 40 mg PO Q24H <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home With Service Facility: ___ <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> Aortic Abdominal Aneurysm <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> You were admitted to ___ and underwent endovascular aneurysm repair. You have now recovered from surgery and are ready to be discharged. Please follow the instructions below to continue your recovery: MEDICATIONS: - Take Aspirin 325mg (enteric coated) once daily - Do not stop Aspirin unless your Vascular Surgeon instructs you to do so. - Continue all other medications you were taking before surgery, unless otherwise directed - You make take Tylenol or prescribed pain medications for any post procedure pain or discomfort WHAT TO EXPECT AT HOME: It is normal to have slight swelling of the legs: - Elevate your leg above the level of your heart (use ___ pillows or a recliner) every ___ hours throughout the day and at night - Avoid prolonged periods of standing or sitting without your legs elevated It is normal to feel tired and have a decreased appetite, your appetite will return with time - Drink plenty of fluids and eat small frequent meals - It is important to eat nutritious food options (high fiber, lean meats, vegetables/fruits, low fat, low cholesterol) to maintain your strength and assist in wound healing - To avoid constipation: eat a high fiber diet and use stool softener while taking pain medication ACTIVITIES: - When you go home, you may walk and go up and down stairs - You may shower (let the soapy water run over groin incision, rinse and pat dry) - Your incision may be left uncovered, unless you have small amounts of drainage from the wound, then place a dry dressing or band aid over the area that is draining, as needed - No heavy lifting, pushing or pulling (greater than 5 lbs) for 1 week (to allow groin puncture to heal) - After 1 week, you may resume sexual activity - After 1 week, gradually increase your activities and distance walked as you can tolerate - No driving until you are no longer taking pain medications CALL THE OFFICE FOR: ___ - Numbness, coldness or pain in lower extremities - Temperature greater than 101.5F for 24 hours - New or increased drainage from incision or white, yellow or green drainage from incisions - Bleeding from groin puncture site FOR SUDDEN, SEVERE BLEEDING OR SWELLING (Groin puncture site or incision) - Lie down, keep leg straight and have someone apply firm pressure to area for 10 minutes. If bleeding stops, call vascular office. If bleeding does not stop, call ___ for transfer to closest Emergency Room.
target: Mr. ___ is a ___ year old male with AAA who was admitted to the ___ on ___. The patient was taken to the endovascular suite and underwent FEVAR. For details of the procedure, please see the surgeon's operative note. The patient tolerated the procedure well without complications and was brought to the post-anesthesia care unit in stable condition. After a brief stay, the patient was transferred to the ICU at which time the patients lumbar drain was capped, SBPs were controlled briefly on/off nitro and eventually off nitro. On POD#1 we obtained a CTA which was negative for an endoleak, the patient was on a regular diet, drain was capped and we decided that the patient should stay in the ICU overnight. On POD#2, the patients drain came out, we removed the patients foley, A-line and moved the patient to our VICU. On POD#3 the patient was ambulating well and ready for discharge home. Post-operatively, he did well without any groin swelling. He was able to tolerate a regular diet, get out of bed and ambulate without assistance, void without issues, and pain was controlled on oral medications alone. He was deemed ready for discharge, and was given the appropriate discharge and follow-up instructions.

fixed_summary:
Mr. ___ is a ___-year-old male with an abdominal aortic aneurysm who was admitted to the ___ on ___.
He was taken to the endovascular suite where he underwent fenestrated endovascular aneurysm repair (FEVAR).
The procedure was completed without complication, and he was transferred to the post-anesthesia care unit in stable condition.
After a brief recovery period, he was moved to the ICU for postoperative monitoring.
At that time, his lumbar drain was capped and systolic blood pressures were managed intermittently with nitroglycerin before discontinuation.
On postoperative day one, a CTA was obtained and demonstrated no evidence of endoleak.
He was tolerating a regular diet, and the lumbar drain remained capped, prompting continued ICU observation overnight.
On postoperative day two, the lumbar drain was removed along with the Foley catheter and arterial line.
He was then transferred from the ICU to the vascular intermediate care unit.
By postoperative day three, he was ambulating well and showed no signs of groin complications.
He continued to tolerate a regular diet, voided without difficulty, and had pain well controlled with oral medications alone.
He was deemed medically stable for discharge home and was provided with appropriate discharge instructions and follow-up plans.

target: Ms. ___ was admitted for diagnosis and treatment of her shortness of breath. She remained afebrile. Outside records were obtained from ___ and CXR showed evidence of possible pulm edema. # Shortness of breath: DDx was broad, given hx of RA and immunosuppresion. Pleuritic chest pain was thought to be radiation from lung process (given negative extremity exam). CAP was considered most likely etiology of SOB. Less likely etiologies included: legionella (esp considering hyponatremia although urine ag negative)), TB (no hx of exposure, prior PPD negative). She was also treated for pulm edema suggested by CXR (however, echo was not consistent with CHF and EKG not suggestive of MI/ACS as cause of CHF). Her leukocytosis resolved (16.3-->10.8) on Levofloxacin. Pt also rec'd Lasix w good urine output. fixed_summary: The patient is a ___-year-old woman with a history of paradoxical vocal cord dysfunction, asthma/COPD, severe hypertension, insulin-dependent diabetes, cocaine use, and psychiatric illness who presented to the emergency department with one week of dyspnea. Although she reported shortness of breath and wheezing, she appeared comfortable on examination with good air movement, normal oxygen saturation on room air, a peak flow of approximately 450, and no clinical evidence of bronchospasm. Given her reported history of DVT/PE and left lower extremity swelling, pulmonary embolism was considered, but CT pulmonary angiography was negative. She was managed with her home inhalers and nebulized treatments with some symptomatic improvement and had no wheezing on examination at the time of discharge. Evaluation of her left leg swelling was negative, and anticoagulation was not continued after pharmacy review showed that rivaroxaban had not been picked up. Her blood pressure remained well controlled on lisinopril 40 mg daily. She also reported a recent fall with left hip pain, but imaging showed no fracture, and her pain was managed with acetaminophen while opioids were avoided due to prescription monitoring findings. Her diabetes was managed with her home NPH insulin regimen and sliding-scale insulin during hospitalization, with an A1c of 7.7% and no evidence of microvascular complications. She reported obstructive sleep apnea without current access to CPAP and difficulty obtaining sleep clinic follow-up, which was deferred to the outpatient setting. Psychiatrically, she showed no signs of acute psychosis and was continued on her last confirmed quetiapine regimen. Transitional issues included difficulty completing medication reconciliation, and she was advised to bring all medication bottles to her next primary care appointment.

draft_summary:
The patient presented after collapsing at home with sudden respiratory failure and was found to be in cardiogenic shock.
Initial imaging revealed massive bilateral pulmonary emboli and severe right heart strain requiring emergent thrombolysis.
Cardiac evaluation showed complete heart block and recurrent ventricular tachycardia necessitating temporary pacing.
She underwent urgent coronary angiography, which demonstrated triple-vessel disease requiring balloon angioplasty.
Her hospital course was complicated by acute liver failure, renal failure requiring dialysis, and septic shock.
An echocardiogram revealed a ruptured papillary muscle with severe mitral regurgitation and a ventricular septal defect.
Despite aggressive ICU management, she required prolonged mechanical ventilation and vasopressor support.
She was ultimately discharged to a long-term care facility with hospice consultation and a poor overall prognosis.
fixed_summary: The patient, with limited prior medical history, presented with progressive dyspnea on exertion and orthopnea three weeks after a viral upper respiratory infection. Initial evaluation revealed severe volume overload with a markedly elevated BNP of 6915, cardiomegaly with pulmonary vascular congestion, and small bilateral pleural effusions on chest imaging. Transthoracic echocardiography demonstrated new severe systolic heart failure with an ejection fraction of 15% and global ventricular dysfunction, representing a significant decline from a prior study showing preserved function. She was treated with intravenous furosemide and successfully diuresed to a dry weight of 80.2 kg, with improvement in her symptoms. A contrast-enhanced echocardiogram subsequently identified a large apical left ventricular thrombus, and anticoagulation was initiated with enoxaparin bridging to warfarin. Given the presence of the thrombus, invasive coronary angiography was deferred, with plans for outpatient evaluation including cardiac MRI and eventual coronary assessment. She was started on guideline-directed medical therapy with metoprolol succinate and lisinopril, which were well tolerated, and discharged on a stable diuretic regimen along with a wearable defibrillator after discussion with her family. At discharge, she was euvolemic, hemodynamically stable, and had close follow-up arranged for anticoagulation monitoring and heart failure management.

target: Ms. ___ was admitted to the Urology service after undergoing open radical cystectomy, bilateral salpingo-oopherectomy, partial vaginectomy with ileal conduit. No concerning intrao-perative events occurred; please see dictated operative note for details. Patient received ___ intravenous antibiotic prophylaxis and deep vein thrombosis prophylaxis with subcutaneous heparin. Perioperative pain was managed with epidural. On POD2 the patient became extremely agitated overnight requiring IV Haldol. Narcotic was removed from the epidural and toradol was discontinued. Geriatric medicine was consulted who recommended seroquel for agitation and PRN Haldol, which was not needed again. The epidural was removed on POD3 and the patient was started on oral pain medication. No narcotics were needed. The patient was transitioned to lovenox for DVT prophylaxis and started on macrobid for infectious prophylaxis on POD5. With the eventual passage of flatus, diet was gradually advanced. The ostomy nurse saw the patient for ostomy teaching. At the time of discharge the wound was healing well with no evidence of erythema, swelling, or purulent drainage. Her surgical drain was removed. The ostomy was perfused and patent and the ureteral stents were visible. Post-operative follow up appointments were arranged/discussed and the patient was discharged to rehab.
draft_summary:
Patient admitted with acute coronary syndrome (ACS) due to ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI). The patient was treated with enoxaparin sodium 40 mg SC daily, nitrofurantoin monohyd 100 mg PO daily, and quetiapine fumarate 12.5 mg PO daily. The patient was also prescribed acetaminophen 1000 mg PO q6h as needed for pain. The patient was instructed to take docusate sodium 100 mg PO bid to prevent constipation. The patient was advised to avoid vigorous physical activity or sports for 4 weeks and to drink plenty of fluids to stay hydrated. The patient was also instructed to notify their doctor if they develop blood in their stool or if they experience increased redness, swelling, or discharge from their incision. The patient was discharged on day 30. 

Note: The date of admission is not provided in the record.

draft_summary: The patient is a middle-aged man with relapsed AML status post stem cell transplant complicated by severe graft failure, end-stage liver disease, and recurrent septic shock, admitted emergently for worsening respiratory failure during dialysis. He received high-dose IVIG for acute immunologic collapse and was treated for presumed fungal pneumonia with amphotericin. His GVHD had progressed to involve the brain and kidneys, prompting escalation of ruxolitinib to daily dosing. He developed recurrent MRSA bacteremia requiring prolonged IV vancomycin and removal of all central lines. Dialysis was complicated by hypotension and cardiac arrest, though he ultimately stabilized. He was discharged on hospice with plans for comfort-focused care and no further chemotherapy.
fixed_summary: The patient is a ___-year-old individual with a history of acute myeloid leukemia status post unrelated allogeneic stem cell transplant complicated by chronic graft-versus-host disease, hypogammaglobulinemia, heart failure with reduced ejection fraction, and end-stage renal disease on hemodialysis, who was admitted for a scheduled intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) infusion coordinated with dialysis. The patient requires monthly IVIG, and a 25-gram dose was administered during this admission without complication.The patient remains in remission from AML and continues treatment for chronic GVHD with ruxolitinib, which was increased to 20 mg three times weekly after dialysis. Home prophylactic medications, including antiviral and antipneumocystis prophylaxis, were continued, as was daily prednisone. The patient has a history of Staphylococcus bacteremia previously treated with intravenous vancomycin; IV therapy was completed, and the patient was transitioned to oral minocycline for suppression per infectious disease recommendations. Vancomycin locks for the port and dialysis catheter were continued pending outpatient reassessment. The patient underwent scheduled hemodialysis during admission and remained clinically stable without evidence of volume overload or hypoxia. Chronic pulmonary GVHD remained stable on home BiPAP and inhaled therapies. Pain, anticoagulation for prior pulmonary embolism, heart failure medications, nutritional support, and chronic psychiatric medications were continued. The patient was discharged home in stable condition with close outpatient follow-up arranged.

target: Ms. ___ was admitted given her persistent shortness of breath and hypertension. With regards to her shortness of breath, her work up included a CXR, ECHO, and CTA. Her CXR showed cardiac enlargement and prominent pulmonary vasculature. Her ECHO showed a normal ejection fraction however did have elevated pulmonary artery pressures. This finding prompted a CTA given concern for PE causing pulmonary hypertension. The CTA was negative for PE however did show small pleural effusions. Cardiac enzymes were checked and were normal. Given orthopnea/ PND/ and ?fluid overload on CXR/CTA, lasix was given x2 with excellent UOP response and significant improvement in her symptoms. Throughout her admission she was afebrile and her O2sat remained 95-98% on room air. Following the 2nd dose of lasix she required no further intervention as she was asymptomatic. Ms. ___ blood pressures were very labile and this was the focus of much of the admission. Her blood pressures ranged from 120-170/80-100's. She was started on nifedipine CR 30 daily which was titrated up to 30 BID. Labetalol was initially held on admission as she was started on nifedipine, however this was restarted at 200mg BID ___ persistently elevated BP's and this brought her BP's to normal/ mild range. Ms. ___ was discharged on HD #4 in stable condition. She was no longer short of breath and her blood pressures were stable x 24 hours.
draft_summary: The patient was admitted for evaluation of symptoms suggestive of a primary pulmonary process. The patient had mild-moderate mitral regurgitation and a dilated aortic arch, which suggested a possible pulmonary issue. The chest X-ray showed an enlarged cardiac silhouette with prominence of pulmonary vessels, and the CT scan of the chest revealed fluid in the lungs. The patient was treated with nifedipine and labetalol for hypertension, and was advised to continue taking these medications as prescribed. The patient was discharged with a plan to follow up with the physician for further evaluation and management of the underlying condition.

target: Mr. ___ is admitted to urology with muscle invasive bladder cancer and is now status post robotic radical cystectomy with ileal conduit creation. No concerning intrao-perative events occurred; please see dictated operative note for details. Mr. ___ received ___ intravenous antibiotic prophylaxis and SubQ heparin thrombosis prophylaxis. The patient was transferred from the PACU in stable condition before transfer to the general surgical floor. Intravenous fluids and IV pain control provided via PCA. The post-operative course was not complicated. Our colleagues in rehabilitation services ___ and/or OT) were consulted for evaluation and treatment. With the eventual passage of flatus, diet was gradually advanced and the patient was transitioned from IV pain medication to oral pain medications. With the advancement to clears, converted to Lovenox for thrombosis prophylaxis and also started on ureteral stent prophylaxis with daily Macrobid. Entereg was continued through first bowel movement. The ostomy nurse specialist had regular encounters and teaching visits and facilitated discharge needs/stoma care supplies. Education on cystectomy diet was provided by nutrition services. At the time of discharge the wound was healing well without evidence of erythema, swelling, or purulent drainage. Drain fluid was sent for creatine prior to removal. At discharge, the urostomy was perfused and patent and the ureteral stents were visible. Post-operative follow up appointments were arranged/discussed and the patient was discharged home with visiting nurse services to further assist the transition to home with ostomy care. He was discharged with PICC (non-heparin) at RUE for IVF administration every-other-day.

Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker or cane). <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> 1. Please return to the emergency department or notify your physician if you experience any of the following: severe pain not relieved by medication, increased swelling, decreased sensation, difficulty with movement, fevers greater than 101.5, shaking chills, increasing redness or drainage from the incision site, chest pain, shortness of breath or any other concerns. 2. Please follow up with your primary physician regarding this admission and any new medications and refills. 3. Resume your home medications unless otherwise instructed. 4. You have been given medications for pain control. Please do not drive, operate heavy machinery, or drink alcohol while taking these medications. As your pain decreases, take fewer tablets and increase the time between doses. This medication can cause constipation, so you should drink plenty of water daily and take a stool softener (such as Colace) as needed to prevent this side effect. Call your surgeons office 3 days before you are out of medication so that it can be refilled. These medications cannot be called into your pharmacy and must be picked up in the clinic or mailed to your house. Please allow an extra 2 days if you would like your medication mailed to your home. 5. You may not drive a car until cleared to do so by your surgeon. 6. Please call your surgeon's office to schedule or confirm your follow-up appointment. 7. SWELLING: Ice the operative joint 20 minutes at a time, especially after activity or physical therapy. Do not place ice directly on the skin. You may wrap the knee with an ace bandage for added compression. Please DO NOT take any non-steroidal anti-inflammatory medications (NSAIDs such as Celebrex, ibuprofen, Advil, Aleve, Motrin, naproxen etc) until cleared by your physician. 8. ANTICOAGULATION: Please continue your Aspirin 325 mg twice daily for four (4) weeks to help prevent deep vein thrombosis (blood clots). Continue Pantoprazole daily while on Aspirin to prevent GI upset (x 4 weeks). If you were taking Aspirin prior to your surgery, take it at 325 mg twice daily until the end of the 4 weeks, then you can go back to your normal dosing. 9. WOUND CARE: Please keep your incision clean and dry. It is okay to shower five days after surgery but no tub baths, swimming, or submerging your incision until after your four (4) week checkup. Please place a dry sterile dressing on the wound each day if there is drainage, otherwise leave it open to air. Check wound regularly for signs of infection such as redness or thick yellow drainage. Staples will be removed by ___ in two weeks. 10. ___ (once at home): Home ___, dressing changes as instructed, wound checks. 11. ACTIVITY: Weight bearing as tolerated on the operative extremity. Mobilize. Posterior precautions. No strenuous exercise or heavy lifting until follow up appointment. Mobilize frequently. Physical Therapy: WBAT RLE Posterior hip precautions x 6 weeks from date of surgery Wean assistive devices as able (i.e., 2 crutches, walker) Mobilize frequently Treatments Frequency: daily dressing changes as needed for drainage wound checks daily ice staple removal and replace on POD14-17 at ___

Ms. ___ is discharged to home with services in stable condition.
