target: Pt is ___ yo M with hx of of prior silent MI, HTN, HLD, transitional cell carcinoma (s/p radiation, no surgery or chemo) who p/w LLE edema and swelling . # DVT: Given the patient's history of bladder cancer and radiation within the past year, his LLE edema was most consistent on presentation with lymphatic obstruction, either from reseeding of the lymphatic bed with tumor or direct damage from radiation. However, the patient's pain on hip flexion, tenderness in the left hip, and acute onset suggested DVT. LENIs were negative, suggesting a more proximal DVT. He was started on a heparin drip on admission. CT abd/pelvis the following day demonstrated a 2cm DVT in the left external iliac vein. The patient's heparin drip was continued, and he was started on 5mg coumadin. His INR remained subtherapeutic, and his coumadin was increased to 10mg. The patient initially refused to go home on Lovenox injections on account of his fear of needles but after several attempts at counseling, he agreed to administer his own Lovenox with the assistance of a home ___ until his INR became therapeutic. He was discharged with 110mg BID Lovenox injections, 10mg coumadin qdaily, and scheduled to follow-up with his PCP to manage his anticoagulation over the next 6 months. He should follow-up with oncology or his PCP regarding how long to continue on anticoagulation given that inciting cause of DVT was either malignancy or XRT and it is unclear whether the provoking agent can ever be considered removed. . # Acute renal insufficiency: The patient's baseline Cr is 1.2 and was 1.3 on admission. Per the patient, he has been dehydrated the previous 2 days. His Cr remained at baseline after adequate IVF rehydration and was 1.2 upon discharge. . # Bladder CA - In-house CT abd/pelvis showed no evidence of recurrence or metastatic spread of patient's previous bladder cancer. The patient was scheduled for routine surveillance CT in ___, and we have communicated with his radiation oncologist in order to cancel this study, if the in-house CT performed during this hospitalization is sufficient to rule out recurrence. . # HTN - The patient's blood pressure was well-controlled throughout his hospitalization on his home anti-hypertensives. . # Hyperlipidemia - The patient was continued on his home statin. . # S/p silent MI - Given the patient's history of silent MI, we have communicated with the patient's PCP regarding aspirin and ACE inhibitor therapy. He will follow-up with his PCP for further management of this condition. .

fixed_summary:
The patient is a ___-year-old man with a history of prior silent myocardial infarction, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and transitional cell carcinoma of the bladder status post radiation therapy, who presented with left lower extremity swelling and edema.
Given his recent cancer history and radiation exposure, lymphatic obstruction was initially considered, but the acute onset of pain, hip tenderness, and swelling raised concern for deep vein thrombosis.
Initial lower extremity Doppler studies were negative, suggesting a more proximal clot, and he was started on a heparin infusion on admission.
A CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis subsequently revealed a 2 cm thrombus in the left external iliac vein.
Heparin was continued, and warfarin was initiated with dose escalation due to a persistently subtherapeutic INR.
Although he initially declined outpatient injections, the patient ultimately agreed to self-administer enoxaparin with home assistance until his INR becomes therapeutic.
He was discharged on enoxaparin 110 mg twice daily and warfarin 10 mg daily, with close follow-up arranged with his primary care physician to manage anticoagulation over the next six months.
His renal function remained stable throughout hospitalization, returning to baseline after intravenous fluid rehydration.
CT imaging showed no evidence of recurrent or metastatic bladder cancer, and coordination with his radiation oncologist was initiated regarding future surveillance imaging.
His blood pressure and lipid levels remained well controlled on home medications, and follow-up with his primary care physician was planned to address secondary prevention related to his prior silent myocardial infarction.

draft_summary: An adult female with a history of colon cancer status post resection, breast cancer status post bilateral mastectomy, osteoporosis, and asthma presented with bright red blood per rectum. She reported three episodes of bleeding in the morning, sufficient to turn the toilet water red, which resolved spontaneously. She denied abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, dizziness, or lightheadedness at the time of bleeding. She noted a brief episode of crampy abdominal pain the prior night that resolved after a non-bloody loose bowel movement. She reported one prior self-limited episode of rectal bleeding earlier in the year. Her last colonoscopy was several years ago. On examination, she was hemodynamically stable and in no acute distress. Abdominal exam was benign. Laboratory studies showed stable hemoglobin and hematocrit without evidence of ongoing bleeding. Coagulation studies and basic metabolic panel were unremarkable. No invasive procedures were performed during this admission. She did not experience recurrent bleeding while hospitalized, and her blood counts remained stable. The lower gastrointestinal bleed was considered resolved. She was discharged home in stable condition with instructions to resume home medications, including doxycycline for presumed Lyme disease, and to contact her gastroenterologist promptly for outpatient follow-up and further evaluation. She was advised to seek medical attention if bleeding recurred or if new concerning symptoms developed.
fixed_summary:
The patient is a ___-year-old woman with a history of colon cancer and breast cancer who presented with bright red blood per rectum.
The bleeding resolved prior to admission after she received intravenous fluids in the emergency department, and she was admitted for monitoring.
Her hematocrit was mildly decreased to 39.1 at the time of discharge, which was felt to be due to hemodilution rather than ongoing blood loss.
She remained hemodynamically stable throughout hospitalization with negative orthostatic vital signs prior to discharge.
The episode of bleeding followed straining with a large bowel movement and was painless, making a hemorrhoidal source most likely.
Other potential etiologies, including diverticulosis, arteriovenous malformations, or malignancy, were also considered given her history.
She had no further episodes of bleeding during hospitalization and remained afebrile with low suspicion for infectious causes.
Given her history of colon cancer and the interval since her last colonoscopy, outpatient gastrointestinal evaluation with full colonoscopy was recommended.
The patient reported she was already in contact with her gastroenterologist and planned to arrange follow-up promptly.
Her asthma remained stable, and she was continued on nebulizer treatments and a prednisone taper as previously prescribed.
She was advised to continue doxycycline for Lyme disease, with reassurance provided regarding her concerns about this medication.
She was discharged home in stable condition on a diet as tolerated, with no pharmacologic DVT prophylaxis given recent gastrointestinal bleeding and plans for close outpatient GI follow-up.

Medical: #Chronic nausea- No acute issues, still with chronic nausea slightly improved with ECT. Continued home Prilosec 20 mg bid and Zantac 300 mg qhs. He was also given Zofran ODT 4mg bid PRN for nausea, although this did not help. #BPH- continued pt's home meds: tamsulosin 0.4 bid, Avodart 0.5 mg daily Collateral: Spoke with outpatient psychiatrist, Dr. ___. Dr. ___ has been treating patient since ___. Patient frequently makes SI comments that he wants to die because of his intractable nausea. However, patient has never acted on these urges/comments or been psychiatrically hospitalized. Psychiatrist says that he believes patient's nausea is associated with his depression. The nausea has been extensively worked up in past, both by gastroenterology and PCP, and has never revealed any pathology. Dr. ___ that nausea may be a manifestation of psychotic depression, and this is why he referred patient for ECT. Dr. ___ that patient has cluster A traits such as becoming paranoid and he never speaks of friends/family. Dr. ___ that he would prefer Mr. ___ to engage in psychotherapy as well as continuing to see to Dr. ___ psychiatric follow up. Spoke with PCP, ___. PCP relates that patient is relatively new to her. He has previously been extensively worked up in past for nausea ___ years. He had celiac/ h pylori workup that was negative. He has had both colonoscopy and EGD (___ last year) that was nonremarkable, but with a slight hiatial hernia. She has tried zantac/prilosec on him, but these do not seem to help. PCP has also done abdominal MRI, that did not reveal any pathology. She was considering referring him to GI again for furthur workup. PCP agrees that nausea seems linked with depression. PCP also said that in past patient has endorsed suicidal ideation, but he would say he had no intent to kill himself and he never had a plan. Risk Assessment: Patient is at moderate chronic risk of harm to self. Pt has no prior hospitalizations, SAs, family history of SA, no hx of impulsivity or substance use, and is help seeking. However, pt is also an unmarried white, elderly male living alone, has questionable reality testing ability, has frequent SI related to his intolerable and intractable nausea (and has hopelessness and anxiety regarding this), and has the means to act on his plan. It was reassuring to hear from the patient's psychiatrist and PCP, both say that patient's SI is a recurrent problem that is not new, suggesting that patient is at an elevated chronic risk to self, but his imminent risk is low/unchanged. While on Deaconness 4 patient's risk factors were modified by ECT therapy and change to aripiprazole for better cotnrol of both mood and delusions. He was encouraged to participate in outpatient psychotherapy. He reports that if he begins to feel worse he will go to the ___ 1 mile from his house.
draft_summary: Patient was admitted for suicidal ideation and plan to harm self. Patient reported worsening nausea and suicidal thoughts. Patient was treated with phenelzine sulfate, ziprasidone hydrochloride, clonazepam, tamsulosin, and dutasteride. Patient was discharged with aripiprazole, tamsulosin, and instructions to follow up with outpatient appointments and continue prescribed medications. Patient was advised to avoid abusing alcohol and drugs and to contact providers if concerns arise. Patient was also advised to call emergency services if feeling unsafe.
fixed_summary: Patient was treated with phenelzine sulfate, ziprasidone hydrochloride, clonazepam, tamsulosin, and dutasteride. Patient was discharged with aripiprazole, tamsulosin, and instructions to follow up with outpatient appointments and continue prescribed medications. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> -Please follow up with all outpatient appointments as listed - take this discharge paperwork to your appointments. -Please continue all medications as directed. -Please avoid abusing alcohol and any drugs--whether prescription drugs or illegal drugs--as this can further worsen your medical and psychiatric illnesses. -Please contact your outpatient psychiatrist or other providers if you have any concerns. -Please call ___ or go to your nearest emergency room if you feel unsafe in any way and are unable to immediately reach your health care providers. *It was a pleasure to have worked with you, and we wish you Patient was advised to avoid abusing alcohol and drugs and to contact providers if concerns arise.

input: <SEX> M <SERVICE> SURGERY <ALLERGIES> tacrolimus <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> symptomatic splenomegaly <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> ___ Splenic artery Embolization ___ pseudoaneurysm embolization ___ ERCP with stent <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> Mr. ___ is a ___ yo male s/p liver transplant on ___ for NASH cirrhosis who is presenting today as a planned admission for pain control after a mid-pole splenic embolization for symptomatic splenomegaly. His post transplant course has been complicated by significant immunodeficiency, pancytopenia derived from thalassemia, pyruvate kinase deficiency and a profound splenomegaly. Mr. ___ was hospitalized recently for a pneumonia likely developed in the setting of immunodeficiency as well as sinusitis. He was treated with IV vancomycin, Zosyn, erythromycin and ceftriaxone for a total of seven days. He has been getting weekly aranesp shots by hematology. He is currently on CSA 100mg BID and Creat 2.5-3.0.m PLT count is 37, so he required 2u FFP prior to the procedure today. On presentation, Mr. ___ denies any pain (abdominal, groin, or otherwise), nausea, vomiting, fevers, chills, headaches, chest pain, diarrhea, or constipation. He does endorse some SOB, however, this has been stable for years. He is voiding and stooling normally. This morning he took 6u of Lantus instead of his normal dose of 12u, otherwise he took all of his medications as prescribed. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> 1. ___ cirrhosis complicated by mild ascites, portal hypertension in the form esophageal varices and splenomegaly. - S/p variceal bleed s/p banding ___ - S/p TIPS ___ and TIPS redo/downsize ___ d/t recurrent hepatic encephalopathy and TIPS stenosis - S/p OLT ___ from ___ year old ABO compatible standard criteria brain dead donor 2. S/p OLT ___: No history of rejection, no history of BK, high CMV risk D+/R-. On tacrolimus monotherapy. For PPX he is on atovoquone from Bactrim due to persistent leukopenia. 2. Pyruvate kinase deficiency, complicated by chronic hemolysis. 3. Cholelithiasis, likely related to pigment stones from chronic hemolysis. 4. Beta thalassemia. 5. History of iron deficiency on iron supplementation. 6. Diabetes mellitus, on insulin. 7. History of migraines. 8. Chronic back pain and leg pain status post fall in ___. 9. Gout. 10. History of right cheek basal cell carcinoma excised in ___. <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> There is a family history of thalassemia trait and arthritis. There is no family history of liver disease or GI cancers. No famly history of CAD/MI. <PHYSICAL EXAM> P/E: VS: T: 97.2 P: 59 BP: 162/76 RR: 18 O2sat: 95 RA GEN: WD, WN in NAD HEENT: NCAT, anicteric, MMM, EOMI CV: RRR PULM: non-labored, no respiratory distress ABD: soft, NT, ND, no mass, +splenomegaly. 1.5 cm incisional hernia present. L inguinal hernia present. Groin: R groin puncture site with angioseal present over top. no swelling present, area slightly tender to palpation. minimal shadowing present on dressing. EXT: WWP, 2+ radial pulses, palpable femoral pulses b/l and palpable DP pulse b/l. NEURO: A&Ox3, no focal neurologic deficits <PERTINENT RESULTS> Admission Labs: ___ 07: 43AM BLOOD WBC-2.3* RBC-3.11* Hgb-7.1* Hct-23.6* MCV-76* MCH-22.8* MCHC-30.1* RDW-17.1* RDWSD-47.3* Plt Ct-28* ___ 07: 43AM BLOOD ___ ___ 07: 43AM BLOOD Creat-3.0* ___ 05: 20AM BLOOD Glucose-103* UreaN-32* Creat-2.7* Na-139 K-4.7 Cl-109* HCO3-18* AnGap-17 ___ 05: 20AM BLOOD ALT-20 AST-51* AlkPhos-54 TotBili-2.4* DirBili-1.4* IndBili-1.0 ___ 05: 20AM BLOOD Calcium-7.8* Phos-3.3 Mg-1.3* ___ 05: 20AM BLOOD Cyclspr-64* Discharge Labs: ___ 03: 23AM BLOOD WBC-6.1# RBC-3.32* Hgb-8.2* Hct-24.9* MCV-75* MCH-24.7* MCHC-32.9 RDW-18.6* RDWSD-49.2* Plt Ct-44* ___ 03: 23AM BLOOD ___ PTT-27.2 ___ ___ 03: 23AM BLOOD Glucose-120* UreaN-40* Creat-3.0* Na-136 K-5.4* Cl-106 HCO3-14* AnGap-21* ___ 03: 23AM BLOOD ALT-<5 AST-8 AlkPhos-56 Amylase-25 TotBili-5.0* ___ 03: 23AM BLOOD Calcium-8.0* Phos-3.8 Mg-1.7 ___ 06: 08AM BLOOD Cyclspr-122 ___ 05: 58AM BLOOD Cyclspr-125 ___ 03: 23AM BLOOD Cyclspr-197 ___ 05: 46AM BLOOD Hapto-49 <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete. 1. CycloSPORINE (Neoral) MODIFIED 100 mg PO Q12H 2. Albuterol Inhaler ___ PUFF IH Q4H: PRN sob/wheeze/cough 3. Atovaquone Suspension 1500 mg PO DAILY 4. Nephrocaps 1 CAP PO DAILY 5. Aranesp (in polysorbate) (darbepoetin alfa in polysorbat) 100 mcg/0.5 mL injection 1X/WEEK ___ 6. Vitamin D ___ UNIT PO 1X/WEEK (MO) 7. Filgrastim 300 mcg SC PRN: AS DIRECTED BY TRANSPLANT CLINIC neutropenia 8. Fludrocortisone Acetate 0.1 mg PO 3X/WEEK (___) 9. FoLIC Acid 4 mg PO DAILY 10. Glargine 12 Units Breakfast Insulin SC Sliding Scale using HUM Insulin 11. Metoprolol Succinate XL 150 mg PO BID 12. Ondansetron 8 mg PO DAILY: PRN nausea. takes prior to am meds 13. Pantoprazole 40 mg PO Q12H 14. Acetaminophen ___ mg PO Q8H: PRN Pain - Mild <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. HYDROmorphone (Dilaudid) 2 mg PO Q8H: PRN Pain - Moderate RX *hydromorphone 2 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth every eight (8) hours Disp #*10 Tablet Refills: *0 2. Glargine 12 Units Breakfast Insulin SC Sliding Scale using HUM Insulin 3. Acetaminophen ___ mg PO Q8H: PRN Pain - Mild do not take more than 3000mg of Tylenol in 24 hours 4. Albuterol Inhaler ___ PUFF IH Q4H: PRN sob/wheeze/cough 5. Aranesp (in polysorbate) (darbepoetin alfa in polysorbat) 100 mcg/0.5 mL injection 1X/WEEK ___ 6. Atovaquone Suspension 1500 mg PO DAILY 7. CycloSPORINE (Neoral) MODIFIED 100 mg PO Q12H 8. Filgrastim 300 mcg SC PRN: AS DIRECTED BY TRANSPLANT CLINIC neutropenia 9. Fludrocortisone Acetate 0.1 mg PO 3X/WEEK (___) 10. FoLIC Acid 4 mg PO DAILY 11. Metoprolol Succinate XL 150 mg PO BID 12. Nephrocaps 1 CAP PO DAILY 13. Ondansetron 8 mg PO DAILY: PRN nausea. takes prior to am meds 14. Pantoprazole 40 mg PO Q12H 15. Vitamin D ___ UNIT PO 1X/WEEK (MO) <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> Symptomatic Splenomegaly s/p splenic artery embolization. anemia ___ nephropathy <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> Please have your labs drawn tomorrow, ___ MEDICATION: - Continue all other medications you were taking before surgery, unless otherwise directed - You make take Tylenol or prescribed pain medications for any post procedure pain or discomfort WHAT TO EXPECT: - It is normal to feel tired and have a decreased appetite, your appetite will return with time - Drink plenty of fluids and eat small frequent meals - It is important to eat nutritious food options (high fiber, lean meats, vegetables/fruits, low fat, low cholesterol) to maintain your strength and assist in wound healing - To avoid constipation: eat a high fiber diet ACTIVITIES: - When you go home, you may walk and use stairs - You may shower (let the soapy water run over groin incision, rinse and pat dry) - The groin puncture site may be left uncovered, unless you have small amounts of drainage from the wound, then place a dry dressing or band aid over the area - No heavy lifting, pushing or pulling (greater than 5 lbs) for 1 week (to allow groin puncture to heal) - No driving until you are no longer taking pain medications CALL THE OFFICE FOR: ___ - Numbness, coldness or pain in lower extremities - Temperature greater than 101.5F for 24 hours - New or increased drainage from incision or white, yellow or green drainage from incisions - Bleeding from groin puncture site SUDDEN, SEVERE BLEEDING OR SWELLING (Groin puncture site) - Lie down, keep leg straight and have someone apply firm pressure to area for 10 minutes. If bleeding stops, call Interventional Radiology office ___. If bleeding does not stop, call ___ for transfer to closest Emergency Room.
target: Mr. ___ was admitted to the Transplant Surgery Service under Dr. ___ on ___ for pain control after a splenic artery embolization done by the Interventional Radiology service. He received PO Dilaudid and standing tylenol for pain control during his hospital stay. On the morning of ___, his Hct was 19.4, a repeat Hct was 18.6. He was given 2u pRBCs. A post-transfusion Hct was 22. He spiked to 102.7 for which he was pan-cultred. CXR was negative for pneumonia. IV Zosyn was started for empiric coverage. Right groin puncture site pain was persistent. U/S of the area identified a 2.5 cm partially thrombosed right groin pseudoaneurysm, with a neck measuring 3 mm in width. Hct decreased to 19 again. IV Vitamin K was given for INR of 2.9. An abdominal CT was also done demonstrating just ascites. Post CT, creatinine increased to 3.9. He was bloused with IV fluid for low urine output. ___ then embolized the pseudoaneurysm on ___. Postop, embolization, right groin appeared ecchymotic with positive distal pulses. He had less pain in the right groin. Hct was down to 17. Two units of PRBC were transfused with post hct of 23. Postop transfusion, he had an 8 beat run of VTach that resolved. Calcium repletion was given for calcium of 7.5. Hct stabilized at ___. LFTs were notable of rise in t.bili to 3.9. ERCP was done on to interrogate the metal stent on ___. It was noted that the previously placed metal stent had migrated, a CBD anastomotic stricture was noted and a new MS was placed. He tolerated this procedure well and diet was advanced to regular the next day. A repeat U/S of the groin was done on ___lood flow at the neck of the pseudoaneurysm which may represent a small arterial branch vessel. No documented flow within the body of the pseudoaneurysm. He continued to have discomfort at this site as well as abdominal and back pain for which he was receiving po Dilaudid. He was taking a total of ___ per day of the Dilaudid. The plan was to send him home with a script for dilaudid 2mg prn every 8 hours with only 10 tabs. Of note, the anemia/hemolysis w/u was negative. He received a total of 3 units of prbc. Leukopenia was improving. Blood and urine cultures were negative to date. Creatinine increased and this was likely related to the contrast given during the angiogram. Creatinine increased to 3.9, but had decreased to 3.0 on the day of discharge. Potassium was elevated to 5.4. He was instructed to follow a low potassium diet, have his labs checked on ___ and to resume the Florinef. Weight was 77kg up from admission weight of 71kg. Urine output was averaging 400cc/day. A repeat right groin U/S should be done one week from ___ to assess pseudoaneurysm. At time of discharge, vitals signs were stable, he was a regular diet, ambulating independently.

input: Mr. ___ is a ___ y/o male with h/o IVDU, homelessness, HCV, cirrhosis, ascites, BLE cellulitis x 6 months who presented as ___ transfer with worsening of his preexisting cellulitis and two days of scrotal induration, erythema, and tenderness. There was initially concern for necrotizing infection or ___ gangrene. However, CT scan showed no subcutaneous gas, and consulting teams from urology and ___ surgery did not feel exam consistent with such. He was initially on Zosyn, Vanc, Clindamycin (Day 1 = ___. Clindamycin was discontinued on ___, and he was transitioned to oral antibiotics on ___ based on prior culture data. Patient with significant ascites on arrival, in setting of not taking home diuretics for over one week. Underwent 6.5L paracentesis on ___, with ascitic fluid analysis negative for SBP. =================== ACTIVE ISSUES =================== # Cellulitis: Patient with history of history of bilateral lower extremity cellulitis presenting with spreading to scrotum. Concern initially for ___ gangrene, urology and surgery consulted in the ED. However, CT scan showed no subcutaneous gas, and consulting teams from urology and ___ surgery did not feel exam consistent with such. Per OSH records, recent wound cultures were positive for MRSA, acinetobacter, and pseudomonas. He was initially on Zosyn, Vanc, Clindamycin (Day 1 = ___. Clindamycin was discontinued on ___ given low suspicion for ___. Transitioned to PO antibiotics (Bactrim and levofloxacin) on ___ based on previous culture data culture data for planned 14 day course (Last day: ___. Pain managed with combination of PO and IV Dilaudid. # Cirrhosis: MELD 9, Childs A. Secondary to HCV and alcohol. Decompensated by ascites. No encephalopathy. Unknown variceal status. Unknown ___ screening status. Has required large-volume paracenteses previously. Continued furosemide 80 mg daily, spironolactone 200 mg daily, lactulose 15 ml TID. S/p diagnostic and therapeutic paracentesis on ___ (6.5L), with ascitic fluid analysis negative for SBP. =================== CHRONIC ISSUES =================== # Normocytic anemia: Unknown baseline. ___ be secondary to liver disease. Iron studies indicate anemia of chronic disease # Chronic pain: Continued gabapentin 800 mg PO TID. # Depression: Continued citalopram 20 mg PO DAILY. # Housing instability: Likely will require SW consult. # Health maintenance: Continued MV # Misc: Held Emtricitabine-Tenofovir (Truvada) 1 TAB PO DAILY inpatient given history of nonadherence with medications and unknown HIV status at present. =================== TRANSITIONAL ISSUES =================== [] Patient to continue treatment for cellulitis/SSTI (Bactrim and levofloxacin) for (Day 1 = ___, last day ___ if worsening infection low threshold to switch back to IV agents (Vanc/Zosyn) [] Continue routine wound care for lower extremities. [] Acute pain managed with hydromorphone (Dilaudid) 1 mg IV Q4H:PRN and hydromorphone (Dilaudid) 4 mg PO/NG Q3H:PRN; as pain resolves should attempt to wean IV medications ASAP [] Patient with cirrhosis, MELD 9, Childs A on admission, no encephalopathy, SBP, or known varices, but s/p multiple large volume paracenteses; would benefit from inpatient/outpatient management and risk stratification of cirrhosis/HepC [] Had R IJ placed on ___ due to poor access, advanced into RA but been used without issue and patient without ectopy; attempted to pull back on ___ but per CXR unsuccessful. Patient difficult to get access, should have PIVs before removing IJ. [] Would benefit from social work consult due to housing instability [] Held Truvada inpatient, consider restarting as outpatient [] Will need ___ consult and cane on discharge # Contact: Mother, ___

draft_summary: A middle-aged man with IV drug use and cirrhosis was transferred with rapidly progressive Fournier gangrene causing septic shock, acute kidney failure, and respiratory distress requiring ICU admission and emergency surgical debridement. He was found to have SBP, hepatic encephalopathy, new HIV infection, and MRSA bacteremia, ultimately requiring prolonged IV antibiotics, dialysis, and planned liver transplant evaluation.
fixed_summary:
Mr. ___ is a ___-year-old man with a history of IV drug use, homelessness, hepatitis Câ€“related cirrhosis with ascites, and chronic bilateral lower-extremity cellulitis who presented as a transfer with worsening cellulitis and two days of scrotal erythema, induration, and tenderness. There was initial concern for a necrotizing infection, including Fournier gangrene; however, CT imaging showed no subcutaneous gas, and urology and surgery felt the examination was not consistent with necrotizing disease. He was initially treated with broad-spectrum IV antibiotics, including vancomycin and piperacillin-tazobactam, with clindamycin discontinued after low concern for necrotizing infection. Based on prior wound cultures showing MRSA, acinetobacter, and pseudomonas, he was transitioned to oral trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole and levofloxacin for a planned 14-day course.
The patient also presented with significant ascites after not taking home diuretics for over one week. He underwent diagnostic and therapeutic paracentesis with removal of 6.5 liters of fluid, with ascitic fluid analysis negative for spontaneous bacterial peritonitis. His cirrhosis was classified as MELD 9, Child-Pugh A, without encephalopathy. Chronic issues included normocytic anemia, chronic pain, depression, and housing instability. Social work involvement was recommended for discharge planning.

target: ___ with NICM (EF ___, AF/SSS/VT on warfarin and amiodarone s/p ICD to CRT, ESRD on HD, admitted for presyncope after dialysis and chronic dry gangrene of right hallux. # Presyncope Likely orthostasis since occurred with standing after 1L removed at HD. Pacemaker interrogation was negative for arrhythmia. He had no further chest pain or palpitations during his hospitalization and there was no evidence of cardiac ischemia, decompensated heart failure, PE, TIA, or seizure. # Right hallux dry gangrene He also underwent a partial right hallux amputation for chronic dry gangrene. The patient remained afebrile and without exam or radiographic signs of infection. He received one dose of vancomycin and piperacillin/tazobactam in the ED, and was discharged on prophylactic amoxicillin/clavulanate for a 7 day course per Podiatry with close Podiatry f/u, ___ for wound care, and home ___. Bone pathology and cultures were pending at discharge. # Atrial fibrillation with sick sinus syndrome # h/o ventricular tachycardia Patient was recently admitted for ICD shock for VT due to patient not taking amiodarone. Rate and rhythm now well controlled on home amiodarone and metoprolol. ICD interrogation several days prior to admission non-concerning. # Supratherapeutic anticoagulation INR 4.2 on admission. Given VitK ___ preoperatively. Warfarin restarted ___. INR 2.2 at discharge (goal ___, closer to 2 given triple therapy). # Non-ischemic dilated cardiomyopathy / chronic systolic heart failure (EF ___ No evidence for acute exacerbation. Pacemaker interrogation found no dysfunction or arrhythmias. Volume status was managed with HD, and home metoprolol was continued. Patient not on ___ due to reported allergy. # Peripheral vascular disease s/p angioplasty and stent Had recent balloon angioplasty and stent of anterior and posterior tibial arteries (___). No acute ischemic symptoms. Home meds were continued (ASA, clopidogrel, atorva 80). # ESRD on HD No indications for emergent dialysis. Nephrology was consulted and patient received scheduled HD. Home VitD was continued and nephrocaps started. Calcium acetate was stopped since calcium-phosphate product was low. # h/o cefazolin hepatotoxicity ___ Resolved -- repeat LFTs this admission normal. # Anxiety Patient endorsed severe daily anxiety and stress regarding his health problems and medication side effects, which appears to be contributing to his poor adherence and follow-up. He declined counseling or medication this admission, but would be interested in seeking psychiatric care as an outpatient. TRANSITIONAL ISSUES: ===================== -Please draw INR at ___ appointment on ___. Patient will also have INR drawn at dialysis on ___. Warfarin held, then decreased from 4mg to 3mg. INR 2.2 on day of discharge. -Wound care: keep dressing clean, dry, and intact until Podiatry f/u. -Abx: discharged on empiric amoxicillin/clavulanate for a 7-day course (d1= ___ pending bone biopsy cultures. -Calcium acetate stopped prior to hospitalization -Fistula aneurysm: f/u with transplant surgery scheduled ___ -Anxiety: significant symptoms that appear to interfere w/medication adherence and f/u. Declined counseling and medication. Please continue to offer.

input: The patient was admitted for evaluation and management of her facial pain. MRI/MRA/MRV brain was unremarkable, and the etiology of the pain was thought to be a combination of trigeminal neuralgia, temperomandibular joint disease, and migraine. The patient frequently demanded narcotics during her admission, reporting that "nothing works except dilaudid (or IV medications)." She was noted to complain of significantly more discomfort when medical personnel were in the room. There had apparently been some concern for drug-seeking behavior in the past. One-time doses of dilaudid 2mg were given several times when the patient complained of severe pain; she also received morphine and ativan due to pain and anxiety prior to her MRI. She was started on oxcarbazepine (Trileptal) for pain control of trigeminal neuralgia. She was discharged with a prescription for oxcarbazepine as well as dilaudid 2mg PRN (3 tabs total), with instructions to follow-up with pain clinic and dental surgery. The MRI/MRA/MRV was discussed with neuroradiology prior to discharge, but the final read is pending.

draft_summary:
The patient was admitted after collapsing at home with intractable facial pain and altered mental status.
Initial neuroimaging revealed a large posterior fossa mass with brainstem compression and obstructive hydrocephalus.
She was emergently started on high-dose steroids, mannitol, and continuous EEG monitoring.
During hospitalization, she developed recurrent seizures requiring intubation and ICU transfer.
Neurology determined the pain was secondary to invasive skull base malignancy with perineural spread.
Her course was complicated by aspiration pneumonia and acute respiratory failure.
She required escalating doses of intravenous opioids and ketamine infusions for pain control.
Cardiac monitoring revealed intermittent ventricular arrhythmias requiring antiarrhythmic therapy.
Repeat imaging demonstrated rapid progression of disease with multifocal cerebral infarcts.
Given poor prognosis, oncology and palliative care were consulted for goals-of-care discussions.
The patient declined further intervention and elected comfort-focused treatment.
She was discharged to inpatient hospice with family at bedside and minimal neurologic responsiveness.
fixed_summary: The patient was admitted for evaluation and management of facial pain. MRI, MRA, and MRV of the brain were unremarkable, and the pain was felt to be multifactorial, likely related to trigeminal neuralgia, temporomandibular joint disease, and migraine. During the admission, the patient frequently requested narcotic medications, stating that only intravenous opioids were effective, and was observed to report increased discomfort when medical staff were present; there had been prior concern for drug-seeking behavior. She received several one-time doses of intravenous hydromorphone for severe pain, as well as morphine and lorazepam for pain and anxiety prior to imaging. She was started on oxcarbazepine for treatment of trigeminal neuralgia. Prior to discharge, the imaging was reviewed with neuroradiology, although the final radiology report remained pending. She was discharged with a prescription for oxcarbazepine and a limited supply of hydromorphone 2 mg as needed, with instructions to follow up with the pain clinic and dental surgery.

Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> You were admitted to the hospital for elective hernia repair. You were taken to the operating room where you had a ventral hernia repaired. During your post-operative course, you were noted to have an elevated white blood cell count and you were started on an antibiotic for a presumed pneumonia. Your skin around the incision site also developed some redness, which can be a sign of infection. The antibiotic you are on will likely be able to cover for any possible skin infection - we are giving you a prescription for a 10-day course. Your vital signs have been stable and your white blood cell count has normalized. You are now preparing for discharge home with the following instructions: Medications: Please resume all regular home medications, unless specifically advised not to take a particular medication. Also, please take any new medications as prescribed. These will include: *Clindamycin 450 mg by mouth daily, for 8 days *Oxycodone 4 mg by mouth every four hours, as needed for pain *Colace 100 mg by mouth twice daily, while taking oxycodone Activity: -Please get plenty of rest, continue to ambulate several times per day, and drink adequate amounts of fluids. Avoid lifting weights greater than ___ lbs until you follow-up with your surgeon, who will instruct you further regarding activity restrictions. -Avoid driving or operating heavy machinery while taking pain medications. -Please follow-up with your surgeon and Primary Care Provider (PCP) as advised. Incision Care: -Please call your doctor or nurse practitioner if you have increased pain, swelling, redness, or drainage from the incision site. -Avoid swimming and baths until your follow-up appointment. -You may shower, and wash surgical incisions with a mild soap and warm water. Gently pat the area dry. -If you have staples, they will be removed at your follow-up appointment. -If you have steri-strips, they will fall off on their own. Please remove any remaining strips ___ days after surgery. Pain control: -You were given oxycodone, an opioid pain medication. This may cause constipation so you should increase your fiber intake and take colace twice daily to prevent this. -Only take your pain medication when you need to. -Do not drive after taking oxycodone.
target: The patient was admitted to the hospital for elective repair of a ventral hernia. He was taken to the operating room where he underwent a ventral hernia repair with mesh overlay and lysis of adhesion. A thoracic epidural catheter was placed prior to the procedure for pain management. The operative course was stable with minimal blood loss. The patient was extubated after the procedure and monitored in the recovery room. His post-operative course was stable. The patient resumed a regular diet on the operative day. His foley catheter was removed on POD #1 and the patient voided without difficulty. He was transitioned from intravenous analgesia to an oral pain regimen and his epidural catheter was removed. He was reported to have a white blood cell count of 20 on POD #1. The patient's hemodynamic status remained stable and there were no signs of wound infection. On POD #2, his white blood cell count remained elevated to 22 and he underwent a chest x-ray which revealed a right-sided consolidation. Clindamycin was started for presumed pneumonia. One POD #3 the patient's leukocytosis decreased to 14 and normalized on POD #4. He did have mild blanching erythema surrounding the midline abdominal incision with minimal tenderness and no notable drainage or fluctuance. This remained stable without expansion from POD#2 - POD#4. The patient's vital signs remained stable and he afebrile. He was tolerating a regular diet and resumed his home medication. The patient was discharged home on POD #4 in stable condition. He was given a prescription for a 10-day course of clindamycin. An appointment for follow-up was made with the acute care service and with his primary care provider.
draft_summary: The patient was admitted to the hospital for repair of an aortic pseudoaneurysm after a motor vehicle accident (MVA). The patient had a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and severe obstructive sleep apnea. Upon admission, the patient had scattered wheezes on lung CTAB, mild tenderness, and irregular blanching erythema at the surgical site. The patient was treated with oxycodone for pain control and advised to increase fiber intake and take Colace to prevent constipation. The patient was also advised to remove any remaining steri-strips 3 days after surgery. The patient was discharged with instructions to shower and wash surgical incisions with mild soap and warm water. The patient's peripheral pulses were 2+ bilaterally, and there were no signs of cyanosis or clubbing. The patient's respiratory and abdominal examinations were normal, with no rales or rhonchi. The patient's sleep apnea was not addressed during the hospital stay. The patient was not given any other treatments or medications during the hospital stay. The patient was discharged with a follow-up appointment scheduled for removal of staples.

The patient's peripheral pulses were 2+ bilaterally, and there were no signs of cyanosis or clubbing. The patient's respiratory and abdominal examinations were normal, with no rales or rhonchi.

At the time of transfer from OSH, her serum pancreatic enzymes were generally normal (lipase 25), and her serum EtOH level was 158. There were no narrowing, filling defects, or extrinsic compression. Of note, there was moderate erythema, friability and congestion of the esophageal mucosa with contact bleeding in the lower ___ of the esophagus, consistent with esophagitis. There were also 3 small ___ tears noted in the lower esophagus without evidence of bleeding. She was observed overnight following this procedure, and her pain was controlled. Her post-procedure labs were unremarkable, and she began to tolerate a clear liquid diet. The patient expressed her interest and readiness to return home. By the time of discharge, she was tolerating a clear liquid diet, ambulating, and without significant abdominal pain. She was afebrile and hemodynamically stable. She was discharged home with follow-up with Dr. ___ in clinic.

- Severe dehydration
- Acute kidney injury (AKI)
- Anemia
- Hypertension
- Pain in the flank area

- Pain management with acetaminophen and ibuprofen
- Medications to manage blood pressure (labetalol)
- Iron supplements (ferrous sulfate)
- Monitoring for signs of AKI and anemia

Note: The information provided is based on the patient record and may not be a comprehensive or up-to-date summary of the patient's entire medical history.

Had mild elevation of troponin from 0.03 to 0.04 x2 but negative CK-MB. EKG consistent with LBBB that was known per ___ records with no significant acute ST changes. Weight on ___ was 76 kg. Unclear patient baseline dry weight. Continued on home metop and losartan. Planned transfer to ___ cardiology service. It is unclear if pt's drop in LVEF is acute vs. subacute vs. chronic. Received metoprolol 5mg IV in ED on ___, as well as fractionated metoprolol tartrate 25mg at that time with improvement. Elevated CHADS2 score such that patient should be anticoagulated. Low clinical suspicion for underlying malignancy. Needs nutritional education also given new heart failure. Touch base with outpatient PCP. input: <SEX> M <SERVICE> SURGERY <ALLERGIES> ___ <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> S/p fall <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> None <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> A ___ male with h/o epilepsy presented to the ED on ___ after a fall from 15-feet with +HS/LOS. He states that he was up on a lift for work and "lost his momentum" and fell. He reports that he tried to grab a tree "on the way down" and denies any seizure activity. In the ED he was found to have a scalp laceration, L1-l4 transverse process fractures, and L 11th rib fracture. He was admitted to the trauma service, and today an over read of a CT abdomen/pelvis identified non-displaced fractures through the right inferior and superior pubic rami. He notes that he is having intermittent mid to low back pain that is exacerbated by movement. He reports he is having some mild discomfort in the right hip but denies any numbness or tingling in the right leg. He denies any chest pain, SOB, abdominal pain, nausea or vomiting. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> Epilepsy S/p R hip surgery ___ ___ c/b chronic R foot drop <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> Non-contributory <PHYSICAL EXAM> Physical Exam on Admission: Gen: NAD, AAOx3 CV: RRR Resp: CTAB Abdomen: Soft, Wound: Incisions clean, dry, intact scalp lacerations sutured with no active bleeding Ext: Warm Physical Exam on Discharge: <PERTINENT RESULTS> ___ 06: 21AM BLOOD WBC-7.8 RBC-3.73* Hgb-11.5* Hct-36.0* MCV-97 MCH-30.8 MCHC-31.9* RDW-12.9 RDWSD-46.2 Plt ___ ___ 09: 25AM BLOOD Neuts-74.2* Lymphs-12.9* Monos-11.5 Eos-0.0* Baso-0.4 Im ___ AbsNeut-5.82 AbsLymp-1.01* AbsMono-0.90* AbsEos-0.00* AbsBaso-0.03 ___ 06: 21AM BLOOD Glucose-127* UreaN-17 Creat-0.9 Na-141 K-4.4 Cl-99 HCO3-32 AnGap-10 ___ 02: 29AM BLOOD CK-MB-11* cTropnT-<0.01 ___ 06: 21AM BLOOD Calcium-8.7 Phos-2.8 Mg-2.5 ___ 02: 32AM BLOOD Type-ART pO2-132* pCO2-48* pH-7.41 calTCO2-31* Base XS-5 ___ 02: 32AM BLOOD Lactate-1.0 ___ 02: 32AM BLOOD freeCa-1.13 TRAUMA #3 (PORT CHEST ONLY) ___: IMPRESSION: No definite acute cardiopulmonary process. Prominent contour of the mediastinum most likely a function of technique, to be followed on subsequent CT. CT CHEST/ABD/PELVIS W/CONTRAST ___: IMPRESSION: 1. Acute fracture of the left posterior eleventh rib. Multiple left transverse process fractures from L1 through L4. 2. Nondisplaced fractures through the right inferior and superior pubic rami. 3. No evidence of visceral organ injury. 4. 6 mm hyperdensity in the gallbladder which may represent stone or polyp. CT C-SPINE W/O CONTRAST ___: IMPRESSION: No fracture or dislocation. PELVIS AP ___ VIEWS ___: IMPRESSION: No new fractures identified on the single AP view of the pelvis. CTA CHEST ___: IMPRESSION: 1. No evidence of pulmonary embolism. 2. Extensive consolidation in the bilateral lower lobes and right middle lobe with air bronchograms. Patchy consolidative and ground-glass opacities in the right upper lobe. Findings are compatible with multifocal pneumonia. 3. Right hilar lymphadenopathy, likely reactive. 4. Component of enhancing atelectasis in the left lower lobe. Small left pleural effusion. 5. Please see separately dictated report for CT of the abdomen/pelvis performed the same day. CT ABD & PELVIS WITH CONTRAST ___: IMPRESSION: 1. No source of infection in the abdomen or pelvis. 2. Known fractures are unchanged compared to CT of the torso from ___. 3. Please refer to separately dictated report for CTA of the chest performed the same day. <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete. 1. Clobazam 20 mg PO QHS 2. LamoTRIgine 375 mg PO QAM 3. LamoTRIgine 450 mg PO QPM 4. LORazepam 1 mg PO Q6H: PRN seizure <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. Acetaminophen 1000 mg PO Q8H 2. Milk of Magnesia 30 mL PO Q6H: PRN Constipation - Third Line 3. OxyCODONE (Immediate Release) ___ mg PO Q6H: PRN Pain - Moderate Reason for PRN duplicate override: Patient is NPO or unable to tolerate PO RX *oxycodone 5 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth every six (6) hours Disp #*14 Tablet Refills: *0 4. Polyethylene Glycol 17 g PO DAILY: PRN Constipation - First Line 5. Clobazam 20 mg PO QHS 6. LamoTRIgine 375 mg PO QAM 7. LamoTRIgine 450 mg PO QPM 8. LORazepam 1 mg PO Q6H: PRN seizure <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> Polytrauma head lacerations L1-4 transverse process fx, L 11th rib fx nondisplaced fx through the R inf and sup pubic rami <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Weight baring as tolerated on Right Lower Extremity <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> Dear Mr. ___, You suffered a fall and were admitted to ___ due to your injuries, you suffered a spine fracture, rib fracture and pelvic fracture along with lacerations in your scalp. You have recuperated well and you are now ready to head home. Please follow this instructions in order to continue your recovery * Your injury caused 1 rib fractures which can cause severe pain and subsequently cause you to take shallow breaths because of the pain. Please use your IS machine every 10 minutes in order to continue improving your breathing. * You should take your pain medication as directed to stay ahead of the pain otherwise you won't be able to take deep breaths. If the pain medication is too sedating take half the dose and notify your physician. * Pneumonia is a complication of rib fractures. In order to decrease your risk you must use your incentive spirometer 4 times every hour while awake. This will help expand the small airways in your lungs and assist in coughing up secretions that pool in the lungs. * You will be more comfortable if you use a cough pillow to hold against your chest and guard your rib cage while coughing and deep breathing. * Symptomatic relief with ice packs or heating pads for short periods may ease the pain. * Narcotic pain medication can cause constipation therefore you should take a stool softener twice daily and increase your fluid and fiber intake if possible. * Do NOT smoke * If your doctor allows, non-steroidal ___ drugs are very effective in controlling pain ( ie, Ibuprofen, Motrin, Advil, Aleve, Naprosyn) but they have their own set of side effects so make sure your doctor approves. * Return to the Emergency Room right away for any acute shortness of breath, increased pain or crackling sensation around your ribs (crepitus).
target: Mr. ___ is a ___ year old male, with a PMH significant for epilepsy who fell 15 ft w/ head strike and +LOC. His imaging upon admission showed left posterior scalp hematoma/abrasion, frontal scalp laceration, L1-4 transverse process fractures, left 11th rib fracture, and right inferior and superior pubic rami fracture. He was seen by the orthopedics service for his pubic rami fracture, who felt he did not need surgical intervention and weight-bearing as tolerated. He was transferred to the floor hemodynamically stable. His pain was controlled on oral analgesics. ___ were consulted and he was ambulating with crutches. On HD3, he was noted to be in respiratory distress with tachypnea, increased oxygen requirement, and tachycardia to the 160s. CXR, CTA, ABGs, and labs were ordered. He was transferred to the TSICU due to his acute hypoxia. He was weaned off the non-rebreather to hiflow oxygen and eventually nasal cannula. On HD4, he was transferred back to the floor. Patient recuperated well on the floor, he worked with physical therapy which recommended discharge to home. He was weaned off O2 and on ___ was found ready to head home. Patient was instructed regarding warning signs and discharge instructions, he was also instructed to continue his respiratory recovery at home using his IS. He will follow up with us in clinic.

The patient was admitted to the hospital for evaluation of a possible gallbladder issue, as indicated by a 6 mm hyperdensity in the gallbladder. The patient underwent imaging studies, including a CT scan of the chest and abdomen/pelvis, which revealed multifocal pneumonia, right hilar lymphadenopathy, and a small left pleural effusion. The patient's condition was further evaluated, and it was determined that there was no source of infection in the abdomen or pelvis. The patient's known fractures were unchanged compared to the previous CT scan of the torso. The patient's overall condition was stable, and the patient was discharged from the hospital.

input: ___ m with hx of HTN, DM II, BPH who presented with sudden onset fevers, chills, and rigors. Infectious work up concerning for possible retrocardiac pneumonia +/- influenza. Hospital course c/b rash on L leg and positive blood culture. ACTIVE ISSUES: # Fevers: Most likely secondary to a viral process. Patient had defervesced on arrival, but had one low-grade fever on HOD #3. Initially, he was treated empirically with Tamiflu for suspected influenza infection. After his DFA returned negative for flu on HOD #4, Tamiflu was discontinued. One blood culture from HOD #3 return positive for coagulase negative staph, but as all other blood cultures from this admission were negative, and patient was hemodynamically stable, this was most likely a contaminant. Additionally, he was noted to have a patchy erythematous rash on his left lower leg on HOD #3. Thus, he was started on vancomycin empirically for coverage of cellulitis. He continued vancomycin ___ at discharge; at that time, he was transitioned to cephalexin to complete a 7-day course of antibiotics for cellulitis. Although rash appeared atypical for cellulitis, it seemed to improve with antibiotics. ACE wraps were applied to legs, and legs were elevated, as patient reported similar afflication with venous stasis in the past. # Bacteremia: One blood culture from ___ grew coagulase-negative staph. Although this was likely just a contaminant (blood cultures from ___ and ___ without growth, it was covered by empiric antibiotics, as above. Patient will finish 7-day course of cephalexin as an outpatient. # LLE Rash / cellulitis: Unilateral, with patchy erythema that appeared atypical for cellulitis. LLE ultrasound was negative for DVT. In the setting of fevers, empiric vancomycin was started on ___ for coverage, and rash appeared to improve. Patient to complete 7-day course with cephalexin after discharge. ACE wraps were applied to legs, and legs were elevated, as patient reported similar afflication with venous stasis in the past. He was instructed to use compression stockings at home. His ultrasound did show an enlarged lymph node on the left side, c/w an underlying infectious/inflammatory process. CHRONIC ISSUES: #HTN: Stable. Continued on home regimen. #BPH: Patient denied any recent urinary retention or hesitancy. Prostate exam normal. He continued his home finesteride and doxazosin. TRANSITIONAL ISSUES: # Follow up finalized blood cultures from ___ and ___. # Consider repeat imaging if left inguinal LAD persists # Full code: confirmed

draft_summary: An elderly man with hypertension and diabetes was admitted in septic shock from influenza pneumonia complicated by MRSA bacteremia, necrotizing fasciitis of the left leg, and acute renal failure requiring ICU care. His course was further complicated by endocarditis, pulmonary embolism, and refractory hypotension, necessitating prolonged IV antibiotics and mechanical ventilation before discharge to rehab.
fixed_summary:
Mr. ___ is a man with a history of hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and benign prostatic hyperplasia who presented with acute onset fevers, chills, and rigors. Initial evaluation raised concern for a viral process, including possible influenza or retrocardiac pneumonia. He was empirically treated with oseltamivir, which was discontinued after influenza testing returned negative. During hospitalization, he had one episode of low-grade fever on hospital day 3 but otherwise remained hemodynamically stable.
One blood culture grew coagulase-negative staphylococcus, which was felt to represent contamination given subsequent negative cultures. He developed a unilateral, patchy erythematous rash on the left lower extremity that appeared atypical for cellulitis; however, in the setting of fevers, empiric vancomycin was initiated. Lower-extremity ultrasound was negative for deep vein thrombosis but showed an enlarged left inguinal lymph node consistent with an inflammatory process. The rash improved with antibiotics, and he was transitioned to oral cephalexin to complete a 7-day course. Chronic conditions, including hypertension and BPH, remained stable on home medications.

input: SUMMARY: ___ with PMH of dilated cardiomyopathy ___ class IV s/p VAD/ICD placement ___ and subsequent OHT ___, newly diagnosed hypothyroidism, presented after routine labs discovered neutropenia. ACTIVE ISSUES # Neutropenia Unclear etiology but a concerning finding. Fortunately, the patient was asymptomatic and had no fevers. Multiple possibilities could be involved: too much immunesuppression from her regimen, an occult infection (no symptoms however), Bactrim toxicity (has been on it for some time though). Had positive urine culture no treatment needed given no symptoms. Hematology and ID were consulted. CMV/EBV viral load negative, flow cytometry negative for concerning clonal populations to suggest hematological malignancy. After stopping Bactrim and decreasing the dose of MMF from 1000mg BID to ___ BID, her ANC slowly recovered and was at 638 at discharge. Therefore, most likely explanation was Bactrim toxicity. Bone marrow biopsy was deferred given recovery. Filgrastim was not given due to no signs of infection. # Dilated Cardiomyopathy s/p OHT Patient endorsed shortness of breath that had been chronic and stable since transplant. She had only mild rejection on recent biopsy and appeared euvolemic. Her immunesuppression was modified to MMF 750mg BID from 1000mg BID. Prednisone was continued at 2.5mg daily. Tacrolimus levels were monitored every day, and due to persistent levels <7, her tacrolimus was increased to 3mg BID from 2mg in AM and 3mg in ___. Bactrim was stopped and atovaquone started at 1500mg daily for PCP and toxoplasmosis prophylaxis. Nystatin was continued. # Hypothyroidism Patient continued to be very symptomatic from her hypothyroidism despite recent increase in levothyroxine. However, TSH appeared to be lowering with increasing free T4. Endocrine recommended continuing current regimen as she had yet to reach steady-state yet. She continued to take levothyroxine 75mcg daily while inpatient. CHRONIC ISSUES # Compression Fractures: She received Tylenol and oxycodone PRN, and continued vitamin D and calcium supplementation. 24hr urine collection for calcium, creatinine, and UPEP were collected based on outpatient endocrine recommendations. # T2DM: Continued home insulin regimen. # GERD: Continued pantoprazole 40mg BID. # Anxiety: Continued sertraline 75mg daily and clonazepam 2.5mg QHS. # Anemia: Chronic but stable. Continued ferrous sulfate 325mg daily. TRANSITIONAL ISSUES - Follow up labs on ___ for CBC w/ diff and tacrolimus trough level

She had only mild rejection on recent biopsy and appeared euvolemic. Her immunesuppression was modified to MMF 750mg BID from 1000mg BID. Prednisone was continued at 2.5mg daily. Tacrolimus levels were monitored every day, and due to persistent levels <7, her tacrolimus was increased to 3mg BID from 2mg in AM and 3mg in ___. Bactrim was stopped and atovaquone started at 1500mg daily for PCP and toxoplasmosis prophylaxis. Nystatin was continued. # Hypothyroidism Patient continued to be very symptomatic from her hypothyroidism despite recent increase in levothyroxine. However, TSH appeared to be lowering with increasing free T4. Endocrine recommended continuing current regimen as she had yet to reach steady-state yet. She continued to take levothyroxine 75mcg daily while inpatient. CHRONIC ISSUES # Compression Fractures: She received Tylenol and oxycodone PRN, and continued vitamin D and calcium supplementation. 24hr urine collection for calcium, creatinine, and UPEP were collected based on outpatient endocrine recommendations. # T2DM: Continued home insulin regimen. # GERD: Continued pantoprazole 40mg BID. # Anxiety: Continued sertraline 75mg daily and clonazepam 2.5mg QHS. # Anemia: Chronic but stable. Continued ferrous sulfate 325mg daily. TRANSITIONAL ISSUES - Follow up labs on ___ for CBC w/ diff and tacrolimus trough level
draft_summary: A critically ill postâ€“heart transplant patient was admitted in septic shock with profound neutropenia caused by acute leukemia and uncontrolled CMV infection, requiring emergency bone marrow biopsy, filgrastim, and broad-spectrum IV antibiotics in the ICU. Her course was complicated by acute transplant rejection, thyroid storm, renal failure requiring dialysis, and discontinuation of all immunosuppression before discharge to long-term rehab.
fixed_summary: The patient is a woman with a history of dilated cardiomyopathy status post ventricular assist device and implantable cardioverter-defibrillator placement, followed by orthotopic heart transplant, who was admitted after routine laboratory testing revealed neutropenia. She was asymptomatic without fevers or signs of infection on presentation. Evaluation considered medication-related toxicity, occult infection, and immunosuppression as potential causes. Infectious workup, including CMV and EBV viral loads, was negative, and flow cytometry showed no evidence of hematologic malignancy.Bactrim was discontinued due to concern for drug-induced neutropenia, and the mycophenolate mofetil dose was reduced. Her absolute neutrophil count gradually improved, reaching 638 at discharge, and bone marrow biopsy and filgrastim were not required. She had chronic, stable dyspnea post-transplant with only mild rejection on recent biopsy and appeared euvolemic. Tacrolimus dosing was adjusted to achieve therapeutic levels, and prednisone was continued. Hypothyroidism was managed with ongoing levothyroxine therapy per endocrinology recommendations. She was discharged with plans for close outpatient laboratory monitoring.

draft_summary:
Patient was admitted for suspected urinary tract infection (UTI) due to symptoms of dysuria and frequency. Patient was diagnosed with a urinary tract infection (UTI) and treated with antibiotics. Patient was also diagnosed with a vaginal yeast infection (Vaginal Candidiasis) and treated with antifungal medication. Patient was given fluids and pain management as needed. Patient was discharged home with a follow-up appointment scheduled.

Reason for Admission: Suspected urinary tract infection (UTI)
Diagnosis: Urinary Tract Infection (UTI), Vaginal Candidiasis
Treatment: Antibiotics, Antifungal medication, Fluids, Pain management
Outcome: Discharged home with follow-up appointment scheduled.
fixed_summary:
Ms. ___ is a ___ with a history of recurrent pancreatitis of unclear etiology complicated by pancreatic pseudocyst formation and rupture, who presented with abdominal pain and recurrent pancreatitis.
She was admitted for management of an acute flare of chronic pancreatitis that had been worsening over two days, with her last hospitalization for pancreatitis occurring previously.
No clear underlying cause for her recurrent symptoms was identified during this admission.
Given a recent MRCP four months prior and her acute presentation, repeat MRCP imaging was not performed.
She was managed with intravenous fluids, pain control, and initial bowel rest, followed by gradual advancement of diet as tolerated.
Her known chronic splenic vein thrombosis, likely related to repeated pancreatic inflammation, was monitored without evidence of bleeding complications.
Metformin was held during hospitalization due to poor oral intake and was replaced with insulin sliding scale coverage.
Urinalysis showed elevated white blood cells, and clinical evaluation was consistent with vulvovaginal candidiasis, which was treated with intravenous fluconazole while NPO.
Her diabetes regimen was resumed at discharge, including metformin, once oral intake improved.
She was discharged home in stable condition with pain and antiemetic medications and plans for outpatient follow-up with primary care and gastroenterology, including periodic MRCP surveillance.

Denies recent fever, chill, nausea or vomiting or pain anywhere. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> PMH: hepatitis C (___) c/b cirrhosis, salmonella gastroenteritis with acute renal failure, chronic kidney disease with renal stones s/p lithotripsy (___), DM (dx ___, off medications, diet-controlled), HTN ___, well-controlled, off medications), ITP s/p splenectomy (___), asthma PSH: splenectomy ___, lithotripsy ___ <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> FH: His family history is significant for an aunt and uncle with diabetes. <PHYSICAL EXAM> Discharge Physical VS: T 98.4 P 95 BP 137/96 RR 18 O2sat 99RA NAD, AAOx3 no murmurs ctab abd soft, apropriately tender over incision, incision closed with staples c/d/i, minimal surrounding ecchymosis, no discharge from incisions. two JP sites closed with nylon suture. no ___ edema <PERTINENT RESULTS> ___ LIVER U/S: 1. Iron stain shows mild iron deposition in hepatocytes. ___ Donor Liver, allograft, needle core biopsy: 1. Moderate mixed macro- and microvesicular steatosis and focally prominent neutrophils. 2. Mild portal mononuclear inflammation, non-specific. 3. No necrosis or features of acute cellular rejection are seen. 4. Trichrome and iron stains will be reported in an addendum. target: Pt was admitted to hospital for combined liver/kidney transplant. Pt was brought to OR, after informed consent was obtained, including explaining to the patient the risks associated with the donor liver including steatosis and increased risk of delayed graft function and failure. Intraop significant hemorrhage with no surgical bleeding but a massive amount of just diffuse ooze was encountered. Activated factor VII was given and shortly after the patient began making clot and drying up. It was not thought to be safe to close primarily packed the right upper quadrant and the iliac fossa with sponges and placed a temporary abdominal closure with anticipation of returning the patient to the operating room in 24 hours for washout and definitive closure. Introp received 16 of packed cells, 6 of CRYO, 15 of FFP, 5 of platelets and 1 dose of factor VII. See operative dictation for full details. Transferred to SICU intubated. Overnight, continued transfusions to goal hct >30, plt >100, INR <1.5, receiving 7 units pRBCs, 3 plts. Morning POD#1 returned to OR for Exploratory laparotomy, removal of intra-abdominal packing, liver biopsy, and hepaticojejunostomy. See operative dictation for full details. Transferred back to SICU intubated. ___ U/S showed all vessels are patent. Over next two days hct remained stable ~30 with 4 units pRBCs, 3 units plts. No other transfusions during hospital course. Extubated on ___. Following day had increasing oxygen requirement secondary to pulm edema as mobilized fluid. Was diuresed in SICU and transferred to floor on ___. Course on floor was uneventful, except for pain control. Methadone and dilaudid doses were adjusted apropriately. Was ultimately continued on home methadone dose 35 mg, and pain well controlled with intermittent dilaudid po 5 mg q6 prn. Lateral JP d/c'ed ___, medial removed ___. No evidence ascites leak through JP sites or incision. Immunosuppression was administered and titrated per pathway. Ppx was given per pathway. Pt tolerated regular diet, pain controlled with oral pain medications, voiding without difficulty, and ambulating. ___ felt safe for pt to be d/c'ed home. On day of discharge pt and staff felt it safe for pt to be discharged home with ___.
draft_summary:
The patient was admitted to the hospital for a postoperative complication following a liver transplant. The patient presented with a stable appearance of a perihepatic fluid collection adjacent to the right hepatic dome, a newly apparent left subhepatic collection, and a moderate left pleural effusion. The patient also had diffuse fatty infiltration of the liver with focal areas of sparing, and geographic and nodular hypoechoic areas. The patient was treated with insulin, tacrolimus, and potassium-lowering medications. The patient was also given pentamidine inhalation for prophylaxis against Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia. The patient was discharged after 14 days of hospitalization.

draft_summary:
Patient was admitted with ongoing pneumonia and diagnosed with Legionella pneumonia. She was treated with antibiotics and discharged home. However, she experienced worsening symptoms, including fever, chills, and overall feeling ill, prompting a return to the emergency department. She was seen by the cardiologist and scheduled for an echocardiogram in one week. The patient also experienced severe headaches, which have improved. The patient has moderate emphysema in the upper lobes. The patient was treated with Levaquin and Moxifloxacin. The patient's current level of consciousness is alert and interactive, and the patient is ambulatory and independent. The patient was prescribed Moxifloxacin for 7 more days. The patient was sent home with follow-up instructions. The patient was also sent home with discharge instructions. 

Reason for Admission: Ongoing pneumonia
Diagnosis: Legionella pneumonia
Treatments Given: 
- Levaquin 500mg PO
- Moxifloxacin 500mg PO
Key Findings: 
- Small to moderate pericardial effusion
- Moderate emphysema in the upper lobes
- Severe headaches
- Increasing temperature to 100.0
- Subjective fevers
- Overall
fixed_summary: However, she experienced worsening symptoms, including fever, chills, and overall feeling ill, prompting a return to the emergency department, as she initially felt well upon discharge. She was seen by the cardio in 1 week post d/c with echo 2 weeks post. The patient was prescribed Moxifloxacin for 7 more days. The patient was also sent home with discharge instructions, to continue Moxifloxacin for 7 more days as prescribed.

input: ___ yo F with Asthma, HTN, OSA and GERD who presents with SOB, cough and fever consistent with asthma exacerbation and CAP. . # Asthma exacerbation: Patient known asthma, multiple hospitalization for exacerbations, but no intubations. Most likely cause of exacerbation was felt to be community acquired pneumonia. Influenza was neg by DFA. She was treated with a 7 day course of levofloxacin ending on the day of discharge, and prednisone 60 mg orally for five days, followed by a decrease to 40 mg daily. She was instructed to complete a slow prednisone taper over the next several weeks. Additionally, she was treated with albuterol and atrovent nebulizers every four hours, as well as benzonatate and guafenesin for symptomatic relief. At discharge her cough and shortness of breath were significantly improved, but still decreased from baseline. She was able to ambulate with some mild dyspnea, but no decrease in oxygen saturation. . . # GERD: Pt provided a history of significant reflux symptoms, on PPI at home. Last EGD in ___ was normal. She also provided history of more recent dysphagia particularly with solid foods and pills. She underwent a video swallow evaluation, which showed no evidence of aspiration, but some slight penetration with thin liquids. Consequently, she was advised to take thin liquids slowly (one sip at a time), soft solids and pills whole with puree. Differential for her dysphagia includes esophageal stricture, web, or malignancy. She was proved with an appointment to follow-up in GI clinic three days after discharge for possible EGD to evaluate her dysphagia. She was also continued on omeprazole during this admission. . . # ARF: Creatinine was found to be elevated from baseline several days into admission. This resolved with gentle IV fluids, and was felt to be prerenal in etiology, likely secondary to decreased PO intake during period of dyspnea with asthma exacerbation. . # Hypertension: Continued on home regimen of valasartan and verapamil. . # Anemia: Stable normocytic anemia, which appeared to be at patient's baseline of ___. . # OSA: Uses CPAP at home, which was continued during this admission. . # Hypothyroidism: Continued on home dose levothyroxane.

draft_summary: An elderly woman with asthma and sleep apnea was admitted in respiratory failure from influenza pneumonia complicated by septic shock, requiring intubation, ICU admission, and emergent dialysis for acute kidney failure. Her hospital course was further complicated by esophageal cancer causing severe aspiration, uncontrolled hypertension, myocardial infarction, and stroke before discharge to a skilled nursing facility.
fixed_summary:
The patient is a woman with a history of asthma, hypertension, obstructive sleep apnea, gastroesophageal reflux disease, and hypothyroidism who presented with shortness of breath, cough, and fever consistent with an asthma exacerbation in the setting of community-acquired pneumonia. Influenza testing was negative. She was treated with a 7-day course of levofloxacin and high-dose prednisone with a planned gradual taper. She also received scheduled bronchodilator nebulizations and symptomatic therapy for cough. Her respiratory symptoms improved significantly during hospitalization, and she was able to ambulate with mild dyspnea without oxygen desaturation at discharge.
She reported chronic reflux and new dysphagia to solids and pills. A video swallow study showed no aspiration but mild penetration with thin liquids, and dietary modifications were recommended. She was continued on proton pump inhibitor therapy and scheduled for outpatient gastroenterology follow-up for further evaluation. During admission, she developed transient acute kidney injury that resolved with gentle intravenous fluids and was felt to be prerenal. Chronic conditions, including hypertension, obstructive sleep apnea, anemia, and hypothyroidism, were managed on home regimens. She was discharged in stable condition with close follow-up and completion of her medication courses.

target: The patient was admitted to the plastic surgery service on ___ and had a lap cholecystectomy. The patient tolerated the procedure well. Neuro: Post-operatively, the patient received Dilaudid IV with good effect and adequate pain control. When tolerating oral intake, the patient was transitioned to oral pain medications. CV: The patient was stable from a cardiovascular standpoint; vital signs were routinely monitored. Pulmonary: The patient was stable from a pulmonary standpoint; vital signs were routinely monitored. GI/GU: Post-operatively, the patient was given IV fluids until tolerating oral intake. Her diet was advanced when appropriate, which was tolerated well. Pt had a semi-elective lap cholecystectomy. She tolerated the procedure well. Her pain was well controlled initially on IV pain meds and then was transitioned to PO pain meds. ID: Post-operatively, the patient was not started on any antibiotics. Prophylaxis: The patient received subcutaneous heparin during this stay, and was encouraged to get up and ambulate as early as possible. At the time of discharge on POD#3, the patient was doing well, afebrile with stable vital signs, tolerating a regular diet, ambulating, voiding without assistance, and pain was well controlled.
draft_summary: The patient was admitted to plastic surgery for an emergency open heart surgery after presenting with gallbladder rupture and septic shock. She underwent a complicated laparoscopic cholecystectomy that was converted to open surgery due to massive bleeding and bowel perforation. Postoperatively, she required mechanical ventilation, vasopressors, and prolonged ICU stay. Her course was complicated by stroke, acute kidney failure requiring dialysis, and hospital-acquired pneumonia treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics. She developed severe postoperative delirium and required restraints. Pain control was difficult, necessitating high-dose IV opioids and ketamine infusion. She remained unable to tolerate oral intake and required TPN. She was discharged to a long-term acute care facility with ongoing infections and poor functional status.
fixed_summary:
The patient was admitted to the plastic surgery service and underwent a semi-elective laparoscopic cholecystectomy, which she tolerated well without complications. Postoperatively, her pain was initially managed with intravenous hydromorphone and later transitioned to oral pain medications once she tolerated oral intake. She remained hemodynamically stable throughout her hospitalization, with stable cardiovascular and pulmonary status. Intravenous fluids were administered postoperatively until oral intake was adequate, after which her diet was advanced without difficulty.
She did not require postoperative antibiotics. For prophylaxis, she received subcutaneous heparin and was encouraged to ambulate early. By postoperative day three, she was afebrile with stable vital signs, tolerating a regular diet, ambulating independently, voiding without assistance, and had well-controlled pain on oral medications. She was discharged home in stable condition.

target: Mr. ___ was admitted to the hospital on ___. He was made NPO and G and J tubes were placed to gravity and IV fluids were initiated. He was placed on IV dilaudid for pain control w/ good effect and empiric IV unasyn. - a chest CT scan was done showing small left pleural effusion, esophageal reflux and dismotility. As it turns out, the patient had been clamping his g-tube most of the time and unclamping it for only brief periods, but continued to take liquids liberally as well as j-tube feeds. His d/c instructions were to clamp G-tube x1hr after ___ meds then place back to gravity. The acute pain service was consulted to manage pt's ongoing incisional and epigastric pain. A Fentanyl patch was placed, and neurontin was used with IV dilaudid for breakthrough pain with good effect. Psych was consulted for depression and pt was maintained on clonazepam, celexa was discontinued and duloxetine was started. J-tube feeds were resumed, his ___ intake was was limited to 500cc and G-tube was kept to gravity and clamped only for ___ meds. He tolerated this regimen well with no further episodes of N/V or epigastric pain. He was passing flatus and stool. His diabetes was managed with a regular insulin sliding scale and his oral agents were held. Blood sugars were 71am-184pm. Just prior to discharge, his glipizude was resumed at 5mg ___ qam. His usual regimen was actos 30mg, glipizide 10mg bid, metformin 1000mg bid which can be added if his blood sugars warrant. He was determined to be stable for discharge on
draft_summary:
Mr. ___ was admitted in extremis after being found unresponsive with severe abdominal sepsis and respiratory failure.
Imaging revealed a large esophageal perforation with mediastinal contamination requiring emergent surgical intervention.
He was intubated, placed on vasopressors, and transferred to the ICU for hemodynamic instability.
His hospital course was complicated by acute renal failure requiring continuous dialysis.
Pain control required escalating doses of ketamine and continuous opioid infusions without adequate relief.
Psychiatry determined the patient lacked decision-making capacity and initiated an involuntary hold.
He was discharged to a long-term acute care facility with a guarded prognosis and plans for palliative follow-up.
fixed_summary:
Mr. ___ was admitted to the hospital on ___ and initially managed with NPO status, G- and J-tubes to gravity, intravenous fluids, IV hydromorphone for pain control, and empiric IV Unasyn.
Chest CT demonstrated a small left pleural effusion along with esophageal reflux and dysmotility.
It was noted that the patient had been clamping his G-tube for prolonged periods while continuing oral liquid intake and J-tube feeds, contributing to his symptoms.
The acute pain service was consulted, and his pain was managed with a fentanyl patch, gabapentin, and IV hydromorphone for breakthrough pain with good effect.
Psychiatry evaluated the patient for depression, continued clonazepam, discontinued citalopram, and initiated duloxetine.
J-tube feeds were resumed with limited oral intake, the G-tube was kept to gravity except for brief medication clamping, and he tolerated this regimen without further nausea, vomiting, or epigastric pain.
His diabetes was managed with insulin sliding scale during hospitalization, glipizide was resumed prior to discharge, and he was deemed stable for discharge.
