Pt awas also started on statin, beta-blocker. Pt was then transferred to ___ for plan for cath with Dr. ___. . Upon arrival to the floor, pt is comfortable, has no complaints. Denies any chest pain, shortness of breath. . Review of systems: as per HPI. endorses some mild rhinorrhea. endorses occ pain in knees and hip. denies fever, chills, night sweats, recent weight loss or gain, headache, sinus tenderness. denies cough, palpitations. denies nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, constipation or abdominal pain. denies dysuria. . <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> 1. CARDIAC RISK FACTORS: Hypertension 2. CARDIAC HISTORY: -CABG: none -PERCUTANEOUS CORONARY INTERVENTIONS: -PACING/ICD: none 3. OTHER PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: Osteoarthritis - left hip and left knee treated with motrin in past <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> father with CAD in late ___, mother with "cardiomyopathy" in ___, GM with DMII <PHYSICAL EXAM> Admission Exam: Vitals: T: 97.7 BP: 147/92 P: 57 R: 18 O2: 98% on RA General: alert, oriented, no acute distress HEENT: EOMI, MMM, oropharynx clear Neck: supple, no JVD Lungs: CTAB, no wheezes, rales, ronchi CV: RRR, no murmurs, rubs, gallops Abdomen: soft, non-tender, non-distended, bowel sounds present, no rebound tenderness or guarding, no organomegaly Ext: warm, well perfused, 2+ pulses, no clubbing, cyanosis or edema <PERTINENT RESULTS> Cardiac Cath: 1. Selective coronary angiography in this right dominant system demonstrated 1 vessel coronary artery disease. The LMCA had minimal diffuse atherosclerotic disease. The LAD and LCx had diffuse non-critical disease. The RCA had 90% proximal stenosis as well as 80% mid-segment stenosis. The R-PDA had diffuse disease. 2. Resting hemodynamics revealed normal left and right sided filling pressures with an RVEDP of 9 mmHg and a PCWP of 13 mmHg. The pulmonary arterial pressure was normal at ___ mmHg. Systemic arteral pressures were initially elevated at 173/89 mmHg, however post-intervention normalized to 117/64 mmHg. Cardiac output and index were within normal limits. FINAL DIAGNOSIS: 1. 1 vessel coronary artery disease. 2. Normal left and right sided filling pressures. 3. Normal pulmonary and systemic arterial blood pressures. Echo: The left atrium is normal in size. There is mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy with normal cavity size and regional/global systolic function (LVEF>55%). Right ventricular chamber size and free wall motion are normal. The ascending aorta is mildly dilated. The aortic valve leaflets (3) are mildly thickened but aortic stenosis is not present. Mild (1+) aortic regurgitation is seen. The mitral valve leaflets are mildly thickened. There is no mitral valve prolapse. Mild (1+) mitral regurgitation is seen. There is borderline pulmonary artery systolic hypertension. There is no pericardial effusion. IMPRESSION: Mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy with preserved regional and global systolic function. Mild mitral and aortic regurgitation. Mild aortic dilation. Borderline pulmonary hypertension. <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> Ibuprofen (stopped 2 weeks ago) Felodipine 7.5 mg daily <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. metoprolol succinate 25 mg Tablet Sustained Release 24 hr Sig: One (1) Tablet Sustained Release 24 hr PO once a day. Disp: *30 Tablet Sustained Release 24 hr(s)* Refills: *2* 2. clopidogrel 75 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily). Disp: *30 Tablet(s)* Refills: *11* 3. lisinopril 5 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO once a day. Disp: *30 Tablet(s)* Refills: *2* 4. Tylenol Extra Strength 500 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO three times a day as needed for pain. 5. simvastatin 20 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO once a day. Disp: *30 Tablet(s)* Refills: *2* 6. aspirin 325 mg Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.) Sig: One (1) Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.) PO once a day. <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> Coronary artery disease status post drug eluting stent to the right coronary artery. Vaso-vagal episodes <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> You were admitted to the hospital for a positive stress test. Your heart had a blockage in one of the arteries of your heart. A stent was placed to improve blood flow. Other vessels of your heart have some smaller plaques. We started you on new medications to manage your coronary artery disease. Please make sure to take these medications every day to protect your heart. During your cardiac catheterization procedure, you had some "vagal episodes" which caused a low blood pressure and improved after the procedure and after all the tubes were removed from your body. The vagal episodes of nausea and low blood pressure were likely due to your body's reaction to the procedure. Please avoid any strenuous exersize over the next 1 week. We do not recommend you go back to work for one week and should increase your activity slowly. We recommend you change your diet to a low cholesterol and heart healthy diet. We also recommend you eat foods low in salt. It is important to exercise regularly. The following changes were made to your medications: STOP: Felodipine and Ibuprofen START: Lisinopril to lower your blood pressure START: Metoprolol ot lower your heart rate and prevent a heart attack START: Clopidogrel or Plavix and a full dose (325mg) aspirin to prevent the stent from clotting off. You will need to take these medicines every day without fail for the next ___ year and possibly longer. Stopping or missing these medicines may cause a heart attack. Do not stop these medicines unless Dr. ___ you it is OK. START: Simvastatin to lower your cholesterol and prevent blockages in your heart arteries. START: Tylenol at 1000mg Three times a day as needed to treat your arthritis.

target: ___ F PMhx prior CVA, PVD, HTN, admitted ___ with abdominal pain, nausea and drug rash ___ and found to have MRCP concerning for ampullary stenosis or sphincter dysfunction, course complicated by diarrhea, new atrial fibrillation and new diastolic CHF Drug Rash - Dermatology input appreciated. Rash consistent with drug rash, related to either CTX or Ertapenem given at ___. Started topical steroid and supportive care with resolution. Derm follow up arranged at ___ on ___. Abdominal pain / Nausea / Diarrhea / Gastric Ulcers / Possible Ampullary stenosis- patient presented with several weeks worsening abdominal pain, nausea and diarrhea. Ultrasound and MRCP were concerning for intrahepatic and pancreatic ductal dilation, suggestive of ampullary stenosis/structure vs sphincter of oddi dysfunction. Patient was recommended for outpatient endoscopic ultrasound. However symptoms persisted. Infectious workup of diarrhea was negative. EGD showed multiple gastric ulcers, prompting high-dose PPI initiation. Bx was negative for H. pylori, and gastrin levels were WNL. ___ 9 and ttg-IgA were wnl. - STOOL ELASTASE PENDING. only helpful if negative (excludes pancreatic insufficiency) She was started on loperamide with improvement in her diarrhea. She underwent a ___ MRCP which confirmed persistent if not mildly worse CBD dilatation, despite NORMAL LFTs. The case was reviewed by the advanced endoscopy team and radiology and determined to be likely benign ampullary stenosis, NO mass identified. Outpatient EUS was again recommended. She did undergo ___ EGD as well as colonoscopy which were largely unremarkable. Biopsies of the colon did show colitis, but non-specific and possibly related to medication or prep, NO microscopic colitis or IBD found. Close GI follow up was recommended. She should take her PPI for 8 weeks. Atrial fibrillation - diagnosed during this admission in the setting of an irregular heart rate to the 110s; patient was started on metoprolol with improved rate control. Given CHADS2 of 4, she was recommended to start anticoagulation. While her outpatietn cardiologist recommended a NOAC, patient declined and preferred to initiate coumadin. PCP's office to coordinate as outpatient. She was started on Lovenox and warfarin for discharge. INR 1.8 on discharge after warfarin 5mg. She was discharged on warfarin 2 mg daily and close INR monitoring. Her atenolol was resumed on DC. Acute Diastolic CHF Â– Admission was complicated by worsening lower extremity edema. TTE showed significant R sided failure with 4+ TR. Patient was seen by cardiology and pulmonary service who could not identify an acute trigger, but felt that symptoms were likely secondary to left-sided heart failure. She was recommended for diuresis, with plan for repeat TTE when euvolemic, as well as outpatient pulm follow-up (scheduled at ___ and follow-up with her outpatient Cardiologist ___ ___. Patient started on lisinopril and standing lasix with improvement in her edema though not complete resolution. She had L>R asymmetric edema which could not be entirely explained by CHF. ___ was negative. This was likely due to venous stasis from her previous surgery. - she was discharged on atenolol, lisinopril 5mg, and torsemide 10mg daily. Her torsemide dose may need uptitration. Her DC weight was 50.12kg PVD/CVA: Her ___ was resumed after discussion with her PCP. Given that she is now on warfarin, consideration can be made to stop her ___. Primary HTN: Resumed atenolol on DC and changed amlodipine to lisinopril.
draft_summary:
The patient was admitted after being found confused at home with severe abdominal pain and hypotension requiring ICU admission.
Early imaging revealed a large pancreatic head mass with invasion into surrounding vascular structures and biliary obstruction.
Her hospital course rapidly deteriorated with fulminant hepatic failure and refractory metabolic acidosis.
She developed sustained ventricular tachycardia requiring emergent cardioversion and amiodarone infusion.
Endoscopic evaluation demonstrated diffuse gastrointestinal ischemia with active bleeding requiring multiple transfusions.
Neurologically, she suffered an acute cerebellar stroke with loss of consciousness and prolonged intubation.
Renal function declined precipitously, necessitating continuous renal replacement therapy.
Despite broad-spectrum antimicrobials, she progressed to septic shock with multiorgan failure.
After multidisciplinary discussions, care was transitioned to comfort-focused measures.
She was discharged to inpatient hospice with family present and a grave prognosis.
fixed_summary: The patient is a ___-year-old woman with a history of prior cerebrovascular accident, peripheral vascular disease, and hypertension who was admitted with several weeks of worsening abdominal pain, nausea, diarrhea, and a new drug-related rash. Imaging with ultrasound and MRCP demonstrated intrahepatic and pancreatic ductal dilation concerning for ampullary stenosis or sphincter of Oddi dysfunction, though liver function tests remained normal. Her hospital course was complicated by persistent gastrointestinal symptoms, prompting further evaluation including EGD, which revealed multiple gastric ulcers, leading to initiation of high-dose proton pump inhibitor therapy; biopsies were negative for H. pylori, gastrin levels were normal, and additional serologic testing was unremarkable. Diarrhea improved with loperamide, infectious studies were negative, and colonoscopy showed nonspecific colitis without evidence of inflammatory bowel disease or microscopic colitis. Repeat MRCP confirmed persistent common bile duct dilation without evidence of mass, and after multidisciplinary review with advanced endoscopy and radiology, the findings were felt to be most consistent with benign ampullary stenosis, with outpatient endoscopic ultrasound recommended. Dermatology evaluated her rash, which was consistent with a drug reaction likely related to recent antibiotic exposure, and it resolved with topical steroids and supportive care, with outpatient follow-up arranged. During admission, she was found to have new atrial fibrillation with rates in the 110s and was started on metoprolol with improved rate control; given a CHADSâ‚‚ score of 4, anticoagulation was recommended, and she elected to start warfarin with enoxaparin bridging and close INR monitoring after discharge. Her course was further complicated by acute diastolic heart failure with lower extremity edema, and echocardiography showed significant right-sided dysfunction with severe tricuspid regurgitation, felt to be secondary to left-sided heart failure. She responded to diuresis with improvement in edema and was discharged on atenolol, lisinopril, and torsemide, with plans for repeat echocardiography when euvolemic and close follow-up with cardiology, pulmonology, gastroenterology, and her primary care physician.

target: ___ is a ___ female high school senior with PMH of Prader-Willi, ADHD, chronic migraine without auras, known 2mm R PCA aneurysm, hx Kawasaki's disease who presents with headache, fevers, myalgias, c/f meningitis vs severe migraine in setting of a concominant viral illness, with improving symptoms. # chills # myalgias # headache Initial concern for meningitis given chills, HA, and report of photophobia so started on empiric therapy with vanc/ceftriaxone/acyclovir in the ED after several failed attempts at LP. Her exam on the floor was notable for improving headache, without any evidence of nuchal rigidity, which was not felt to be suggestive of meningitis. Notably, she does have a 2 mm PCA aneurysm; however, given new onset, "worst headache" symptoms and family history of hemorrhagic stroke from aneurysm x2, obtained NCHCT on ___ that was within normal limits. Low suspicion of expanding PCA aneurysm, which would need to be worked up with CTA, because expansion would not be consistent with her systemic symptoms. ___ guided LP performed on ___ with CSF that was bland (1 WBC, 8 RBCs) and antibiotics/antivirals were stopped at that time. Given clear CSF without xanthochromia and only 8 RBCs, as well as negative head CT, subarachnoid hemorrhage felt to be ruled out. Other infectious workup, including CXR, UA, and flu swabs were negative. Some infectious studies, including respiratory viral panel, Lyme, serum anaplasma PCR, CSF HSV PCR, and CSF Arborvirus IgM and IgG, are pending at time of discharge. We think overall picture most consistent with a particularly severe migraine in setting of a concominant viral illness. For patient headache, pain at site of LP attempts, and myalgias, recommended ibuprofen PRN, tylenol, and lidocaine patch. # Migraines Continued home topiramate. # Depression Continued home citalopram. # Allergic rhinitis Continued home loratadine. #Nausea/vomiting Continued home Prochlorperazine 10 mg PO TID:PRN. #Insomnia Continued home HydrOXYzine 25 mg PO/NG QHS insomnia #Menses regulation Held home OCP because non-formulary. =================== TRANSITIONAL ISSUES =================== #stopped meds: none #changed meds: none #new meds: none [ ] please follow-up symptoms of chills, myalgias, and headache and ensure resolution [ ] please follow-up studies pending at time of discharge: respiratory viral panel, serum anaplasma PCR, CSF HSV PCR, and CSF Arborvirus IgM and IgG. # CODE: full # CONTACT: ___, Mother, ___
draft_summary:
The patient was admitted after collapsing at school with sudden loss of consciousness and severe neurologic deficits.
Initial imaging revealed a ruptured posterior circulation aneurysm with diffuse subarachnoid hemorrhage and hydrocephalus.
She rapidly deteriorated, requiring emergent intubation, external ventricular drain placement, and ICU admission.
Her course was complicated by refractory seizures, septic shock, and acute respiratory failure.
Broad infectious workup revealed bacterial meningitis with positive blood and CSF cultures, prompting prolonged IV antibiotics.
Cardiology was consulted after she developed cardiogenic shock related to late complications of Kawasaki disease.
Despite aggressive intervention, she suffered multiple ischemic strokes with persistent neurologic deficits.
Given poor prognosis, neurosurgery deemed her not a surgical candidate.
Goals-of-care discussions were held with family, and comfort measures were initiated.
She was discharged to inpatient hospice with minimal responsiveness and a grave outlook.
fixed_summary: The patient is a ___-year-old female high school senior with a history of Praderâ€“Willi syndrome, ADHD, chronic migraines without aura, a known 2 mm right posterior cerebral artery aneurysm, and prior Kawasaki disease who presented with headache, fevers, chills, myalgias, and photophobia, raising concern for meningitis versus severe migraine in the setting of a concurrent viral illness. In the emergency department, she was started on empiric vancomycin, ceftriaxone, and acyclovir after multiple unsuccessful lumbar puncture attempts. On inpatient evaluation, her headache was improving, and she had no neck stiffness or other exam findings suggestive of meningitis. Given her report of a new severe headache and a family history of hemorrhagic stroke related to aneurysm, a non-contrast head CT was obtained and was normal, making aneurysmal rupture unlikely. A subsequent image-guided lumbar puncture revealed bland cerebrospinal fluid with minimal cells and no xanthochromia, leading to discontinuation of antibiotics and antivirals and ruling out subarachnoid hemorrhage. Additional infectious studies, including chest X-ray, urinalysis, and influenza testing, were negative, with several viral and tick-borne studies pending at discharge. Overall, her presentation was felt to be most consistent with a severe migraine triggered by a viral illness. Her symptoms were managed conservatively with acetaminophen, ibuprofen, and topical lidocaine for pain at prior lumbar puncture sites, and she continued her home medications for migraine prophylaxis, mood, allergic rhinitis, nausea, and insomnia. She was discharged in stable condition with instructions to follow up pending test results and monitor for resolution of her symptoms.

Make sure to take your steroid medication with meals, or a glass of milk. -Clearance to drive and return to work will be addressed at your post-operative office visit. -Make sure to continue to use your incentive spirometer while at home.

target: #Cervical spondylosis - The patient's symptoms were most attributable to neck muscle strain and spasm on top of her chronic degenerative disc disease. Plain films of the C-spine showed normal bone density, decreased physiologic cervical lordosis, a relatively sharp angle at the level of C5 and C6, a fusion between C6 and C7, mild dorsal spondylosis of the entire C-spine, and minimal arthrosis of the intravertebral joints but no evidence of compression fracture or pathologic vertebral displacement. C-spine MRI preliminarily showed congenital block vertebral body at C6 through T1 with partial obliteration of the dorsal intervertebral disc spaces, multifactorial canal narrowing with no spinal cord deformity or intrinsic signal abnormality at C5-C6, bilateral neural foraminal narrowing with possible bilateral exiting C6 nerve root impingement, and at C4-C5 left endplate/uncovertebral complex encroachment on the left neural foramen with likely impingement upon the exiting left C5 nerve root. MRA of the neck was normal. Pain and spasm was well-controlled on the patient's outpatient medication regimen. The patient was advised not to drive or drink alcohol while taking her usual medications. She was advised to follow up with neurology at her earliest convenience. . #Hyponatremia - Corrected with saline administration. . #Uncomplicated cystitis - Preliminary urine culture grew >100K GNR. Given cipro x 3 days since prior GNR isolates have been sensitive to FQ's. . #Chronic pain - Continued the outpatient regimen. . #Non-insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus - Blood sugars were well-controlled on an insulin sliding scale. . #Epilepsy - No acute issues. Continued tegretol. . #Reflux esophagitis - Continued carafate and PPI. . #Hypertension - Blood pressure well-controlled on imdur. . #Hyperlipidemia - Continued statin.
draft_summary:
The patient was admitted after sudden onset quadriplegia following a high-speed motor vehicle collision.
Emergency imaging revealed unstable cervical spine fractures with spinal cord transection and extensive epidural hematoma.
She rapidly developed respiratory failure and required intubation and mechanical ventilation in the ICU.
Neurosurgery performed emergent decompressive laminectomy and cervical fusion spanning multiple vertebral levels.
Her hospital course was complicated by refractory seizures, malignant hypertension, and acute renal failure.
Further workup revealed vertebral osteomyelitis with epidural abscess and bloodstream infection.
She required prolonged intravenous antibiotics and multiple revision spine surgeries.
Despite aggressive intervention, she remained neurologically impaired with minimal recovery.
Goals-of-care discussions were initiated due to poor functional prognosis.
She was discharged to a long-term acute care facility with ventilator dependence and palliative follow-up.
fixed_summary: The patientâ€™s presenting symptoms were felt to be most consistent with neck muscle strain and spasm superimposed on chronic cervical spondylosis and degenerative disc disease. Plain radiographs of the cervical spine demonstrated normal bone density with decreased physiologic lordosis, a sharp angulation at C5â€“C6, fusion at C6â€“C7, mild dorsal spondylosis throughout the cervical spine, and minimal intervertebral arthrosis, without evidence of compression fracture or pathologic displacement. Preliminary cervical spine MRI revealed a congenital block vertebral body from C6 through T1 with partial obliteration of dorsal disc spaces, multifactorial canal narrowing without spinal cord deformity or intrinsic signal abnormality at C5â€“C6, bilateral neural foraminal narrowing with possible C6 nerve root impingement, and left-sided foraminal encroachment at C4â€“C5 likely affecting the exiting C5 nerve root. MRA of the neck was normal. Her neck pain and muscle spasm were well controlled on her outpatient medication regimen, and she was advised not to drive or consume alcohol while taking these medications. She was instructed to follow up with neurology as an outpatient. During her hospitalization, hyponatremia resolved with saline administration, and an uncomplicated cystitis was treated with a three-day course of ciprofloxacin based on preliminary urine culture results. Her chronic pain regimen was continued, blood glucose levels remained well controlled on an insulin sliding scale, and there were no acute issues related to her epilepsy while continuing carbamazepine. Her reflux esophagitis, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia were managed with continuation of her home medications.

target: ___ y/o man with PMHx CAD c/b STEMI ___ - posterolateral ventricular branch of the right coronary artery now s/p BMS), Ulcerative Colitis, HTN and HLD presenting with CP in the setting of a known totally occluded RCA at recent ___ cath. # Chest pain/CAD: Given significant cardiac history and concern for unstable angina, patient was initially on a heparin and nitro drip. Home pravastatin was changed transiently to high dose atorvastatin while there was concern for possible ACS/NSTEMI. Metoprolol, aspirin, and IMDUR were continued. Admission EKG was unchanged from prior, serial cardiac enzymes were drawn and remained flat so heparin and nitro were discontinued. On hospital day 1, chest pain recurred while patient was lying in bed. EKG at the time showed TWIs in precordial leads. Patient was restarted on heparin gtt. He was taken for a nuclear stress on ___ that showed no reversible areas of ischemia. He was discharged with nitro SL for symptomatic use and he was also put on amlodipine in case symptoms might be related to coronary vasospasm. Patient's metoprolol was stopped in the setting of SBPs in ___ and starting amlodipine. # ?CHF: most recent ECHO prior to admission showed preserved EF, repeat ECHO done in house showed EF 50-55%. Patient was noted to have slight L>R swelling in ___, LENIs were done which showed no DVT. Patient remained on home lasix and lisinopril and continued to remain euvolemic. # HTN: continued lisinopril, metoprolol, imdur. # HLD: substituted atorvastatin for pravastatin as above # BPH: continued tamsulosin TRANSITIONAL ISSUES # Outpatient team can decide whether pt would benefit from beta blocker, as it was stopped on this admission, in the setting of low systolic blood pressures and starting amlodipine
draft_summary:
The patient presented after sudden cardiac arrest at home and required prolonged resuscitation prior to arrival.
Emergent coronary angiography revealed acute left main occlusion with extensive myocardial necrosis.
He underwent urgent coronary artery bypass grafting complicated by intraoperative cardiogenic shock.
Postoperatively, he developed severe systolic heart failure with an ejection fraction below 10 percent.
His hospital course was further complicated by recurrent ventricular arrhythmias requiring defibrillator placement.
Renal failure ensued, necessitating continuous dialysis and vasopressor support.
He was diagnosed with fulminant ulcerative colitis flare causing massive gastrointestinal bleeding.
Despite aggressive medical and surgical management, his condition continued to decline.
Goals-of-care discussions were held with family given poor prognosis.
He was discharged to inpatient hospice with comfort-focused care.
fixed_summary: The patient is a ___-year-old man with a history of coronary artery disease complicated by prior STEMI involving the posterolateral ventricular branch of the right coronary artery status post bare-metal stent placement, as well as ulcerative colitis, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia, who presented with chest pain in the setting of a known chronically occluded right coronary artery on recent cardiac catheterization. Given concern for unstable angina, he was initially treated with heparin and nitroglycerin infusions, and his home pravastatin was temporarily switched to high-dose atorvastatin while acute coronary syndrome was being evaluated. Admission electrocardiogram was unchanged from prior studies, and serial cardiac enzymes remained negative, allowing discontinuation of heparin and nitroglycerin. On hospital day one, he experienced recurrent chest pain at rest with new T-wave inversions in the precordial leads, prompting reinitiation of heparin therapy. A subsequent nuclear stress test demonstrated no reversible ischemia. His chest pain was ultimately managed medically, and he was discharged with sublingual nitroglycerin for symptomatic relief and started on amlodipine for possible coronary vasospasm, while metoprolol was discontinued due to low systolic blood pressures and the addition of amlodipine. Evaluation for heart failure showed preserved systolic function on repeat echocardiography with an ejection fraction of 50â€“55 percent, and lower extremity ultrasound showed no evidence of deep vein thrombosis. He remained euvolemic on his home regimen of furosemide and lisinopril, continued tamsulosin for benign prostatic hyperplasia, and was discharged with plans for outpatient reassessment of beta-blocker therapy.

target: The patient was admitted to the General Surgical Service on ___ for evaluation of the aforementioned problem. Admission liver/gallbladder ultra-sound revealed multiple small gallstones at the gallbladder neck and mildly thickened gallbladder wall with a normal CBD consistent with acute cholecystitis versus chronic cholelithiasis. He was made NPO, started on IV fluids, and given Morphine IV PRN for pain. He was started on empiric IV Ciprofloxacin and Flagyl. The patient underwent ERCP, which revealed three irregular stones in the distal CBD. A sphincterotomy and stone extraction were successfully performed. He was subsequently placed on aggressive IV fluid hydration and allowed clear liquids. . On ___, the patient then underwent laparoscopic exploration, extensive lysis of adhesions and laparoscopic cholecystectomy, which went well without complication (see Operative Note). The patient was alos found to have chronic cholecystitis intra-operatively. After a brief, uneventful stay in the PACU, he was returned to the floor tolerating clears, on IV fluids, and received Dilaudid IV PRN for pain control. He remained hemodynamically stable. . Post-operative pain was adequately controlled with the Dilaudid IV PRN, which was converted to oral oxycodone when tolerating clear liquids. Due to inadequate pain control, the oxycodone was changed to Dilauid PO PRN and IV Toradol added with improved pain control. The patient tolerated clears on POD#0. Diet was advanced as to a regular diet by later that day with good tolerability. The patient voided normally. Laparoscopic incisions remained clean and intact. . During this hospitalization, the patient ambulated early and frequently, was adherent with respiratory toilet and incentive spirrometry, and actively participated in the plan of care. Labwork was routinely followed; electrolytes were repleted when indicated. . At the time of discharge, the patient was doing well, afebrile with stable vital signs. The patient was tolerating a regular diet, ambulating, voiding without assistance, and pain was well controlled. He was discharged home without services. The patient received discharge teaching and follow-up instructions with understanding verbalized and agreement with the discharge plan.

input: Mr. ___ is a ___ who underwent an exploratory laparotomy, lysis of adhesions, recurrent incarcerated ventral incisional hernia with mesh and component separation; please see the operative note for details. Pt was extubated, taken to the PACU until stable, then transferred to the ward for observation. Neuro: The patient was alert and oriented throughout hospitalization; pain was initially managed with a thoracic epidural and intravenous acetaminophen and ketorolac, but was split to a bupivacaine containing epidural and hydromorphone PCA on POD1. On POD2, the epidural catheter was inadvertently dislodged and ultimately removed by the Acute Pain Service. Once tolerating a diet, the pain regiment was transitioned to oral acetaminophen and oxycodone. CV: The patient was hypotensive on POD0-1 requiring fluid and albumin boluses and a decrease in the epidural rate with complete resolution. Pulmonary: The patient remained stable from a pulmonary standpoint; vital signs were routinely monitored. Good pulmonary toilet, early ambulation and incentive spirometry were encouraged throughout hospitalization. Given a temp of 101.1 on POD3, a chest x-ray was obtained and revealing for left sided atelectasis. He remained afebrile throughout the remainder of his hospitalization and his WBC normalized (6.3) by the day of discharge. GI/GU/FEN: The patient was initially kept NPO. On POD1, the diet was advanced to clears, but made NPO again on POD2 due to increased abdominal distention. However, on POD2, the patient began passing flatus and the diet was gradually progressed to regular which was well tolerated. On POD1, he was noted to have an acute kidney injury which resolved with fluid resuscitation. The Foley catheter was removed on POD2. The JP drain output was serosanguinous and left in place at the time of discharge. HEME: The patient's blood counts were closely watched for signs of bleeding, of which there were none. Prophylaxis: The patient received subcutaneous heparin and ___ dyne boots were used during this stay and was encouraged to get up and ambulate as early as possible. At the time of discharge, the patient was doing well, afebrile and hemodynamically stable. The patient was tolerating a diet, ambulating, voiding without assistance, and pain was well controlled. The patient received discharge teaching and follow-up instructions with understanding verbalized and agreement with the discharge plan.
target: Mr. ___ is a ___ who underwent an exploratory laparotomy, lysis of adhesions, recurrent incarcerated ventral incisional hernia with mesh and component separation; please see the operative note for details. Pt was extubated, taken to the PACU until stable, then transferred to the ward for observation. On POD2, the epidural catheter was inadvertently dislodged and ultimately removed by the Acute Pain Service. Once tolerating a diet, the pain regiment was transitioned to oral acetaminophen and oxycodone. Pulmonary: The patient remained stable from a pulmonary standpoint; vital signs were routinely monitored. Good pulmonary toilet, early ambulation and incentive spirometry were encouraged throughout hospitalization. Given a temp of 101.1 on POD3, a chest x-ray was obtained and revealing for left sided atelectasis. He remained afebrile throughout the remainder of his hospitalization and his WBC normalized (6.3) by the day of discharge. GI/GU/FEN: The patient was initially kept NPO. On POD1, the diet was advanced to clears, but made NPO again on POD2 due to increased abdominal distention. On POD1, he was noted to have an acute kidney injury which resolved with fluid resuscitation. The Foley catheter was removed on POD2. The JP drain output was serosanguinous and left in place at the time of discharge. HEME: The patient's blood counts were closely watched for signs of bleeding, of which there were none. draft_summary: Mr. ___ is a middle-aged patient who underwent a complex exploratory laparotomy with mesh placement and component separation complicated by intraoperative bowel ischemia requiring partial small bowel resection. Postoperatively, he required prolonged mechanical ventilation in the ICU due to respiratory failure and aspiration pneumonia. He developed new-onset atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response requiring amiodarone and cardiology consultation. Pain control was challenging and required ketamine infusion in addition to epidural and PCA therapy. The patient experienced postoperative delirium with visual hallucinations and required antipsychotic treatment. He had persistent hypotension requiring vasopressor support for three days. Imaging revealed an anastomotic leak treated with percutaneous drainage. Acute kidney injury progressed to temporary dialysis dependence. Blood cultures grew multidrug-resistant organisms requiring long-term IV antibiotics. He developed a postoperative myocardial infarction confirmed on troponin testing. Severe ileus necessitated prolonged TPN and NG tube decompression. Wound dehiscence required bedside vacuum-assisted closure. He underwent repeat exploratory surgery for abdominal compartment syndrome. The patient was ultimately discharged to a long-term acute care facility with guarded prognosis.
fixed_summary: Mr. ___ underwent a complex exploratory laparotomy with mesh placement and component separation, a surgery that quickly became more complicated when bowel ischemia was discovered, necessitating partial small bowel resection. After the operation, his recovery was difficult from the start, requiring prolonged mechanical ventilation in the ICU due to respiratory failure and aspiration pneumonia. During this critical period, he developed new-onset atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, prompting treatment with amiodarone and involvement of cardiology. Pain control proved challenging and required escalation to ketamine infusion in addition to epidural and PCA therapy. As his hospital course progressed, he became delirious with visual hallucinations, requiring antipsychotic management. He experienced persistent hypotension and remained on vasopressor support for three days. Imaging later revealed an anastomotic leak, which was treated with percutaneous drainage. His kidney function deteriorated into acute kidney injury, eventually requiring temporary dialysis. Blood cultures grew multidrug-resistant organisms, leading to initiation of long-term intravenous antibiotics. He also suffered a postoperative myocardial infarction confirmed by troponin elevation. Gastrointestinal recovery was slow, with severe ileus necessitating prolonged nasogastric decompression and total parenteral nutrition. After a prolonged and complicated hospital course, he was ultimately discharged to a long-term acute care facility with a guarded prognosis.

target: ___ y/o female with PMH of CAD, dementia, endometrial Ca s/p hysterectomy ___ presented with bilateral lower extremity edema and erythema for one week, improved on lasix. LIkely due to heart failure. Early stage dementia. # Leg edema: appears mildly hypervolemic on initial exam, echo showed EF 55% and indicated impaired relaxation. Given hx of CAD, diastolic heart failure most likely cause. Albumin was normal. Edema improved with lasix, but lasix stopped given ___. Recommend non-pharmacologic management with ___ compression stockings. # Acute kidney injury: Admit Cr 1.1. Cr 1.5 at discharge likely ___ lasix overdiuresis. # CAD: Restarted ASA # Sterile pyuria: Patient asymptomatic. Urine culture with mixed flora consistent with skin contamination. Outpatient repeat urinalysis. # RUL opacity on CXR: Patient with known prior right upper lobe cavity. # Dementia: Continued donepezil and memantidine # Endometrial cancer s/p hysterectomy
draft_summary: The patient is an elderly woman with a complex medical history who presented with rapidly progressive bilateral leg swelling, erythema, and severe pain concerning for necrotizing soft tissue infection. On arrival, she was febrile, hypotensive, and found to be in new-onset atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response. Laboratory studies revealed profound leukocytosis, acute liver failure, and nephrotic-range proteinuria. Imaging demonstrated extensive bilateral lower extremity deep vein thromboses and pulmonary emboli. She was emergently started on broad-spectrum antibiotics, IV heparin, and vasopressors and admitted to the ICU. Transthoracic echocardiogram showed severely reduced ejection fraction of 20% with apical thrombus. The patient developed flash pulmonary edema requiring intubation and mechanical ventilation. Blood cultures grew multidrug-resistant MRSA and Candida glabrata. She required continuous renal replacement therapy for worsening renal failure. Dermatology diagnosed Stevens-Johnson syndrome as the cause of her lower extremity findings. Neurologically, she suffered an acute embolic stroke with residual hemiparesis. Gastroenterology was consulted for massive GI bleeding requiring transfusion. Oncology noted recurrent metastatic endometrial cancer with lymphatic obstruction. After a prolonged ICU course complicated by cardiac arrest and reintubation, she slowly stabilized. She was discharged to hospice care with comfort-focused goals after family meetings.
fixed_summary: The patient is an older woman with a history of coronary artery disease, dementia, chronic kidney disease, and prior endometrial cancer status post hysterectomy who presented with one week of bilateral lower extremity edema and erythema.â€¨She was asymptomatic, ambulatory, and denied pain, fever, shortness of breath, chest pain, or urinary symptoms.â€¨Initial vital signs were stable, and she was afebrile on presentation.â€¨Laboratory studies showed stable chronic anemia, sterile pyuria, and an elevated BNP greater than 1000.â€¨Electrocardiogram demonstrated new T-wave inversions in leads I and aVL with QTc prolongation.â€¨Chest X-ray showed a possible right upper lobe opacity.â€¨Bilateral lower extremity Doppler studies were negative for deep vein thrombosis.â€¨Transthoracic echocardiogram showed preserved left ventricular systolic function with diastolic dysfunction and mild pulmonary hypertension.â€¨Physical examination revealed bilateral lower extremity edema without focal neurologic deficits.â€¨There was no evidence of infection, pulmonary embolism, or acute coronary syndrome.â€¨The lower extremity edema was attributed to volume overload and diastolic heart failure.â€¨She was treated with diuresis, resulting in improvement of leg swelling.â€¨Renal function showed a mild acute kidney injury that remained stable.â€¨No invasive procedures were performed during the hospitalization.â€¨The patient was discharged home in stable condition with compression stockings.â€¨She was advised to follow up with her primary care physician for ongoing management and medication review.

input: Consider for bone marrow dz/malignancy - consider bone marrow biopsy Mr. ___ presented with lumbar spine osteomyelitis, multiple pulmonary embolisms, atypical pneumonia, strep viridans bacteremia complicated by aortic and mitral valve endocarditis with abscess. He underwent pre-operative evaluation in the CCU and remained in stable condition. He had acute on chronic back and leg pain related to severe spinal stenosis. MRI from ___ also revealed osteomyelitis at L4-L5 without epidural or paraspinal abscess likely related to strep viridans bacteremia. Chest x-rays and chest CT revealed multivfocal pneumonia. Work up was notable for mycoplasma IgM and IgG positivity, indicating recent infection, however not necessarily the cause for present infection. He was treated with 14 day course of doxycycline. He noted to be acutely tachypneic earlier in hospital course. CTA was done which showed bilateral pulmonary emboli. No reported hemodynamic compromise or RV dysfunction. There was prior concern for HIT, however HIT Ab returned negative and platelets were normal. He was anemic at the outside hospital and was transfused 2 units PRBCs. Labs were also notable for iron deficiency with normal ferritin; elevated LDH but haptoglobin also elevated; SPEP with elevated proteins, no M spike. MRI notable for diffuse abnormal bone marrow signal, consistent with a marrow replacement process. Incidentally also found to have splenomegaly on imaging. Had previously been planning for ___ biopsy of bone marrow prior to transfer. He was cleared by hematology and dental s/p tooth extraction to proceed with surgery. He was brought to the operating Room on ___ where he underwent aortic valve replacement, mitral valve replacement, and pericardial patch. Please see operative note for full details. He tolerated the procedure well and was transferred to the CVICU in stable condition for recovery and invasive monitoring. He weaned from sedation, awoke neurologically intact and was extubated on POD 1. He was weaned from inotropic and vasopressor support. ID was consulted for for antibiotic management. Beta blocker was initiated and he developed junctional rhythm with intermittent atrial fibrillation. His beta blocker was stopped and EP was consulted to evaluate intermittent high-grade AV block. He subsequently had temporary screw-in pacemaker placement on ___ with uneventful removal of his epicardial wires. He was diuresing to his preop weight and transferred to the telemetry floor for further recovery. He remained hemodynamically stable with restart of betablocker. He continued with paroxysmal atrial fibrillation but has most recently been in NSR. Given mechanical AVR/MVR and paroxysmal AFib, Coumadin was started with IV heparin bridging (goal INR ___, goal PTT 60-80). He had TTE done ___ to assess valve function. Valves well seated and working well, echo also showed small pericardial effusion w/o tamponade and small secundum ASD with EF 43%. Regarding his Strep Viridans infection, ID team has recommended IV PCN G for 6 weeks with end date of ___. He was evaluated by the physical therapy service for assistance with strength and mobility. By the time of discharge on POD 16 he was ambulating with a walker and will require home ___, the wound was healing, and pain was controlled with a combination of oral analgesics and topical lidocaine patch. He was discharged home in good condition with appropriate follow up instructions. Of note, following antibiotic completion, RUE PICC line should be removed. EP - ___ clinic follow-up with Dr ___ - PICC line removal (once abx course completed) - Will likely need PPM placement in the future (after abx course completed, ideally if BCx remain negative for ___ weeks after abx stopped).

draft_summary: The patient was admitted with widespread metastatic bone cancer causing spinal collapse, massive pulmonary embolisms, and fungal pneumonia leading to respiratory failure. He was found to have uncontrolled leukemia with marrow failure, splenic rupture, and septic shock from MRSA endocarditis involving all four heart valves. His course required emergency liver transplant, dialysis, and prolonged mechanical ventilation with ECMO support. He underwent triple valve replacement complicated by cardiac arrest and stroke. Postoperatively, he developed complete heart block requiring permanent pacemaker implantation and ventricular arrhythmias. He was treated with chemotherapy, antifungals, and lifelong antibiotics. Despite recurrent bleeding and renal failure, he slowly recovered. He was discharged to hospice with plans for palliative radiation therapy.
fixed_summary:
Mr. ___ presented with lumbar spine osteomyelitis, multifocal pneumonia, bilateral pulmonary emboli, and Streptococcus viridans bacteremia complicated by aortic and mitral valve endocarditis with abscess formation. MRI demonstrated L4â€“L5 osteomyelitis without epidural or paraspinal abscess, likely secondary to bacteremia, as well as diffuse abnormal bone marrow signal and splenomegaly concerning for a marrow replacement process. He was anemic and transfused prior to transfer, with iron deficiency and elevated LDH but no monoclonal spike on SPEP; bone marrow biopsy was deferred pending recovery. CTA showed bilateral pulmonary emboli without hemodynamic compromise, and HIT testing was negative.
After preoperative evaluation and dental clearance, he underwent aortic and mitral valve replacement with pericardial patch on ___ and was transferred to the CVICU in stable condition. He was extubated on postoperative day one and weaned from vasopressors. His course was complicated by intermittent atrial fibrillation and high-grade AV block, requiring temporary screw-in pacemaker placement, later removed. He was anticoagulated with heparin bridging to warfarin for mechanical valves. TTE showed well-seated valves, EF 43%, and small pericardial effusion without tamponade. He was discharged on postoperative day 16 on six weeks of IV penicillin G with home services and close follow-up.

Unchanged faint enhancement of the cauda equina nerve roots, without thickening. 2. Unchanged degenerative changes of the lower lumbar spine. ___ CXR IMPRESSION: No acute cardiopulmonary process. No focal consolidation to suggest pneumonia. ___ CT abdomen IMPRESSION: 1. Fluid-filled non-dilated loops of small bowel, cecum and ascending colon, likely representing a viral gastroenteritis. No evidence of obstruction. The appendix is not visualized but there is no secondary sign of acute appendicitis. 2. Mild colonic diverticulosis without evidence of diverticulitis. 3. Hepatic steatosis. You had a CT scan completed that showed irritation in your gut (colon). We later found out that you had norovirus. By the time of discharge your diarrhea and nausea had resolved and we did not think you were contagious any longer. You were also sent for worsening weakness. Our neurology team evaluated you multiple times during your stay. You had an MRI that was unchanged. It was thought that this did not represent worsening of your GBS, thus you did not get any more IVIG. You have follow up with neurology in a few weeks. Please take your medications as prescribed. It was a pleasure taking care of you! Your ___ careteam

input: ___ yo woman with non-ischemic cardiomyopathy (EF: 50-55% in ___, paroxsymal atrial fibrillation who presents with shortness of breath secondary to CHF exacerbation . # Shorthness of breath/CHF exacerbation. Admitting differential diagnosis include acute on chronic CHF, pulmonary emobolism, infection. Heart rates well controlled so Atrila fibrillation not deemed a contributing factor. CTA without evidence of infiltrate or embolism, however did demonstrate findings compatible with right-sided heart failure. Patient treated for exacerbation in setting of radiographic evidence and compatible clinic symtoms. Unclear trigger was patient denies dietary indiscretion or medication non-compliance. Possible insufficient diuretic dose contributed to exacerbation. Diuretic dose increased from 10mg PO Lasix per day -> 20mg PO Lasix per day with use of 20mg IV on ___. Additional spirinolactone was increased from 12.5 every other day to every day. Patient was weaned off supplemental oxygen with near resolution in symptoms. OUTPATIENT ISSUES: -- Continue diuresis with Lasix 20mg PO per day, Spirinolactone 12.5mg PO per day; patient will need to monitor weights daily and contact PCP/cardiologist if weights increase >3lbs as diuretic dose may need to be altered. . # Cardiomyopathy. Followed by cardiology. In house diuretic dose tailored and patient maintained on home regimen of beta-blocker, lisinopril, statin, digoxin. . # Paroxysmal atrial fibrillation. CHADS 3. Patient monitored on telemetry and remained in Afib throughtout stay. 1) Rate controll: Well controlled on home metroprolol (HRs 70-80s). 2) Anticoagulation: INR on admission supra-therapeutic at 4.0. Coumadin held initially. Coumadin 2mg per day (decreased from 3mg) restarted on ___. INR on day of discharge 1.6. OUTPATIENT ISSUES: -- Weekly INR checks to ensure therapeutic INR and proper dose of coumadin. . # Rheumatoid arthritis. Followed by rheumatology as an outpatient. Continued on home regimen of methotrexate (7.5 mg ___ and predisone (3mg daily) . # Osteoporosis- Continued on home alendronate, calcium and vitamin D . # Gout. No signs of active flare on admission. Maintained on standing allopurinol . # Macrocytic Anemia: Stable. Multiple prior B12/folates normal.

draft_summary:
The patient is a middle-aged woman with severe ischemic cardiomyopathy (EF ~25%), permanent atrial fibrillation, and a history of multiple prior myocardial infarctions who presented with acute hypoxic respiratory failure.
She was found to be in atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response causing cardiogenic shock and hypotension.
CT angiography revealed massive bilateral pulmonary emboli with right ventricular strain and pulmonary infarction.
She required ICU admission, noninvasive ventilation, and intravenous vasopressor support.
Aggressive diuresis with high-dose IV furosemide and continuous bumetanide infusion led to rapid symptomatic improvement.
The heart failure exacerbation was triggered by medication noncompliance and excessive salt intake.
Her anticoagulation was transitioned from warfarin to apixaban after supratherapeutic INR-related bleeding complications.
She developed acute kidney injury requiring temporary dialysis during hospitalization.
Rheumatoid arthritis flared, necessitating escalation of steroids and biologic therapy.
She was discharged home on home oxygen with plans for heart transplant evaluation.
fixed_summary:
She is a woman with non-ischemic cardiomyopathy and paroxysmal atrial fibrillation who came to the hospital because her breathing had slowly become more difficult.
Testing showed no infection or blood clot, but imaging and symptoms were consistent with a heart failure exacerbation.
Her heart rate remained well controlled, making atrial fibrillation an unlikely cause of her shortness of breath.
She was treated with increased diuretics, including a brief course of IV furosemide, which led to steady improvement.
Her oxygen needs resolved as excess fluid was removed, and her breathing returned close to baseline.
Spironolactone was increased to support ongoing volume control.
She remained stable on her chronic heart medications, including beta-blocker, ACE inhibitor, statin, and digoxin.
Her anticoagulation was adjusted due to a high INR on admission, and warfarin was restarted at a lower dose.
Other chronic conditions, including rheumatoid arthritis, gout, and osteoporosis, remained stable during admission.
She was discharged feeling improved, with instructions to monitor her weight closely and follow up with cardiology.

input: <SEX> F <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> Demerol / Iodine / Augmentin <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> nausea and vomiting x 4 days <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> ___ Cardiac catherization <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> Ms. ___ is a ___ year old female with medical history significant for Type I Diabetes with ESRD s/p renal transplant in ___ on chronic immunosuppressive agents, who presents with nausea and vomiting of 4 days' duration. Pt stated that this episode was more severe that her usual gastroparesis, and that while her vomiting has eased up in the last two days, she has not been able to tolerate any POs including water, causing her to miss all of her medications since ___. Pt also had loose stools x 4 since yesterday. She had chills, but no fevers that she knows of. . In the ED, she complained of substernal chest pain that felt like pressure with no radiation. Vitals were: 97.7 123 144/72 28 100% on RA. Pt was started on IVF 200cc/hr, Insulin drip 6 units/hr with Q 1hr ___, was given Levaquin 750 mg IV x 1, ASA 325 mg PO x 1, and Zofran 4 mg IV x 1. U cx and B cx were sent. EKG showed demand ischemia (was faxed to Cards fellow for review). CK and Trop sent. Kidney U/S showed mild pelviectasis. CXR demonstrated no acute process. . ROS: Positive for SOB, worse with activity; unintentional weight loss of ___ pounds in 3 months; worsening visual acuity; mild abdominal pain in lower quadrants. Negative for melena, hematochezia, chest pain, orthopnea, PND, lower extremity edema, cough, urinary frequency, urgency, dysuria, lightheadedness, gait unsteadiness, focal weakness, vision changes, headache, rash or skin changes. . <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> Diabetes Type 1, s/p renal transplant in ___, with a history of episodes of diabetic ketoacidosis. Gastroparesis secondary to DM. Hypertension. Hypercholesterolemia. Coronary artery disease with an ejection fraction of 55% in ___, MI x2 and a three-vessel CABG in ___. Left below the knee amputation in ___. Vascular procedures on the right lower extremity. Heel ulcers due to diabetes, s/p bypass graft surgeries Peripheral neuropathy CVA x2. S/p cholecystectomy S/p cataract surgery Depression. <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> Uncle with diabetes Sister died of colon CA Mother died of brain CA <PHYSICAL EXAM> Vitals: T: BP: HR: RR: O2Sat: GEN: Well-appearing, well-nourished, no acute distress HEENT: EOMI, PERRL, sclera anicteric, no epistaxis or rhinorrhea, MMM, OP Clear NECK: No JVD, carotid pulses brisk, no bruits, no cervical lymphadenopathy, trachea midline COR: RRR, no M/G/R, normal S1 S2, radial pulses +2 PULM: Lungs CTAB, no W/R/R ABD: Soft, NT, ND, +BS, no HSM, no masses EXT: No C/C/E, no palpable cords NEURO: alert, oriented to person, place, and time. CN II Â– XII grossly intact. Moves all 4 extremities. Strength ___ in upper and lower extremities. Patellar DTR +1. Plantar reflex downgoing. No gait disturbance. No cerebellar dysfunction. SKIN: No jaundice, cyanosis, or gross dermatitis. No ecchymoses. <PERTINENT RESULTS> Labs (blood) ___ 03: 30PM WBC-14.7 Hgb-12.6 Hct-41.1 MCV-92 MCH-28.3 MCHC-30.7 RDW-13.7 Plt ___ Neuts-92* Bands-0 Lymphs-5.0* Monos-3 Eos-0 Baso-0 ___ PTT-24.2 ___ Glucose-759* UreaN-49* Creat-1.7* Na-130* K-5.6* Cl-86* HCO3-11* Calcium-9.6 Phos-4.2# Mg-2.3 ALT-18 AST-16 LD(LDH)-181 CK(CPK)-77 AlkPhos-213* TotBili-0.5 Lipase-12 cTropnT-0.10* Acetone-LARGE ASA-4 Ethanol-NEG Acetmnp-NEG Bnzodzp-NEG Barbitr-NEG Tricycl-NEG pH-7.31* Glucose-GREATER TH Lactate-3.0* Na-132* K-5.4* Cl-93* calHCO3-11* freeCa-1.04* . Labs (urine) ___ 04: 20PM Color-Straw Appear-Clear Sp ___ Blood-LG Nitrite-NEG Protein-TR Glucose-1000 Ketone-150 Bilirub-NEG Urobiln-NEG pH-5.0 Leuks-NEG ___ Bacteri-FEW Yeast-NONE ___ UTox: bnzodzp-NEG barbitr-NEG opiates-NEG cocaine-NEG amphetm-NEG mthdone-NEG . ___ renal transplant ultrasound FINDINGS: A transplanted kidney is visualized in the right lower quadrant of the abdomen and measures 10.8 cm in length. The corticomedullary differentiation is preserved. Mild pelviectasis is noted which appears new compared to the most recent prior study in ___. Doppler assessment demonstrates resistive indices of the upper, mid and lower poles of 0.8, 1.0, and 1.0. Normal venous flow is demonstrated in the main renal vein. While the arterial upstroke is good in the main renal artery there is minimal diastolic flow. Limited images of the bladder are unremarkable. IMPRESSION: Right lower quadrant transplanted kidney with mild new pelviectasis. Elevated resistive indices as described. Clinical correlation is recommended. . ___ CXR FINDINGS: The lungs are clear without consolidation or edema. There is evidence of prior median sternotomy and CABG. There is convexity involving the AP window which is stable from the prior exam. The cardiac silhouette size is within normal limits. Again seen is minimal blunting of the left costophrenic angle possibly due to the scarring or small effusion. No pneumothorax is noted. The bones are diffusely osteopenic but otherwise unremarkable. The patient has had prior cholecystectomy. IMPRESSION: Relatively stable radiographic examination demonstrating no acute process. . ___ ECG: Sinus tachycardia at 127 bpm, nl axis, nl PR, QRS, and QT intervals, fair R-wave progress, 2mm ST depression in V4-6. . ___ Cardiac cath: 1. Selective coronary angiography of this left dominant system revealed 3 vessel coronary artery disease. The LMCA was normal. The LAD had mild luminal irregularities proximally with a total mid-segment occlusion. D1 was patent with moderate diffuse disease. The LCX is a dominant vessel with mild luminal irregularities. The non-dominant RCA had moderate diffuse disease. 2. Graft arteriography revealed a patent LIMA-LAD, and stump occluded SVGs to OM1 and PDA. 3. Limited resting hemodynamics revealed systemic arterial hypertension with aortic pressures of 178/64 and mildly elevated left sided filling pressures with LVEDP of 17. There was no transaortic pressure gradient on pullback of catheter from LV to aorta. 4. Left ventriculography was not performed. . ___ L femoral U/S No evidence of pseudoaneurysm. . <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> Cymbalta, hydromorphone, furosemide, prednisone, nitroglycerin, Isordil, Plavix, Prograf, glyburide, tramadol, metoprolol, CellCept, gabapentin, ASA, piroxicam, Lipitor, and insulin. <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home With Service Facility: ___ <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> Primary: Diabetic ketoacidosis Non ST-elevation myocardial infarction Right foot ulcer . Secondary: Diabetes Type 1, s/p renal transplant Gastroparesis secondary to diabetes. Hypertension. Hypercholesterolemia. Left below the knee amputation Vascular procedures on the right lower extremity. Peripheral neuropathy cerebrovascular accident x2. S/p cholecystectomy S/p cataract surgery Depression. <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Good, stable. Tolerating POs well <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> You were admitted to the hospital because you were extremely dehydrated and had high blood sugars. We treated you with intravenous fluids and insulin drip, which resolved the acidosis of your blood caused by high sugar. . You had episodes of chest pain during this hospitalization, with elevation of cardiac enzymes. We performed cardiac catherization to evaluate the cause of these frequent chest pains. It showed that your heart arteries are diffusely narrow, with blockage of two out of three bypass grafts, which were also previously seen in ___. No interventions were made. . The following changes were made to your medication regimen: Isordil 20 mg twice a day --> Imdur 60 mg daily Lipitor 10 mg daily --> Lipitor 80 mg daily Aspirin 81 mg daily --> Aspirin 325 mg daily Please resume all of your other medications. It is very important that you take all medications, especially your immunosuppression medications (CellCept, Tacrolimus, Prednisone). . Please attend all of your follow-up appointments. . If you have severe chest pain, nausea/vomiting, shortness of breath, palpitations, or any other concerning symptoms, please call your primary care physician or return to the emergency room. . ***For today, ___, please take 12 units of Lantus with dinner. Starting tomorrow, you can resume taking 18 units of Lantus once a day with dinner, along with Glyburide and carbohydrate counting for short-acting insulin.***
target: Ms. ___ is a ___ year old female with medical history significant for Type I Diabetes with ESRD s/p renal transplant in ___ on chronic immunosuppressive agents, who presents with nausea and vomiting of 4 days' duration, and found to be in DKA. 1) DKA: Anion gap closed with aggressive hydration and insulin drip per DKA protocol. Pt was started on subcutaneous Insulin coverage once gap had closed, with frequent finger sticks. Potassium was repleted PRN. Differential for precipitating factors included diarrhea, gastroparesis, c.diff, MI, infection, or viral gastroenteritis (given pt's lower abdominal discomfort on admission). Pt also may have had TSS with history that a tampon was left in place for 5 days (this history was revealed on a few days after admission). Pt received a single dose of Levoquin in ED on admission, which was not continued in the ICU given that she had borderline high normal WBC and afebrile. Tachycardia resolved with hydration. Upon discovery of retained tampon during hospital stay, vancomycin was started, however, this too was discontinued based on the absence of clinical symptoms and signs. 2) Unstable angina: Pt complained of substernal chest pain in the ED. EKG changes were initially felt to be consistent with demand ischemia due to tachycardia. Pt had cardiac enzyme elevation that peaked then slowly trended down. Pt continued to have short episodes of chest tightness, and cardiac enzymes were cycled. ASA, statin (80 mg daily rather than 10 mg daily, which is her home dose), metoprolol, isosorbide dinitrate (later switched to isosorbide mononitrate extended release) were continued. Heparin gtt were used intermittently with her symptoms. Pt underwent cardiac catherization on ___, which showed diffusely diseased vessels and two out of three occluded grafts (which were previously seen in ___. No interventions were made. 3) DM, type 1 ___ followed the patient during her stay. Pt's insulin regimen were optimized according to blood sugar checks. Pt was encouraged to take part in sliding scale insulin administration. Pt was discharged home on Glyburide 5 mg daily, Lantus 18 units at dinner time, and short-acting insulin with carbohydrate counting. Pt has an appointment to follow up at ___. 4) ARF: Cr 1.7 on admission. Improved to 0.7 with aggressive hydration. U/S of transplanted kidney showed mild pelviectasis. Because pt received dye for cardiac cath, pt was instructed to get a check of BUN and Cr when she follows up with her PMD. 5) Lower abdominal tenderness: unclear etiology. UCG was neg. Resolved shortly after admission. 6) S/p renal transplant: Pt's regular immunosuppressive therapy was continued. Renal team followed pt as inpatient. Pt was advised not to miss any transplantation medications (may open capsules and take the powder sublingually if unable to tolerate PO due to nausea). Pt's Prograf levels were in the lower limits of therapeutic range when checked during hospitalization. Pt was instructed to get a repeat level at her PMD's office when she goes for her follow-up appointment. 7) Right heel ulcer She regularly sees a podiatrist as outpatient for foot care. Podiatry was consulted as inpatient, who recommended that adaptic and guaze dressing be continued, as the ulcer is healing well. 8) Depression: stable - continued cymbalta 9) Code: DNR, but do wish to be intubated if necessary. Husband ___ is her health care proxy.

RIGHT ATRIUM/INTERATRIAL SEPTUM: No ASD by 2D or color Doppler. LEFT VENTRICLE: Mild symmetric LVH with normal cavity size and regional/global systolic function (LVEF>55%). No resting LVOT gradient. RIGHT VENTRICLE: Mildly dilated RV cavity. Normal RV systolic function. AORTA: Normal diameter of aorta at the sinus, ascending and arch levels. Focal calcifications in aortic root. No 2D or Doppler evidence of distal arch coarctation. AORTIC VALVE: Normal aortic valve leaflets (3). No AS. No AR. MITRAL VALVE: Mildly thickened mitral valve leaflets. No MVP. Mild thickening of mitral valve chordae. Mild (1+) MR. ___ VALVE: Normal tricuspid valve leaflets. Mild [1+] TR. Normal PA systolic pressure. PULMONIC VALVE/PULMONARY ARTERY: Normal pulmonic valve leaflet. No PS. Physiologic PR. PERICARDIUM: No pericardial effusion. Conclusions The left atrium and right atrium are normal in cavity size. No atrial septal defect is seen by 2D or color Doppler. There is mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy with normal cavity size and regional/global systolic function (LVEF>55%). The right ventricular cavity is mildly dilated with normal free wall contractility. The diameters of aorta at the sinus, ascending and arch levels are normal. The aortic valve leaflets (3) appear structurally normal with good leaflet excursion and no aortic stenosis or aortic regurgitation. The mitral valve leaflets are mildly thickened. There is no mitral valve prolapse. Mild (1+) mitral regurgitation is seen. The estimated pulmonary artery systolic pressure is normal. There is no pericardial effusion. IMPRESSION: Mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy with normal cavity size and systolic function. Minimally dilated right ventricle with normal systolic function. Mild mitral regurgitation. Chest Film: ___ In comparison with the study ___, the monitoring and support devices have been removed except for the right IJ catheter. With the left chest tube removed, there appears to be an area of the upper left zone without pulmonary markings. This could represent a small to moderate apical pneumothorax. What appears to be a pleural line at the lower portion of this area could merely reflect the cartilaginous calcification in the superior aspect of the first rib on the left. Opacification at the left base is consistent with atelectasis and small effusion. <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> Lipitor 10 mg daily Levothyroxine 150mcg daily Metformin 500mg BID Lisinopril 10mg daily Metoprolol 50mg BID Ntg SL 0.3 prn ASA 81mg daily omeprazole 20mg daily <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. Aspirin EC 81 mg PO DAILY 2. Atorvastatin 80 mg PO QPM 3. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID 4. Furosemide 40 mg PO DAILY Duration: 7 Days RX *furosemide 40 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth once a day Disp #*7 Tablet Refills: *0 5. HYDROmorphone (Dilaudid) 2 mg PO Q4H: PRN pain RX *hydromorphone 2 mg ___ tablet(s) by mouth every four (4) hours Disp #*60 Tablet Refills: *0 6. Levothyroxine Sodium 150 mcg PO DAILY 7. Omeprazole 20 mg PO DAILY 8. MetFORMIN (Glucophage) 500 mg PO BID 9. Metoprolol Tartrate 25 mg PO BID 10. Potassium Chloride 10 mEq PO DAILY Duration: 7 Days take with furosemide RX *potassium chloride [Klor-Con 10] 10 mEq 1 tablet(s) by mouth once a day Disp #*7 Tablet Refills: *0 <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home With Service Facility: ___ <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> Primary: Coronary Artery Disease s/p Coranaary Artery Bypass Grafting x3(LIMA-LAD,SVG-LCx,SVG-OM) Secondary: Hypertension Diabetes mellitus type II hypothyroidism <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Alert and oriented x3 nonfocal Ambulating with steady gait Incisional pain managed with Incisions: Sternal - healing well, no erythema or drainage Leg Right/Left - healing well, no erythema or drainage. Edema <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> Please shower daily including washing incisions gently with mild soap, no baths or swimming until cleared by surgeon. Look at your incisions daily for redness or drainage Please NO lotions, cream, powder, or ointments to incisions Each morning you should weigh yourself and then in the evening take your temperature, these should be written down on the chart No driving for one month or while taking narcotics. Answering service will contact on call person during off hours**
target: The patient was transferred from outside hospital for revascularization after cardiac catheterization revealed multivessel disease. He had been loaded with Plavix for the catheterization and was started on a heparin infusion for unstable angina during his plavix washout. On ___ he was brought to the operating room by Dr ___ bypass grafting. Please see the operative report for details, in summary he had: Coronary artery bypass grafting x3 with the left internal mammary artery to the left anterior descending artery, and reverse saphenous vein graft to the obtuse marginal artery and the distal circumflex artery. His bypass time was 80 minutes with a crossclamp time of 66 minutes. He tolerated the operation well and after surgery was transferred to the cardiac surgery ICU in stable condition. He had a fair amout of bloody drainage on arrival to the ICU and given his pPlavix dosing and normal coagulation studies received platelets with resolution of the bleeding. Shortly after the bleeding was stopped he woke neurologically intact and was extubated. On day one he was hemodynamically stable and breathing comfortably. He was started on BBlockers and diuresed toward his pre operative weight. His chest tubes remained in until POD 3, at that time his epicardial wires were removed also. He remained in the ICU until POD 3 because there were no stepdown beds available. Once on the stepdown floor he worked with nursing and physical therapy to increase his strength and endurance. The remainder of his post-op course was uneventful. He was discharged home with ___ on POD4. He will follow-up as an outpatient.

input: <SEX> M <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> Penicillins <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Gout flare <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> None <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> ___ with hx gout, atrial flutter, HTN, COPD, DM2, HLD, and recent surgery for spinal stenosis complains of one day of sudden onset L knee pain. The patient stated the pain came on suddenly the morning prior to admission and got progressively worse throughout the day. He stated the knee was very red and swollen. By that evening he was unable to bear weight and came to the ED. The patient stated that the joint pain felt like a gout flare. He denied any fevers, hx of trauma. He has had 3 gout flares in his life, the last one in ___. He thinks the joint was tapped back in ___ and showed gout crystals. His previous episodes have been in his ankle. He does not know what precipitates the attacks. In the ED the patient's intial vitals were 98.2 88 141/58 12 95% ra. He was given colchicine 0.6mg tabs x4, 50mg indomethacin, probenicid ___. Xray of the knee showed soft tissue swelling about the right knee with small joint effusion, as well as "redemonstration of scalloped appearance of the anterior aspect of the femoral trochlea of indeterminate etiology and chronicity". His pain and edema/erythema improved markedly in the ED. ___ saw the patient and because he could not walk well (and has to climb stairs at his apt) he was admitted for further optimizaiton of his pain. On the floor, vs were: 97.3 BP: 144/76 P: 66 R: 20 O2: 95% RA <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> From OMR: Hypertension, Essential Microscopic Hematuria Gout COPD Type 2 diabetes mellitus with renal manifestations, controlled Hyperlipidemia History of Colon Cancer SPINAL STENOSIS - LUMBAR besity Renal cell cancer s/p radiofrequency ablation to two lesions ___. Soft tissue swelling about the right knee with small joint effusion. 2. Redemonstration of scalloped appearance of the anterior aspect of the femoral trochlea of indeterminate etiology and chronicity. Please see prior recommendations. MICRO: None <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete. 1. Aspirin 81 mg PO DAILY 2. Calcium 500 + D (calcium carbonate-vitamin D3) 600/400 units Oral daily 3. Diltiazem Extended-Release 240 mg PO DAILY 4. Lisinopril 10 mg PO DAILY 5. Multivitamins 1 TAB PO DAILY 6. Probenecid ___ mg PO BID 7. Ranitidine 150 mg PO BID 8. Simvastatin 10 mg PO HS 9. Cyanocobalamin 1000 mcg PO DAILY <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. Aspirin 81 mg PO DAILY 2. Ranitidine 150 mg PO BID 8. Simvastatin 10 mg PO HS 9. Calcium 500 + D (calcium carbonate-vitamin D3) 600/400 units Oral daily <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home With Service Facility: ___ <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> Gout flare <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker or cane). <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> Dear Mr. ___, It was a pleasure taking care of you during your stay. You were admitted on ___ for a gout flare in your left knee. You were given four doses of colchicine and one dose of indomethacin in the emergency room, which greatly improved your pain. Your home dose of probenecid was increased to prevent these gout flares in the future. You were seen by physical therapy who recommended discharge to home with physical therapy services at home. Please follow up with your primary care physician in ___ week after discharge.
target: ___ with hx gout, atrial flutter, HTN, COPD, DM2, HLD, and recent surgery for spinal stenosis presented with one day of sudden onset left knee pain due to gout flare ACTIVE ISSUES: # Left knee pain: consistent with an acute gout attack. The patient has a history of gout, with the last attack in ___. He is on probenecid for prevention. The patient was given colchicine 0.6mg tabs x4, 50mg indomethacin, and probenecid ___ in the emergency room, which greatly improved his symptoms. His probenecid was incraesed to 1000mg BID in order to prevent future attacks. He should follow up with his PCP for further management of his gout. # Diarrhea: The patient had several episodes of diarrhea after receiving 4 doses of colchicine in the emergency room. After stopping his colchicine his diarrhea improved. CHRONIC ISSUES: # Spinal stenosis: the patient was recently admitted in ___ for spinal stenosis s/p spinal surgery, with residual ___ weakness. He has been in rehab for several weeks and his ___ weakness is improving. Can walk with walker or cane at home. There was some concern initially for cauda equina syndrome given history of urinary urgency and ___ weakness, however, there was no saddle anesthesia and his weakness seemed to be improving. Rectal tone was intermediate and the patient was able to bear down. Physical therapy consulted and initially recommended going to rehab. At discharge the patient had improved and they recommended home with ___. # Urinary urgency: The patient reported a one month of urinary urgency. He often has incontinence before he can reach the bathroom. He should follow up with his PCP about this issue. TRANSITIONAL ISSUES: # Knee xray: Scalloped appearance of the anterior aspect of the femoral trochlea of indeterminant etiology and chronicity and may related to mass effect from a suprapatellar mass/effusion. MR examination would provide further imaging evaluation if clinically warranted. # Anemia: The patient is anemic with MCV of 100. He is on vitamin B12 supplementation. He should follow up with his PCP for further management of this issue.
