Ferritin 106 in house (wnl). # S/P hernia repair ___: Continued prn oxycodone for pain. # BPH: Continued home tamsulosin/finasteride TRANSITIONAL ISSUES ===================================== Discharge Weight: 62.5kg -No medication changes; continue home metoprolol/lisiniprol/torsemide for HF, metoprolol/dabigatraban for atrial fibrillation, and aspirin/atorvastatin for CAD -Patient scheduled for cardiology and PCP follow up next week -Please have patient call cardiologist ___ if weight increses > 3 lbs, can take 20 mg Torsemide extra prn if weight up per outpt cardiologist. Daughter ___, with whom patient lives, has good understanding of this heart failure condition and diuretic regimen and doses his medications at home.

input: Summary: ___ yo female with coronary artery disease status post PCI, paroxysmal atrial fibrillation, breast cancer status post radical mastectomy, recent hospitalization for cardiac tamponade status post pericardiocentesis left-sided pleural effusion status post thoracentesis readmitted with hypotension, hypoxemia, and leukocytosis in the setting of recurrent pleural and pericardial effusions. . #Bilateral pleural effusion (left>right): The patient presented with respiratory distress and was found to have a recurrence of her left sided pleural effusion leading to complete left lung collapse and hypoxemia, requiring intubation. Thoracic surgery inserted a chest tube on the left and a pigtail catheter on the right which both drained serosanginous fluid. The chest tube on the right was eventually pulled after it stopped draining. The insertion of the chest tube on the left was complicated by a pneumothorax, so another chest tube was inserted on the left with a pigtail catheter. The pigtail catheter eventually stopped draining and it was subsequently pulled. A talc pleurodiesis was performed and the patient's pain was controlled with Dilaudid at first and then oxycodone thereafter. Her chest tubes were removed and a chest xray confirmed full expansion of the left lung with an unchanged pleural effusion. She continued to be diuresed with Lasix, however, she developed a metabolic alkalosis with a respiratory acidosis. Diamox was added to the lasix regimen and her bicarbonate remained level. Her final chest xray shows left lower lobe atelectasis. Movement and incentive spirometry were encouraged and should be continued at rehab. The patient continues to have an oxygen requirement, likely due to her atelectasis and possibly an underlying pulmonary process. She has a scheduled pulmonology followup appointment that was made at her last hospitalization. At that time, they will perform pulmonary function testing. . While in the ICU, the patient was started on prednisone for a post-viral serositis. The prednisone was eventually discontinued after 5 days because the post-viral serositis was unlikely in this context. Analysis of the pleural fluid showed the absence of malignant cells in cytology, no bacteria/viral/acid fast bacteria on repeat cultures, and flow cytometry showed no cells concerning for lymphoma. The pleural effusions might be due to exacerbation of her diastolic heart failure, though on prior admissions, the effusion did not appear to be a transudate. Lastly, A CT of the abdomen from ___ showed a cyst in the lower abdomen. A CA125 was mildly elevated and a ___ was in the normal range. A pelvic U/S was done to further characterize the cyst and it was noted to be a simple cyst and not concerning for malignancy. . #Septic shock: The patient was initially hypotensive and the differential included septic shock vs. cardiogenic shock. A bedside echo in the ED did not find evidence of tamponade, so the patient most likely had septic shock with the source of infection being pulmonary. Her blood pressure responded to intravenous fluids boluses. She was initially started on broad spectrum antibiotics vancomycin/zosyn to cover hospital acquired pneumonia and the patient improved. She completed a full course of vancomycin/zosyn for hospital acquired pneumonia and did not have any other signs of hemodynamic instability. . #Acute on chronic anemia: The patient continued to have a low hematocrit with iron=10 (L) and a slightly high ferritin. Her stools were guiaic negative. The patient might have an underlying iron deficiency anemia, though it is unclear given her high ferritin. A reticulocyte count showed an appropriate reponse to her anemia. After repeated blood draws, the patient's hematocrit steadily dropped to 21.8. On ___, she was transfused two units of blood and tolerated it well. On discharge, her hematocrit was 28.9. . #Acute renal failure: The patient presented with acute renal failure, which was likely prerenal azotemia given UNa<10. With treatment of her hypotension, the patient's renal failure trended towards her baseline around 0.6-1.0. With continued diuresis and the addition of lisinopril for BP management, the patient developed acute renal failure again. Her diuresis was held and lisinopril discontinued. Her creatinine on discharge was 1.4. . #Urinary tract infection: The patient presented with a urinary tract infection and was treated with vanco/zosyn as detailed above. She then developed yeast in her urine and her foley was removed. Two days after her Foley was removed, she had a leukocytosis without fever or dysruia. A urine culture revealed pan-senstive Pseudomonas 10,000-100,000 colonies. Treatment with Cipro was initiated and her leukocytosis trended downwards. No yeast remains in her urine. . # Anxiety and Depression- Continue trazodone and ativan as needed. The patient was noted to be anxious during the hospitalization and would consider further therapy with a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor as an outpatient. . #Paroxysmal atrial fibrillation: On admission, the patient was on amiodarone, metoprolol and coumadin. Since the patient remained in a sinus arrhythmia (not in atrial fibrillation on telemetry) throughout hospitalization, it was felt the risks of Coumadin outweighed the benefits, therefore, she will not continue on Coumadin. She will continue to take aspirin, metoprolol and amiodarone for her paroxysmal atrial fibrillation. . # Recurrent pericardial effusion: The pericardial effusion has also been a recurrent issue. A TTE showed an effusion without hemodynamic compromise, therefore, it was treated medically. A repeat echocardiograms showed a reduced effusion. . #H/O hyponatremia: The patient has a history of hyponatremia that has been attributed to the syndrome of inappropriate anti-diuretic hormone release. Her sodium remained in normal range during her time on the floors, so she will not be continued on salt tablets on discharge. In fact, she should avoid sodium since it might precipitate congestive heart failure, the possible etiology of her pleural effusions. She will have a blood draw later in the week to check her sodium. On discharge, her sodium was 133. . # Swollen right arm: The patient was noted to have a swollen right arm. She had a PICC line during the last hospitalization. An ultrasound ruled out a deep venous thrombosis. With diuresis, the swelling improved, so it was likely related to fluid overload. . # Hypothyroidism: Continue Levoxyl . # Osteoporosis: Continue Vitamin D/Calcium . # GERD: Continue omeprazole . # Memory loss: The patient's family states that she does not have any memory loss. She came into the hospital on Donezepil and at the family's request, it was discontinued before discharge. Outpatient followup: 1. Cardiopulmonary assessment 2. Anemia workup/treatment, if any. 3. Daily weights to assess fluid retention 4. Pulmonary followup appointment for pulmonary function tests 5. laboratories: check BUN, Cr, sodium, Hct, WBC

draft_summary: An elderly woman with severe end-stage cardiomyopathy and uncontrolled atrial fibrillation was admitted in cardiogenic shock after stopping all her heart medications and eating a high-salt diet. She was found to have massive pulmonary emboli, pneumonia, and acute kidney failure requiring ICU admission and emergent dialysis. Her hospital course was complicated by ventricular arrhythmias, stroke, and new-onset sepsis requiring intubation. She underwent urgent cardioversion, pacemaker placement, and high-dose IV vasopressors. She was discharged to a skilled nursing facility on hospice-level care with worsening heart failure.
fixed_summary: The patient is a woman with a history of non-ischemic cardiomyopathy with preserved ejection fraction, paroxysmal atrial fibrillation, rheumatoid arthritis, and osteoporosis who presented with shortness of breath due to a congestive heart failure exacerbation. Initial evaluation considered CHF exacerbation, pulmonary embolism, and infection; CTA showed no embolism or infiltrate but findings consistent with right-sided heart failure. Atrial fibrillation was rate controlled and not felt to be the primary contributor. She was treated with diuresis, including intravenous furosemide, with improvement in symptoms and successful weaning off supplemental oxygen. Her outpatient diuretic regimen was adjusted with an increased dose of oral furosemide and daily spironolactone, with instructions to monitor daily weights. Chronic cardiomyopathy medications were continued. She remained in atrial fibrillation with adequate rate control on metoprolol. Anticoagulation was managed by holding warfarin initially for supratherapeutic INR, then restarting at a lower dose with close outpatient INR monitoring. Other chronic conditions, including rheumatoid arthritis, osteoporosis, gout, and macrocytic anemia, remained stable on home therapies. She was discharged in improved condition with cardiology follow-up.

input: Mr. ___ is an ___ M w PMHx of PD, AFib not on anticoagulation ___ falls, HTN, and COPD who presents today with complaint of confusion at home. He was initially brought to ___ and was transferred to ___ after ___ showed left hemispheric SDH and left temporal IPH as well as very small R sided SDH. Although there is no history of any trauma, the location and different types of bleed are most consistent with a traumatic mechanism. Also, patient does have frequent falls at home. It is also possible that he struck his head on something and does not remember this. #NEUROLOGY - L SDH, L temporal IPH, small R SDH. NCHCT was stable day after admission. MRI/A head showed no evidence of infarct, mass, vascular malformation, or VST. He was started on Keppra for a 7 day course of seizure prophylaxis. That should be discontinued after ___. His aspirin has been held in the setting of the hemorrhage. Aspirin 81mg can be re-started on ___. History of PD: home sinemet and selegine were continued. It is imperative that the patient takes these medications regularly. #CV Patient has known afib. Heart rates were slightly elevated to the mid teens and home metoprolol was increased from 25mg bid to 37.5mg bid. He is not on anticoagulation as he is at high risk for fall. Lasix was discontinued as it was not needed. TRANSITIONS OF CARE: - Keppra 500mg bid should be discontinued after ___ - Aspirin 81mg can be re-started on ___.

draft_summary:
Mr. ___ presented after a witnessed fall with loss of consciousness and was found to have massive bilateral intracranial hemorrhages.
He rapidly deteriorated neurologically and required emergent intubation and neurosurgical decompression.
Imaging demonstrated progressive subdural and intraparenchymal bleeding with midline shift and herniation.
He developed refractory seizures despite antiepileptic therapy.
Anticoagulation for atrial fibrillation was urgently reversed due to life-threatening hemorrhage.
His hospital course was complicated by ischemic stroke and acute respiratory failure.
Parkinsonâ€™s medications were held, leading to severe rigidity and autonomic instability.
Cardiac monitoring revealed sustained ventricular arrhythmias requiring ICU-level care.
Neurologic recovery was poor, with persistent coma and poor prognosis.
He was discharged to hospice care following goals-of-care discussions with family.
fixed_summary:
Mr. ___ presented with confusion at home and was transferred for further evaluation after imaging revealed intracranial hemorrhage.
Head CT showed a left hemispheric subdural hematoma, a left temporal intraparenchymal hemorrhage, and a small right-sided subdural hematoma.
Although no trauma was reported, the pattern of bleeding was felt to be most consistent with a traumatic mechanism in the setting of frequent falls.
Repeat CT imaging the following day showed stable hemorrhages without progression.
MRI and vascular imaging demonstrated no evidence of infarction, mass, vascular malformation, or venous sinus thrombosis.
He was started on a seven-day course of levetiracetam for seizure prophylaxis.
Aspirin was held due to intracranial bleeding, with plans for delayed re-initiation.
His Parkinsonâ€™s disease medications were continued and emphasized as essential for daily functioning.
Atrial fibrillation was managed with an increased dose of metoprolol, and anticoagulation was avoided due to fall risk.
He was stabilized medically, and clear instructions were provided for medication adjustments after discharge.

target: ___ with hx of COPD, ESRD s/p renal transplant, CAD p/w dyspnea and ___ and a positive influenza B swab. Thought to be a COPD exacerbation due to influenza B infection in the context of immunosuppression, with some component of mild pulmonary edema. During her hospital stay, she also developed oral thrush with associated sore throat. She has now completed treatment for influenza B and her respiratory status is stable. Her oral thrush and sore throat have resolved. TRANSITIONAL ISSUES =================== - Please draw tacrolimus trough level and Chem 10 on ___. Fax results to ___ Nephrology Attn: Dr. ___ ___ - Anticipate rehabilitation stay to be less than 30 days - Needs ongoing chest ___ to help bring up mucus - Prednisone taper outline in post discharge medication list. Will start ___: 40 x3 days, 20 x3 days, 10 x3 days, and 5 x3 days - Recommend aggressive mucolytic therapy with guiafenasin and chest ___ BID - Recommend humidified oxygen to help thin secretions. - Continue Nystatin for 14 days to end on ___ - tacro dose changed to 1 mg BID on ___ -CODE: Full (confirmed) -CONTACT: ___ (granddaughter, HCP) ___ # ___, influenza B, COPD: On arrival, Ms. ___ was mildly tachypneic, with a supplemental O2 requirement and dyspnea. She was soon transitioned to room air after receiving prednisone and duonebs. Over the course of her hospital stay,she received a 5-day course of Tamiflu and 5-day course of prednisone 40 to treat her influenza B and COPD exacerbation. She began on duonebs q4h, which were weaned to ipratropium nebs q6h and albuterol nebs PRN. She continued to receive her home Advair. When she continued to have some dyspnea and wheezing with occasional oxygen requirement after receiving this treatment, we re-started predisone 60 with a planned wean of 60 x3 days, 40 x3 days, 20 x3 days, 10 x3 days, and 5 x3 days. We also performed a CT chest, which showed significant retained mucus in the lungs and potential aspiration. We started chest ___, humidified air and standing guanfesin. Her respiratory status is now stable, requiring albuterol nebs a few times a day in addition to her home medications. # CHF with reduced EF: EF 45% per ___ echo. No visible JVD or peripheral edema. Estimated dry weight 123 lbs. Recorded weights were feared to be inaccurate with scale malfunction. Received torsemide ___ and ___. Plan to continue 20 mg QoD starting ___. continued home carvedilol, ASA, isosorbide mononitrate. # Sore throat, thrush: Treated with nystatin, plaques resolved by day of discharged. Plan total 14 day course of nystatin. # Hyponatremia: Thought to be hypovolemic in setting of over-diuresis. Improved with optimization of volume status. # ESRD s/p LRRT: Cr at baseline. Followed by Renal. Tacro dose changed to 1 mg BID as level >10 on ___. Continued azathioprine, cinacalcet, sevelamir, calcitriol. Planning to have Chem 10 and tacro level drawn on ___ as above. # CAD: new T-wave inversion in aVF on EKG and slightly elevated trop on admission; now normalized. Pt denied chest pain, palpitations. Elevated trop most likely in presence of known CAD and poor renal function. continued home carvedilol, ASA, isosorbide mononitrate #Tracheobronchomalacia: severe appearance on CT imaging. thought to have no indication for intervention after discussion with IP. Chronic issues: #GERD: cont'd Omeprazole BID #RLL lung lesion: Scheduled for repeat CT Chest ___ to eval progression. #Anemia of chronic disease: On Aranesp, last injection ___ #Depression: cont'd citalopram #HTN: Coreg, Imdur as above
draft_summary:
Ms. ___ presented with acute hypoxic respiratory failure secondary to severe influenza B pneumonia complicated by septic shock.
Given her immunosuppressed status following renal transplant, she rapidly deteriorated and required ICU admission and mechanical ventilation.
Imaging revealed diffuse bilateral infiltrates consistent with ARDS and superimposed bacterial pneumonia.
She developed acute graft rejection with rising creatinine requiring emergent dialysis.
Cardiac evaluation demonstrated an acute NSTEMI requiring heparin infusion and coronary intervention.
Her course was further complicated by severe heart failure exacerbation with pulmonary edema requiring high-dose diuretics.
Persistent airway collapse necessitated bronchoscopic stenting for tracheobronchomalacia.
She experienced prolonged delirium and profound deconditioning, limiting rehabilitation progress.
Due to ongoing oxygen dependence, she required long-term home oxygen and nocturnal BiPAP.
She was discharged to a long-term acute care facility with a guarded prognosis.
fixed_summary:
Ms. ___ presented with dyspnea and was found to have influenza B in the setting of COPD and chronic immunosuppression following renal transplant.
Her symptoms were attributed to a COPD exacerbation triggered by influenza infection, with a mild contribution from pulmonary edema.
She was treated with a five-day course of oseltamivir and systemic steroids, along with inhaled bronchodilators.
Her oxygen requirement improved quickly, and she was transitioned to room air early in her hospital stay.
Persistent wheezing and dyspnea prompted a prolonged prednisone taper and further pulmonary evaluation.
CT imaging revealed retained mucus and possible aspiration, leading to initiation of chest clearance therapy, humidified air, and mucolytics.
During hospitalization, she developed oral thrush with associated sore throat, which resolved with nystatin therapy.
Her renal function remained at baseline, though tacrolimus dosing was adjusted due to elevated trough levels.
Cardiac evaluation showed stable heart failure with reduced ejection fraction and no clinical signs of volume overload.
At discharge, her respiratory status was stable, chronic conditions were managed, and follow-up laboratory monitoring was arranged.

input: <SEX> F <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> Tegretol / Advil <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Abrupt awakenings x 2 overnight <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> none <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> ___ with dCHF, pulmonary HTN, intersitial lung disease, obstructive sleep apnea who presented to the ED because of 2 episodes of self-reported apnea overnight. Patient states that she was asleep overnight with her CPAP and abruptly woke up. She was not acutely short of breath, and was able to breath right away, but thought she possibly had an episode of apnea. She sat up, but was very sleepy so sat up but fell asleep again without her CPAP on. She later awoke again abruptly without dyspnea, again attributing it to apnea. She then slept for the rest of the night comfortably without CPAP until her CNA woke her up in the morning as per routine. Patient had plans for the day but decided to present to the ED for evaluation of her two abrupt awakenings overnight. Patient's CPAP does not have an apnea alarm. In further exploring her symptoms, patient reports she is (and has been in the recent few days) at her baseline ___ right sided chest pain and abdominal pain. She has an undulating course of shortness of breath also since ___, and although she has been on a mild upswing this week, she is not here for that complaint, as her breathing is still essentially within the worse limit of her baseline. However, she does believe she has been drinking more water lately (dry lips), and feels her ___ edema has worsened. Also reporting increased swelling/edema to lower pannus. She has had multiple admissions under circumstances (most recently in ___. She acknowledges that she sometimes has rib spasms and presents to the ED when she cannot regulate her breathing. BNP on prior admission noted to be at 2262. In the ED, initial vitals were 97.5 81 105/71 20 100% 15L nrb. While in the ED she was weaned to her home 3L O2. She was noted to have slight wheezing. CXR showed no acute process of volume overload. BNP ___, trop 0.02. pH 7.32 pCO2 62 pO2 34 HCO3 33. EKG showed new TWI in V5-V6, prompting admission to Cardiology for possible ACS vs. CHF. At present, she is at her baseline CP and is not particularly short of breath. She has no acute complaints except referring back to her nighttime awakenings as described above. She at first refused to speak to any interns and was upset about having to repeat her answers to H/P questions. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> 1. CARDIAC RISK FACTORS: Diabetes, Dyslipidemia 2. CARDIAC HISTORY: - CABG: - PERCUTANEOUS CORONARY INTERVENTIONS: - PACING/ICD: 3. OTHER PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: - Morbid obesity. - Nonalcoholic fatty liver disease. - Hypercholesterolemia. - Impaired fasting glucose. - Secondary amenorrhea. - Polycystic ovaries. - Asthma. - Obstructive sleep apnea on CPAP. - Depression. - Nephrolithiasis. - Epilepsy. - GERD. - Learning disability. - Recurrent sinusitis. - Restrictive lung disease, ILD vs hypersensitivity pneumonitis <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> Mother alive, h/o Breast Ca. Father had DM, d. Bladder Ca. Four siblings: 1 sister d. in fire, stepsister w/ RA. Nephew w/ asthma. No family history of early MI, arrhythmia, cardiomyopathies, or sudden cardiac death; otherwise non-contributory. <PHYSICAL EXAM> VS: 97.6 115/68 p98 R20 97% on 3LNC GENERAL: Obese lady in NAD, speaking in full sentences. Oriented x3. Irritable. Upset about answering questions she has already been asked. HEENT: NCAT. Sclera anicteric. PERRL, EOMI. Conjunctiva were pink, no pallor or cyanosis of the oral mucosa. No xanthelasma. NECK: JVP not visible, possibly due to habitus CARDIAC: RR, S1, S2. SEM at ___. No r/g. LUNGS: No chest wall deformities, scoliosis or kyphosis. Resp were unlabored, no accessory muscle use. CTAB. No crackles, wheezes or rhonchi appreciable. ABDOMEN: Soft, obsese. Nontender to palpation. Patient reporting increased swelling to lower pannus. EXTREMITIES: Trace pitting edema to extremities, with tense adipose. Distal pulses 1+ ___, 2+ UE bilaterally SKIN: No stasis dermatitis, ulcers, scars, or xanthomas. NEURO: CN II-XII intact. Motor and sensory exam grossly normal. On discharge: VS: 145.4kg. 97.8 Tm 98.3, HR 64-68. BP 92/56-115/68, RR 20, 86-98% on CPAP, 97-98% on 2L I/O: ___ GENERAL: Obese woman in NAD, sleeping with CPAP, easily awakened, speaking in full sentences. Oriented x3. Irritable. HEENT: NCAT. Sclera anicteric. PERRL, EOMI. Conjunctiva were pink, no pallor or cyanosis of the oral mucosa. No xanthelasma. NECK: JVP not visible, possibly due to habitus CARDIAC: RR, S1, S2. ___ SEM at ___. target: #. Tylenol OD: Patient admitted for ingestion of a large amount of tylenol tablets and 26 2mg Klonopin pills. Anion gap metabolic acidosis: Pt had a mild gap metabolic acidosis (Gap 15) that was likely secondary to her ingestion with a component of vomiting. Salicylates were negative, ETOH was negative. Her acidosis resolved on HD 2 with hydration and treatment of tylenol OD w/ NAC. All subsequent labs were in the normal range. . #.Bipolar disorder: Pt w/ depressive symptoms during her hospital stay, voiced that she had no desire to live on ___ and was counseled on different forms of help that we could provide to help w/ her life stressors. Her psych meds were held in the setting of her acute liver failure but can now be started as her liver function normailizes. No manic symptoms during hospitalization. Remained with 1:1 sitter throughout. . #. RLS: Pt w/ history of restless leg syndrome discussed with pharmacy risk/benefit of stopping sinemet abruptly and felt that low risk of worsening liver failure and high risk of abrupt cessation of medication so her medication was continued. No episodes of restless legs reported by patient. . #Herniated disk: Pt w/ chronic back pain because of herniated disk. Started on oxycodone 5mg q6h:prn.
draft_summary:
Patient was admitted to the hospital after ingesting a large amount of acetaminophen (APAP) 15 hours prior to presentation. She was treated with N-acetylcysteine (NAC) and activated charcoal. Her vital signs were stable, and she was transferred to the ICU for further management. She received a total of 50mg/kg of NAC over 4 hours and then 100mg/kg of NAC over 16 hours. The patient's liver function had recovered, and electrolyte disturbances had resolved with hydration and treatment. The patient was also tested for Clostridioides difficile (C. difficile) and had a negative result. The patient was discharged from the hospital after a few days of treatment. 

Note: The note about the patient's mental health and suicidal thoughts is not included in the summary as it is not relevant to the clinical summary of the patient's hospital stay.
fixed_summary: Patient was admitted to the hospital after ingesting a large amount of acetaminophen (APAP) 15 hours prior to presentation. She was treated with N-acetylcysteine (NAC) and activated charcoal.

target: Mr. ___ is a ___ with history of HCV/alcohol cirrhosis complicated by ___ s/p deceased donor liver transplant on ___ who presents for further management and evaluation of leukopenia (WBC 1.9 with ANC 264) and rash. ACTIVE ISSUES # Leukopenia/ Neutropenia: Most likely due to immunosuppressive drugs including tacrolimus or mycophenolate, which are known to cause marrow suppression, or TMP-SMX, which is known to cause agranulocytosis. His symptoms are temporally correlated with a switch in his cellcept formulation. The patient is also at risk for opportunistic infections, particularly CMV, however CMV was negative. Other viral serologies still pending. Given recent tick bite, tick-borne illness workup sent, negative to date. His TMP-SMX was stopped ___ for neutropenia and he was switched to Dapsone (G6PD negative) for PCP ___. Inpatient, he was treated with Neupogen 480 mcg daily with improvement in his counts, though insurance appeal for outpatient coverage pending at discharge. On discharge, he should be on the previous formulation of cellcept which he tolerated. He will need labs on ___ for monitoring prior to transplant follow-up appt next ___. # Liver failure, s/p diseased donor liver transplant: history of HCV/alcohol cirrhosis s/p DD liver transplant on ___, on tacrolimus and mycophenolate for immunosuppression. Pt has history of HCC and TACE x2 prior to transplantation. He was continued on tacrolimus at his home dose of 1.5mg bid but decreased his mycophenolate to 500mg (decreased ___. He was continued valgancyclovir for CMV PPX and his Bactrim was switched to dapsone as above. # Rash: The patient presented with a macular, migratory, pruritic, lasting only a few hours at a time. It also affects palms. DDx included drug rash vs. less likely viral (CMV neg). ___ be associated with new formulation of mycophenolate as symptoms seemed to start after he switched to a different generic formulation or from Bactrim. The rash was present on admission but resolved rapidly. # HA: The patient developed a bitemporal frontal HA not different from usual. No meningeal signs or fever. Likely tension HA, tacrolimus level was 10->8.8. CHRONIC ISSUES # HTN: Continued on amlodipine and metoprolol # GERD: chronic and stable. Continued on famotidine ======================================= TRANSITIONAL ISSUES: - Was treated with Neupogen inpatient. ___ need additional dose(s) after discharge, insurance issues being coordinated with ___ and pharmacy - Needs labs (CBC with diff, Chem10, Liver panel, Tacrolimus) drawn ___ prior to appointment next week - Switched back to old formulation of mycophenolate as new formulation may be causing side effects, insurance issues being coordinated with ___ and pharmacy. Patient was given 1mo supply per insurance override; this will need to be addressed at follow-up. - Bactrim was discontinued for leukopenia - Dapsone was started as an alternate to Bactrim for PCP ___. draft_summary: Mr. ___ is a middle-aged man with a history of liver transplant who presented with profound pancytopenia, septic shock, and multiorgan failure after collapsing at home. He was found to have a white blood cell count of zero with complete bone marrow failure caused by recurrent metastatic hepatocellular carcinoma infiltrating the marrow. During admission, he developed fulminant CMV encephalitis, bacterial meningitis, and invasive fungal pneumonia requiring ICU care. Tacrolimus was permanently discontinued due to acute graft rejection and replaced with high-dose cyclophosphamide. He underwent emergent splenectomy and bone marrow biopsy confirming acute leukemia transformation. His hospital course was complicated by massive GI bleeding, acute renal failure requiring dialysis, and Stevens-Johnson syndrome from antibiotics. Neupogen caused cytokine storm and respiratory failure requiring intubation. He suffered a cardiac arrest but fully recovered neurologically. After aggressive chemotherapy and plasmapheresis, his blood counts normalized overnight. He was discharged home off all immunosuppression, cured of cirrhosis, and cleared for international travel.
fixed_summary: Mr. ___ is a liver transplant recipient with a history of HCV and alcohol-related cirrhosis complicated by hepatocellular carcinoma, admitted for evaluation of leukopenia and neutropenia. Outpatient labs showed WBC 1.9 with ANC 264, prompting admission for further workup and treatment. He was asymptomatic aside from baseline arthralgias and mild myalgias with possible rhinorrhea. There was no evidence of active infection during hospitalization. CMV viral load and G6PD testing were pending at discharge. His leukopenia was suspected to be medication-related. Tacrolimus levels were monitored and adjusted during admission. Neupogen was administered inpatient after insurance barriers prevented outpatient use. His white blood cell count and ANC improved prior to discharge. A diffuse macular rash noted on admission resolved during hospitalization. Renal function and liver enzymes remained stable. He was discharged in stable condition with close outpatient laboratory monitoring arranged.

input: Mr. ___ is a ___ yo gentleman with history of oculobulbar myasthenia, on prednisone and recently added on azathioprine, who presented with one day of worsening shortness of breath ___ setting of one month of progressively worsening dysarthria, dysphagia, ptosis, and diplopia. The precipitating cause for this was unclear, but the subacute decline despite uptitration of immunosuppressive medications was concerning and the patient was admitted to the Neurology ICU. # Myasthenia Crisis The patient's exam showed significant bulbar and proximal weakness over the course of many days and required intubation shortly after admission to the hospital. He underwent plasmapheresis x 5 sessions (___). Neuromuscular specialists were consulted for treatment recommendations, with the following changes: azathioprine 200 mg daily, prednisone 60 mg daily, stop mestinon. TPMT activity normal, CT chest negative for thymoma, per outpatient neurologist. . Patient was initially NPO because of significant bulbar weaknees, with NS @ 75cc/hr. Once the patient was intubated, an OG was placed and TF were started. After extubation, he was evaluated by speech and swallow and passed - able to tolerate a regular diet which he will continue after discharge. . Physical therapy also worked with the patient and felt that he had no deficits after several inpatient ___ deficits and was safe for home discharge. . # Pulmonary - Respiratory failure, mixed Patient was intubated on ___ due to respiratory muscle fatigue, increasing O2 requirement, and increasing hypercarbia. He had increased secretion despite discontinuing mestinon. There was concern for aspiration pneumonitis causing elevated WBC but CXR was negative for aspiration or atelectasis. The patient had yellow mucoid secretions and was monitored closely for pneumonia. BAL showed no growth. Antibiotics were given for several days and then were discontinued. . # ID The patient was febrile to 100.8 on ___. Respiratory and urine cx were sent and returned negative. Empiric Abx with vanc/cefepime were started but DCed once culures returned negative. . # Blood pressure Patient was on continuous telemetry monitoring, with no acute events. Lisinopril was initially continued on admission but then held because of soft pressures after intubation; he was on low dose phenylephrine while on propofol, but the pressor was weaned off after 3 days. He was resumed on his lisinopril on discharge. . # Endocrine Home metformin was held due to need for multiple medication changes and tests that could affect renal function. The patient was treated with insulin SS. Metformin was reinstated and tolerated well prior to discharge. . # TRANSITIONAL ISSUES # - Increased prednisone to 60mg daily - Increased azathioprine to 200mg daily - Stopped Mestinon
target: Mr. ___ is an elderly gentleman with longstanding myasthenia gravis who presented after collapsing at home with weeks of confusion, seizures, and complete paralysis. He was found to be in fulminant myasthenic crisis complicated by septic shock, massive aspiration pneumonia, and acute renal failure. Shortly after arrival, he required emergent intubation, ECMO support, and continuous dialysis. Imaging revealed a large invasive thymoma with brain metastases, prompting urgent oncology consultation. He underwent daily plasmapheresis for two weeks and received high-dose cyclophosphamide and IVIG. His hospital course was complicated by refractory hypotension, myocardial infarction, and diabetic ketoacidosis. Blood cultures grew multidrug-resistant organisms requiring prolonged broad-spectrum antibiotics. He developed severe dysphagia necessitating PEG placement and remained unable to tolerate oral intake. Neurologically, he suffered a large ischemic stroke with permanent deficits. After multiple cardiac arrests, goals of care were changed to comfort measures. He was discharged to hospice with tracheostomy and ventilator dependence. Prognosis was deemed poor with life expectancy of weeks.

fixed_summary: Mr. ___ is a man with oculobulbar myasthenia gravis on prednisone and azathioprine who presented with one day of worsening shortness of breath following a month of progressive dysarthria, dysphagia, ptosis, and diplopia. He was admitted to the Neurology ICU for concern of myasthenic crisis. Due to worsening bulbar and proximal weakness, he required intubation shortly after admission for respiratory muscle fatigue and hypercarbia. He underwent five sessions of plasmapheresis with clinical improvement. Immunosuppression was adjusted with an increase in prednisone to 60 mg daily and azathioprine to 200 mg daily, and pyridostigmine was discontinued. CT chest showed no thymoma per outpatient records. He was initially NPO, then received tube feeds while intubated, and later passed a speech and swallow evaluation after extubation. He tolerated a regular diet prior to discharge. Infectious workup for fever was negative, and empiric antibiotics were discontinued. Blood pressure fluctuations related to sedation resolved, and home lisinopril was resumed. Diabetes was managed with insulin during hospitalization, and metformin was restarted prior to discharge. Physical therapy found no residual functional deficits. He was discharged home in stable condition with updated myasthenia management.

input: ___ F past medical history of atrial fibrillation on rivaroxaban, latent TB on INH, ulcerative colitis, presented with non-focal weakness and diarrhea. # Diarrhea: Loose, occasionally bloody stools without mucus and associated abdominal pain but no upper GI symptoms. GI was consulted, and the case was staffed with her outpatient gastroenterologist. She had negative stool cultures. She underwent a flexible sigmoidoscopy, the findings of which were consistent with active ulcerative colitis (pathology similarly consistent with UC). CT scan showed colonic inflammation to the splenic flexure, consistent with a UC flare. Colorectal was consulted, with plan for surgery. She underwent a laparoscopic proctocolectomy with end ileostomy on ___. She tolerated the procedure well with no complications and was transferred to the PACU in stable condition. Please see the operative note for technical details. Postop, her pain was initially controlled with a dilaudid PCA then she was switched to oral pain meds. Her diet was initially advanced to clears on POD#1 but he became nauseous from this was was made NPO again. She was then advanced slowly till she was tolerating a regular diet. On POD#7, she c/o urinary urgency and a UA showed large luekocytes so she was given ceftriaxone for one day then switched to 3 day course of ciprofloxacin. The days afterwards were spent encouraging her to increase her PO intake, working with a dietician and continuing TPN. By POD#11, she was ambulating with assistance, tolerating regular diet and her pain was controlled with oral pain meds so she was deemd fit for discharge to a rehab facility. # Hypokalemia: Ongoing hypokalemia associated with continued diarrhea. She was repleted twice to three times daily while being monitored on telemetry. # Weakness: Nonfocal neurologic exam throughout with negative head CT and no signs or symptoms of sepsis. Most likely due to deconditioning and ongoing diarrheal losses. Patient refused to work with Physical Therapy while on the ___ but was willing to ambulate and get OOB after surgery. Her nutrition was supplemented with Ensure and she was started on TPN postop. She was also given Megace to help stimulate her appetite; calorie counts were ordered and she was seen by a dietician to advice her on the best types of foods to consume to maximize caloric intake. # Acute on Chronic Anemia: Likely having small GI losses from her ulcerative colitis with low iron stores from poor nutrition. Because she is a Jehovah's Witness, she will not accept blood products; a signed acknowledgement of this was placed in her chart, and confirmed with her HCP/daughter. # Latent TB: Patient had been started on INH in preparation for starting Remicade; however, after biologic therapy was determined not to be an option for her, patient opted to discontinue her INH. # Atrial Fibrillation: CHADS-VASC of ___ with history of stroke putting her at high thromboembolic risk. Xarelto was stopped pre-operatively in favor of heparin gtt... Her home metoprolol was continued (except when held for low blood pressures responsive to IV fluids as above). Postop, heparin gtt was stopped and levenox was restarted. She was restarted on metoprolol to control her atrial fibrillation after surgery. She will restart Xarelto after discharge. # Glaucoma: Continued home dose eye drops. # Hypertension: Held home Norvasc given normotension (with occasional episodes of hypotension). Amlodipine restarted after surgery

draft_summary: Ms. ___ is an elderly woman with atrial fibrillation on rivaroxaban, ulcerative colitis, and latent tuberculosis who presented with profound weakness, septic shock, and acute renal failure requiring ICU admission. She was found to have fulminant Clostridioides difficile colitis with toxic megacolon and bowel perforation on CT imaging. Emergency open total colectomy with splenectomy and small bowel resection was performed, complicated by massive intraoperative bleeding requiring transfusion. Postoperatively, she developed respiratory failure requiring prolonged mechanical ventilation and vasopressor support. Her course was further complicated by ischemic stroke related to atrial fibrillation after anticoagulation was held. She developed multidrug-resistant urosepsis requiring prolonged IV carbapenem therapy. Persistent hypokalemia led to ventricular arrhythmias requiring temporary pacing. Severe malnutrition necessitated long-term TPN and PEG tube placement. She was diagnosed with new metastatic colon cancer on surgical pathology. Latent TB reactivated, requiring four-drug RIPE therapy. She experienced adrenal crisis due to chronic steroid use. Recurrent GI bleeding worsened her anemia, requiring blood transfusions despite religious objections. She became wheelchair dependent with critical illness myopathy. She was ultimately discharged to long-term acute care with tracheostomy and poor neurologic recovery.
fixed_summary: Ms. ___ is a woman with a history of atrial fibrillation on rivaroxaban, ulcerative colitis, and latent tuberculosis who presented with weakness and diarrhea. Her diarrhea was loose and occasionally bloody, associated with abdominal pain, and attributed to a flare of ulcerative colitis. Stool studies were negative, and CT imaging showed colonic inflammation extending to the splenic flexure. Flexible sigmoidoscopy and pathology confirmed active ulcerative colitis. Due to refractory disease, she underwent a laparoscopic proctocolectomy with end ileostomy, which she tolerated without surgical complications. Postoperatively, pain was initially managed with a PCA and then transitioned to oral medications. Her diet advancement was slow due to nausea, requiring temporary NPO status and nutritional support including TPN. She developed hypokalemia related to diarrheal losses and was repleted with close monitoring. Postoperative weakness was attributed to deconditioning and poor nutritional intake. She was treated briefly for a urinary tract infection based on urinalysis findings. Anemia was managed conservatively due to refusal of blood products as a Jehovahâ€™s Witness. Latent TB treatment with INH was discontinued after biologic therapy was no longer planned. Anticoagulation was transitioned perioperatively and planned to resume after discharge. She was discharged to a rehabilitation facility once ambulating with assistance, tolerating a regular diet, and with pain controlled on oral medications.

Metoprolol Tartrate 25 mg Tablet Sig: 0.5 Tablet PO BID (2 times a day): hold fro SBP <110; HR <60. 6. Oxycodone 5 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablet PO every ___ hours as needed for pain. 7. Colace 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO twice a day. 8. Senna 8.6 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO twice a day as needed for constipation. 9. Milk of Magnesia 800 mg/5 mL Suspension Sig: Thirty (30) ML's PO twice a day as needed for constipation. 10. Vancomycin in Dextrose 1 gram/200 mL Piggyback Sig: One (1) GM Intravenous Q 12H (Every 12 Hours) for 2 weeks. 11. Ceftriaxone in Dextrose,Iso-os 1 gram/50 mL Piggyback Sig: One (1) GM Intravenous Q24H (every 24 hours) for 2 weeks. 12. Insulin Regular Human 100 unit/mL Solution Sig: One (1) Dose Injection four times a day as needed for per sliding scale. <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Extended Care Facility: ___ <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> s/p Fall Parietal/occipital subgaleal hematoma Right posterior 7th rib fracture Pneumonia T1 transverse process fracture Right buttock hematoma Acute blood loss anemia Oliguira <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Hemodynamically stable, tolerating a regular diet, pain adequately controlled <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> Wear the soft cervical collar for comfort; velcro may be placed in front.
target: He was admitted to the Trauma ICU with following injuries parietal/occipital subgaleal hematoma, right post 7 rib fracture, T1 spinous process fracture as well as a right buttock hematoma with active extravasation. He was actively resuscitated in the ICU with aggressive fluid therapy. A TTE showed hypovolemia and for a low hematocrit of 23 he was given units of packed red cells on ___ post transfusion hematocrit 26. His respiratory status was tenuous likely due to fluid overload and he was given 60mg IV Lasix for pulmonary edema. On ___ he was given another 20mg IV Lasix; a deep sputum culture was obtained showing GPC and GNR and he was started on vancomycin and ceftriaxone. The antibiotics will continue for 2 weeks. He remained in the ICU for several days becoming delirious. Geriatrics was consulted and made several recommendations pertaining to his medications such as scheduling Tylenol, minimizing narcotics, and use of small doses of anti-psychotic to manage behaviors. He was eventually transferred to the regular nursing unit where later in the evening had a desaturation episode. He was also at that time noted with low urine output and was given a fluid challenge with increase in his urine output. He has a 22 CoudÃ© catheter in placed which was inserted by Urology during his ICU stay because of problems with urinary retention. The catheter may removed at the discretion of the primary team once voiding adequately while at rehab. His oxygen saturations did improve and he is currently 97% with forehead probe on ___ liters per minute. Of note on CT imaging of his chest a small nodule was detected; it is being recommended that he have follow up CT of his chest in the next several months. He will require follow up with his primary care doctor for this as an outpatient. He was evaluated by Physical and Occupational therapy and is being recommended for acute care rehab.
draft_summary: The patient is a middle-aged man who fell from a skyscraper staircase during a seizure, arriving comatose and requiring immediate neurosurgical intervention. He was found to have massive intracranial hemorrhage, spinal cord transection, and bilateral femur fractures requiring emergent fixation. In the emergency department, he suffered cardiac arrest, was resuscitated twice, and required prolonged CPR. Imaging revealed ruptured aortic aneurysm, splenic laceration, and complete hepatic failure requiring urgent transplant evaluation. He developed septic shock from aspiration pneumonia and MRSA bacteremia, necessitating high-dose vasopressors and ECMO. Neurologically, he was diagnosed with severe anoxic brain injury and remained unresponsive throughout admission. Cardiac evaluation showed severe systolic heart failure with EF 10% and acute myocardial infarction. He required continuous renal replacement therapy for multi-organ failure. His hospital course was complicated by disseminated intravascular coagulation and massive transfusion protocol activation. Infectious disease identified invasive fungal pneumonia requiring amphotericin B. He underwent emergency tracheostomy and PEG placement. Oncology was consulted after bone marrow biopsy revealed acute leukemia. Despite maximal therapy, he remained critically unstable. Goals of care were transitioned to comfort measures after family meeting. The patient expired shortly thereafter from refractory shock.
fixed_summary: An older man was admitted after falling down approximately 14 stairs with subsequent altered mental status and brief hypotension in the emergency department. Imaging showed a large parietal/occipital subgaleal hematoma, a right posterior eighth rib fracture, a T1 spinous process fracture, and a large right buttock hematoma with active extravasation. Head CT demonstrated no intracranial hemorrhage. He developed acute blood loss anemia with a significant drop in hemoglobin, requiring close monitoring but no operative intervention. Cardiac evaluation with echocardiography showed preserved biventricular systolic function and a moderately dilated aortic root. He underwent central line placement for access and monitoring. His mental status gradually improved without focal neurologic deficits. Pulmonary imaging showed emphysematous changes and a small left apical lung nodule requiring outpatient follow-up. He was managed conservatively for his fractures and hematomas. Pain was controlled with oral medications. He remained hemodynamically stable prior to discharge. Physical therapy assisted with mobility. He tolerated a regular diet. He was discharged to an extended care facility in stable condition. A soft cervical collar was recommended for comfort.

input: ___ year-old left-handed man with CAD, HLD, PAD/PVD, cerebral amyloid, and multiple prior strokes who presented from OSH with worsened lower extremity weakness and dysphagia. Imaging was significant for new left lateral medullary infarct. Likely etiology is significant atherosclerosis. Primary problem remains dysphagia, which has worsened from baseline. Cranial nerve exam revealed rightward tongue deviation, and poor right palate elevation, guttural voice with significant dysarthria (but comprehensible). Full strength in all muscle groups, but LUE ataxia and difficulties with mobility (per ___. # Dysphagia: Dysphagia is a chronic problem for him, which he managed with a specific diet and extreme caution. His dysphagia worsened following this new stroke, though he was able to manage his secretions by various methods of coughing and utilizing the Yankauer suction tip, which was in his hand essentially all day every day during his admission. He failed video swallow with significant deficits and a PEG was placed on ___. The tube was revised to a larger bore on ___ due to becoming clogged with crushed PO pantoprazole. We switched his PO pantoprazole to IV since the crushed PO formulation was clogging his PEG tube. This may be changed to a more compatible solid PPI. ___ and his wife are highly motivated for rehab with physical and speech therapy. # Impaired mobility: Despite full strength on physical exam, he has had worsened mobility due to a combination of deconditioning and ataxia. He will benefit from continued physical therapy and I believe his prognosis is good for becoming ambulatory. # Overnight desaturations: While asleep his SaO2 would regularly drop to the mid-80s. While it seems most likely due to management of his secretions, he never showed any signs of aspiration (including clear chest imaging), so there may be an element of sleep apnea. However, we would not recommend CPAP due to increased risk of aspirating those secretions under positive pressure. He used supplemental O2 during some of his admission, but disliked wearing the nasal cannula, and did not need it during the day. It seems likely his overnight saturations are normal for him and something he has tolerated for years. # Atherosclerosis: We continued the atorvastatin 80mg which was started at the OSH. # Hypertension: Due to his stroke, we allowed his BP had been allowed to auto-regulate. We restarted his home amlodipine 5mg on the day of discharge. # CAD s/p DES: We held his Plavix for 3 days prior to the PEG tube placement, even though the usual hold is 5 days. His cardiologist noted his critical stents and was comfortable with at maximum a 3 day pause. His Plavix and aspirin should be continued indefinitely. # Cerebral amyloid angiopathy: His MRI revealed numerous old microhemorrhages highly suggestive of amyloid. The highest level of anticoagulation/antiplatelet that we are comfortable with is aspirin and Plavix -- which is especially needed for his cardiac stents. He shouldn't be anticoagulated with Coumadin, apixaban, or any other of the newer agents due to his very high risk of cerebral hemorrhage. ============================================ AHA/ASA Core Measures for Ischemic Stroke and Transient Ischemic Attack 1. Dysphagia screening before any PO intake? (x) Yes, confirmed done - () Not confirmed Â– () No 2. DVT Prophylaxis administered? (x) Yes - () No 3. Antithrombotic therapy administered by end of hospital day 2? (x) Yes - () No 4. LDL documented? (x) Yes (LDL = 140) - () No 5. Intensive statin therapy administered? (simvastatin 80mg, simvastatin 80mg/ezetemibe 10mg, atorvastatin 40mg or 80 mg, rosuvastatin 20mg or 40mg, for LDL > 100) (x) Yes - () No [if LDL >100, reason not given: ] 6. Smoking cessation counseling given? () Yes - (x) No [reason (x) non-smoker - () unable to participate] 7. Stroke education (personal modifiable risk factors, how to activate EMS for stroke, stroke warning signs and symptoms, prescribed medications, need for followup) given (verbally or written)? (x) Yes - () No 8. Assessment for rehabilitation or rehab services considered? (x) Yes - () No 9. Discharged on statin therapy? x() Yes - () No [if LDL >100, reason not given: ] 10. Discharged on antithrombotic therapy? (x) Yes [Type: (x) Antiplatelet - () Anticoagulation] - () No 11. Discharged on oral anticoagulation for patients with atrial fibrillation/flutter? () Yes - () No - (x) N/A

draft_summary: The patient is a 62-year-old right-handed man with advanced Parkinson disease, severe dementia, metastatic lung cancer, and longstanding atrial fibrillation on warfarin who presented after collapsing at home with sudden quadriplegia and loss of consciousness. Imaging revealed a massive bilateral brainstem hemorrhage extending into the cerebellum with obstructive hydrocephalus, requiring emergent neurosurgical decompression and ventriculostomy placement. He was intubated for airway protection and placed on continuous EEG for refractory seizures. His dysphagia rapidly progressed to complete inability to handle secretions, leading to recurrent aspiration pneumonia and septic shock. A tracheostomy and jejunostomy tube were placed after multiple failed extubation attempts. Cardiac catheterization showed severe triple-vessel coronary disease with in-stent thrombosis, requiring emergent CABG. His hospital course was complicated by acute renal failure requiring hemodialysis, fulminant hepatic failure, and disseminated intravascular coagulation. MRI also revealed spinal cord infarction explaining his paralysis. He developed severe hypoxic brain injury and remained comatose throughout admission. Anticoagulation was escalated to high-dose heparin despite multiple intracranial bleeds. He required vasopressors for persistent cardiogenic shock. Speech therapy deemed recovery of swallowing impossible. Oncology diagnosed paraneoplastic brainstem encephalitis. Family elected withdrawal of care after ethics consultation. He expired shortly after terminal extubation. Autopsy confirmed widespread metastatic disease and massive cerebral infarction.
fixed_summary:
The patient is a left-handed man with a history of coronary artery disease, hyperlipidemia, peripheral vascular disease, cerebral amyloid angiopathy, and multiple prior strokes who presented from an outside hospital with worsening lower-extremity weakness and dysphagia. Brain imaging demonstrated a new left lateral medullary infarct, most likely due to underlying atherosclerotic disease. His primary ongoing issue during hospitalization was significantly worsened dysphagia compared to baseline. Cranial nerve examination showed rightward tongue deviation, poor right palate elevation, guttural voice, and marked dysarthria, though speech remained comprehensible. Motor strength was preserved, but he had left upper-extremity ataxia and impaired mobility.
The patient failed a video swallow evaluation and required placement of a PEG tube, which was later upsized due to clogging from crushed oral medications. Pantoprazole was switched to an IV formulation to prevent further tube obstruction. He managed secretions with frequent coughing and Yankauer suction. Mobility limitations were attributed to ataxia and deconditioning, and continued physical therapy was recommended. Overnight oxygen desaturations occurred during sleep but without evidence of aspiration; CPAP was avoided due to aspiration risk.
He remained on high-intensity atorvastatin for atherosclerosis. Blood pressure was initially autoregulated post-stroke, and amlodipine was restarted at discharge. Dual antiplatelet therapy with aspirin and clopidogrel was continued due to critical coronary stents. Anticoagulation was avoided because of cerebral amyloid angiopathy. The patient and family were highly motivated for rehabilitation with physical and speech therapy.

input: TRANSITIONAL ISSUES: -Patient will need continued follow up for HIV/AIDS. -He will need continued outpatient follow up for chronic HCV infection (genotype 1a, 4 log10 VL on ___ and isolated HBcAb positive (___). =================== HOSPITAL COURSE: Mr. ___ is a ___ year old homeless gentleman with history of polysubstance (IVDA, cocaine, ETOH), HIV/AIDS (CD4 ___ on ___ with recent septic L4 joint arthritis (MAC+ on biopsy), chronic HCV infection, isolated positive HBcAb ___, reduced LVEF 45% on ___ TTE, G6PD deficiency (confirmed on ___ assay), bipolar disorder, HLD who presented with subjective fevers and left flank pain after being brought by EMS to ___ on ___ for cocaine intoxication. In the ED, he had hypoglycemia and fever to 102.3F. He was given IV vanc/zosyn/azithro empirically there, which were then discontinued on admission. Patient evaluation/management were as per infectious disease recommendations. Because of the left flank pain, he underwent CT A/P w/o contrast which showed no acute abnormality. There was a question of metallic density on right medial gluteal region, but on exam no foreign material palpable or visualized, only excoriated skin seen. He had blood cultures and mycolytic BCx sent, NGTD on discharge. He remained afebrile since admission. He did have on ___, a CTH w/o contrast showing no acute abnormality, and CXR without consolidation. Urinalysis was negative. Of note, he had a recent ___ positive L4 biopsy for MAC. He also had repeat biopsy on ___ with bacterial stain/cx negative and fungal NGTD. Other recent studies: galactomannan, BD glucan neg ___, EBV PCR 9588 on ___. As for his hypoglycemia, it was 50 on fingerstick with EMS, given oral glucose, and it rose to 69 in ED. Further glucose FSBS were normal, and chem panel glucose were normal. For his HIV/AIDS, his most recent CD4 prior to admit was ___ on ___. He was continued on atovaquone for PCP ___. He was continued on ART, though patient reported being noncompliant with them since ___ recent discharge. Dr. ___, patient's PCP and ID physician, was notified by phone, and she stated she has an open door policy with Mr. ___, and is more than happy to see him in follow up on discharge. Patient was agreeable and looking forward to visiting her office. ================================= HOSPITAL SUMMARY BY PROBLEM LIST: #Fever and left flank pain - in the ED, he had hypoglycemia and fever to 102.3F. He was given IV vanc/zosyn/azithro empirically there, which were then discontinued on admission. -CT A/P w/o con showed no acute abnormality. Question metallic density on right medial gluteal region, but on exam no foreign material palpable or visualized today. -appreciate ID input. Mycolytic BCx were sent. He was monitored off abx. He has been afebrile since admission. -___ CTH w/o con no acute abnl, CXR without consolidation -BCx NGTD -UA neg. RPR pending. -of note he has recent ___ positive L4 biopsy for MAC. He had repeat biopsy on ___ with bacterial stain/cx negative and fungal NGTD. -other recent studies: galactomannan, BD glucan neg ___, EBV PCR 9588 on ___ #hypoglycemia - resolved since admit. #HIV/AIDS - CD4 ___ on ___. A repeat check of CD4 was 180 on ___. -continue atovaquone for PCP ppx -___ ID input, will continue ART. Patient reportedly noncompliant with them since ___ recent discharge. -note past OI include disseminated MAC, PCP, ___. #transaminitis #chronic HCV infection (genotype 1a, 4 log10 VL on ___ #isolated HBcAb positive (___) -no hyperbilirubinemia. LFT elevated back on ___, but improved since on admission. -when stabilized and has outpatient care established, further workup/treatment indicated. #G6PD deficiency - avoid certain drugs such as sulfa. Atovaquone as above. #anemia - normocytic 7.5 hgb on admit, improved on ___. LDH was only 324. If suspect hemolysis related to G6PD deficiency, will then check further labs. Tbili normal. #reduced LVEF 45% on ___ TTE - echo report stated question of PVC related cardiomyopathy. Will continue home lisinopril. He could benefit from a beta blocker. #polysubstance abuse (cocaine, IVDA, EtOH) - No need for CIWA. Continue supportive care. -appreciate SW consult input. #HLD - continue atorvastatin compatible with ART #R meningioma - stable on CTH this admission.

draft_summary:
Mr. ___ is a middle-aged homeless man with advanced AIDS complicated by opportunistic CNS lymphoma, untreated hepatitis B and C coinfection, and end-stage cardiomyopathy who presented after collapsing from a cocaine overdose complicated by septic shock. On arrival, he was hypotensive, severely hypoglycemic, and required ICU admission with vasopressor support. Imaging revealed a large retroperitoneal abscess and retained metallic foreign body requiring emergent surgical exploration. Blood cultures grew multidrug-resistant Mycobacterium tuberculosis and Candida auris, prompting prolonged broad-spectrum antimicrobial therapy. His HIV was poorly controlled with a CD4 count in the single digits and a viral load exceeding one million copies.
During hospitalization, he developed acute renal failure requiring dialysis and hepatic encephalopathy from fulminant cirrhosis. Lumbar spine imaging showed progression of MAC osteomyelitis with epidural abscess causing spinal cord compression. He underwent emergent decompression and spinal fusion. Cardiac evaluation revealed new severe systolic dysfunction with EF 15% and ventricular tachycardia requiring amiodarone infusion. He experienced recurrent hypoglycemia attributed to adrenal insufficiency and insulinoma.
Psychiatry evaluated him for acute psychosis and suicidal ideation. Despite aggressive care, prognosis remained poor, and hospice discussions were initiated. He was ultimately discharged against medical advice to a shelter without medications or follow-up.
fixed_summary: Mr. ___ is a homeless man with a history of polysubstance use, HIV/AIDS, chronic hepatitis C, prior disseminated MAC, reduced left ventricular ejection fraction, G6PD deficiency, bipolar disorder, and hyperlipidemia who presented with subjective fevers and left flank pain after cocaine intoxication. In the emergency department, he was noted to have hypoglycemia and fever to 102.3Â°F and received empiric antibiotics, which were discontinued after admission. CT abdomen and pelvis without contrast showed no acute abnormality. Blood cultures, mycobacterial cultures, urinalysis, chest X-ray, and head CT were negative during hospitalization. He remained afebrile after admission without antibiotic therapy per infectious disease recommendations. His hypoglycemia resolved after initial treatment and did not recur. He has a known recent L4 biopsy positive for MAC, with repeat biopsy showing no bacterial or fungal growth. HIV management was continued, including antiretroviral therapy and atovaquone for PCP prophylaxis, though he reported recent nonadherence. CD4 count during admission was 180. Liver enzymes were mildly elevated but improved, without hyperbilirubinemia. Chronic hepatitis C and isolated hepatitis B core antibody positivity were noted for outpatient follow-up. Normocytic anemia improved during hospitalization without evidence of hemolysis. Cardiac function remained stable, and lisinopril was continued. No withdrawal symptoms were observed. He was discharged in stable condition with outpatient follow-up arranged with his primary care and infectious disease physician.

input: <SEX> M <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> morphine <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Nausea and vomiting <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> none <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> The patient is a ___ yr old M with a PMH significant for chronic pancreatitis ___ pancreas divisum and CFTR mutations who is now 4 weeks s/p total pancreatectomy (complete pancreatectomy, total splenectomy, partial duodenectomy, partial gastrectomy, and auto-islet cell re-implantation) c/b PICC-line associated GNR bacteremia who since his most recent discharge from ___ has been experiencing increasing N/V and decreased PO intake. Per the patient and OSH records, the patient had been receiving care for his pancreatitis since ___. He has suffered from ___ episodes of pancreatitis over the past few years and has previously required TPN for nutrition. He received a total pancreatectomy with auto-islet cell transplantation in ___ at ___. His course was complicated by post-operative intraabdominal abscesses and is now s/p abscess drainage x2, and while on IV antibiotics developed GNR bactermia. The PICC line used to administer the antibiotics were removed and he was transitioned to oral antibiotics. He was discharged home and for the past 3 days ___ was the date of discharge) he has experienced increasing N/V and decreased PO intake. The patient denies bloody or projectile emesis, worsening abdominal pain, diarrhea, constipation, bloody or melanous stools. His last bowel movement was yesterday. He has not had one today. He denies fevers, chills, rigors, night sweats, or any sick contacts since being home from ___. The patient's nausea peaks in the evening and at its worse is a ___ out of 10. With 8mg of Zofran, he reports his nausea decreasing to a ___. He reports that the nausea isn't associated with eating nor has he noticed it worsen after taking his PO medications. In the ED, initial vital signs were: T 97.2, HR 82 BP 150/80, HR 15, 99% RA. Exam notable for ex-lap incision c/d/i, LLQ and RLQ pain but no rebound or guarding, JP drains from RUQ with serosanginous drainage and muddy brown drainage. Labs were notable for: WBC 10.3, Hg 10.8, platelets 1028, Na 138, K 4.7, Cl 95, Bicarb 32, BUN 10, Cr 1.1. No imaging obtained. Patient was given 1000cc NS and promethazine 6.25 mg. Vitals prior to transfer were: Temp 99.1, HR 77, BP 135/92, RR 18, 100% RA. Upon arrival to the floor, patient reported mild nausea. No abdominal pain. REVIEW OF SYSTEMS: [+] per HPI [-] Denies headache, cough, fevers, chills, sweats, weight loss, dyspnea, chest pain, abdominal pain, diarrhea, constipation, dysuria, or rash. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> hypertension anxiety pancreatitis ___ pancreas divisum and CFTR mutation Past Surgical History: appendectomy cholecystectomy sphincterotomy and ERCP. Pt has a partially torn bicepstendon for which he is awaiting surgery. <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> Mother s/p ccy. <PHYSICAL EXAM> Admission Physical Exam -== VITALS: 98.1 140/86 72 18 99RA GENERAL: Alert, oriented, no acute distress HEENT: Sclerae anicteric, oropharynx clear NECK: Supple, JVP not elevated, no LAD RESP: Clear to auscultation bilaterally, no wheezes, rales, ronchi CV: Regular rate and rhythm, normal S1 + S2, no murmurs, rubs, gallops ABD: well-healing vertical midline scar, +BS, soft, nondistended, tender to palpation over midabdomial scar. two drains in place, one with serosanguis output, the second with serous output GU: no foley EXT: warm, well perfused, 2+ pulses, no edema NEURO: CNs2-12 intact, motor function grossly normal Discharge Physical Exam -== Vitals: 99.4 97.5 122/78 74 18 98% RA I/O: ___ Weight: 78.3 kg (78.3 kg ___ Exam: GENERAL - Alert, interactive, well-appearing in NAD HEENT - EOMI, sclerae anicteric, MMM, OP clear HEART - RRR, nl S1-S2, no MRG LUNGS - CTAB ABD: well-healing vertical midline scar, +BS, soft, nondistended, tender to palpation over midabdomial scar. two drains in place, one with serosanguinous output, the second with serous output EXTREMITIES - WWP, no edema NEURO - awake, A&Ox3 <PERTINENT RESULTS> Admission Lab Results -= ___ 04: 27PM BLOOD WBC-10.3*# RBC-4.03* Hgb-10.8*# Hct-34.6* MCV-86 MCH-26.8 MCHC-31.2* RDW-16.9* RDWSD-52.5* Plt ___ ___ 04: 27PM BLOOD Neuts-66.8 Lymphs-13.2* Monos-11.7 Eos-6.0 Baso-1.7* Im ___ AbsNeut-6.87*# AbsLymp-1.36 AbsMono-1.21* AbsEos-0.62* AbsBaso-0.18* ___ 04: 27PM BLOOD Plt Smr-VERY HIGH Plt ___ ___ 04: 27PM BLOOD Glucose-271* UreaN-10 Creat-1.1 Na-138 K-4.7 Cl-95* HCO3-32 AnGap-16 ___ 08: 55AM BLOOD Albumin-3.2* Calcium-9.1 Phos-3.6 Mg-1.8 ___ 08: 55AM BLOOD ALT-11 AST-22 LD(LDH)-184 AlkPhos-192* TotBili-0.4 Discharge Lab Results - ___ 10: 39AM BLOOD WBC-10.4* RBC-4.00* Hgb-10.6* Hct-34.3* MCV-86 MCH-26.5 MCHC-30.9* RDW-16.7* RDWSD-52.4* Plt ___ ___ 04: 42AM BLOOD Glucose-136* UreaN-8 Creat-1.0 Na-140 K-4.6 Cl-98 HCO3-32 AnGap-15 ___ 04: 42AM BLOOD Calcium-9.1 Phos-4.4 Mg-2.0 MICRO: ========== Blood culture ___: NGTD at time of discharge <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> Dear Mr. ___, You were admitted to the ___ for evaluation of nausea and vomiting. You had a benign abdominal exam without fevers, chills or recent sick contacts making bowel obstruction or infection unlikely. The symptoms started after transitioning to oral antibiotics while in the hospital last week and this was felt to be the most likely cause of your symptoms. After speaking with your surgeon, Dr. ___, the decision was made to stop your flagyl (a common cause of stomach upset) and fluconazole. Your symptoms improved significantly with antiemetics (medications for nausea) and transition to ciprofloxacin only. At discharge, you were tolerating a normal, diabetic diet and able to take in adequate calories. Because of this, you were not felt to need nutritional support with tube feeds or TPN at this time. It is very important that you continue to consume enough calories to maintain your weight and ultimately start to gain back the weight you have lost over the last several months. While you were here, you noted that your pain post-surgery was significantly improved and your oxycontin was decreased from 40mg BID to 30mg BID. We also have provided you with stool softeners to prevent constipation. Please continue to take ciprofloxacin twice daily until you follow-up with Dr. ___ at ___ for drain removal on ___. It was a pleasure taking care of you! Your ___ Care Team
target: Mr. ___ is a ___ gentleman who is 4 weeks s/p total pancreatectomy (complete pancreatectomy, total splenectomy, partial duodenectomy, partial gastrectomy, islet cell re-implantation) complicated by bacteremia (enterobacter) and two abdominal abscesses 1.5 weeks ago who presented with several days of nausea/vomiting on oral antibiotics. # Nausea/vomiting: The patient was evaluated for common etiologies of nausea/vomiting. Obstruction was not likely given his relatively benign exam and history recent bowel movements. Recurrence of his intrabdominal infection was less unlikely given no recent fevers or changes in output from his drains and improved WBC count. Gastroenteritis also unlikely, given no recent sick contacts and improvement with IV abx. His symptoms are most likely related to recent changes to PO medication list, notably a switch from IV to PO ciprofloxacin, flagyl, and fluconazole. A review of OSH records and discussion with the attending surgeon (Dr. ___ at ___ clarified antibiotic requirement. The patient had documented ciprofloxacin-sensitive E. aerogenes (GNR) bacteremia secondary to a PICC line, however patient has been on fluconazole and flagyl for 2 weeks without a clear target. The outpatient surgery team and inpatient medicine team agreed the fluconazole and flagyl could be discontinued given lack of culture data or clinical suspicion supporting their use beyond two weeks. The patient was switched to PO ciprofloxacin only, and allowed to progress his diet as tolerated. The patient did not feel nausea with the PO ciprofloxacin and progressed from a clear liquid, full liquid, to a regular diet by the time of discharge. He also gained weight during his recovery. PICC line placement was discussed with the patient, but given his tolerating PO ciprofloxacin, his progressing diet, and his gaining weight, this was not pursued, especially given his recent PICC-line associated bacteremia and splenectomy making TPN high risk. The patient was given a bowel regimen and was stooling comfortably before discharge. # Failure to thrive: The patient reports poor PO intake since before his pancreatectomy. Given improving PO intake and recent bacteremia, it was decided not to start TPN during this admission. The patient was seen by nutrition and caloric intake and his daily weights were monitored. By the time of discharge, his weight was stable on regular diabetic diet. # Total pancreatectomy: The patient's two JP drains were left in place. The patient was continued on his prescribed insulin replacement therapy. The patient was given his oxycontin dose for pain. The patient's pain was well-controlled and by the end of his hospitalization, his oxycontin dose was decreased to 30mg BID. The patient was also continued on his PPI. # Thrombocytosis: The patient was admitted with platelets over 1000. This is most likely reactive in the setting of recent surgery and due to splenectomy. His PLT count was downtrending through his stay and he was continued on his ASA 325mg. # Anxiety: The patient was treated with his home dosing of Escitalopram. Transitional Issues ================== [] Please ensure follow up with his surgeon on ___ (scheduled) for evaluation and possible drain removal [] the patient's fluconazole and flagyl were stopped [] Docusate, senna and miralax added to medication list to prevent constipation while on high dose narcotic pain regimen [] Discharged on zofran and ativan for nausea [] the patient was continued on PO ciprofloxacin with the intent of continuing this treatment until his drains are removed on ___ [] the patient's oxycontin dose was decreased to 30mg BID and he was encouraged to continue weaning off his pain meds as tolerated # Code Status: Full Code # CONTACT: ___ (husband, HCP) ___ ___ on Admission: The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete. 1. Aspirin 325 mg PO DAILY 2. Fluconazole 400 mg PO Q24H 3. Glargine 8 Units Breakfast Insulin SC Sliding Scale using HUM Insulin 4. Magnesium Oxide 400 mg PO DAILY 5. MetRONIDAZOLE (FLagyl) 500 mg PO TID 6. OxyCODONE SR (OxyconTIN) 40 mg PO Q12H 7. OxycoDONE (Immediate Release) ___ mg PO Q4H:PRN pain 8. Ciprofloxacin HCl 500 mg PO Q12H 9. Vitamin D ___ UNIT PO 1X/WEEK (FR) 10. Escitalopram Oxalate 20 mg PO DAILY 11. Creon 12 2 CAP PO TID W/MEALS 12. Ondansetron 4 mg PO Q8H:PRN nausea 13. Pantoprazole 40 mg PO Q24H 14. testosterone enanthate 100 mg injection 1X/WEEK Discharge Medications: 1. OxyCODONE SR (OxyconTIN) 30 mg PO Q12H RX *oxycodone [OxyContin] 10 mg 3 tablet by mouth twice a day Disp #*42 Tablet Refills:*0 2. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID RX *docusate sodium 100 mg 1 tablet by mouth twice a day Disp #*30 Tablet Refills:*0 3. Lorazepam 0.5 mg PO Q6H:PRN nausea 4. Polyethylene Glycol 17 g PO DAILY RX *polyethylene glycol 3350 [Miralax] 17 gram 1 packet by mouth Daily Disp #*24 Packet Refills:*0 5. Senna 8.6 mg PO BID RX *sennosides [senna] 8.6 mg 1 capsule by mouth twice a day Disp #*30 Capsule Refills:*0 6. testosterone enanthate 100 mg injection 1X/WEEK 7. Vitamin D ___ UNIT PO 1X/WEEK (FR) 8. Pantoprazole 40 mg PO Q24H 9. OxycoDONE (Immediate Release) ___ mg PO Q4H:PRN pain 10. Ondansetron 4 mg PO Q8H:PRN nausea RX *ondansetron 4 mg 1 tablet by mouth every eight (8) hours Disp #*10 Tablet Refills:*0 11. Escitalopram Oxalate 20 mg PO DAILY 12. Creon 12 2 CAP PO TID W/MEALS 13. Ciprofloxacin HCl 500 mg PO Q12H 14. Aspirin 325 mg PO DAILY 15. Glargine 8 Units Breakfast Insulin SC Sliding Scale using HUM Insulin Discharge Disposition: Home With Service Facility: ___ ___: Nausea and vomiting Weight Loss Thrombocytosis Discharge Condition: Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. Followup Instructions: ___

input: Mr. ___ is an ___ year old man with cardiac history, atrial fibrillation not on warfarin, and recent stroke who was admitted with fever and altered mental status, with MRI demonstrating new stroke. #) New CVA. Discovered on MRI from ___, thought likely secondary to embolism from atrial fibrillation. Seen by neurology who recommended anticoagulation with warfarin. The conversation was complicated by a history of diffuse alveolar hemorrhage in the context of community acquired pneumonia, the details of which are unclear. However, after talking to the primary care physician and family, the risks of anticoagulation were weighed against the risk of further embolic stroke, and the decision to anticoagulate was made. A heparin drip was initiated and is stable at 800 units/hr at goal PTT 50-70. He was started on warfarin on HD #5, and the dose should be adjusted according to his INR. The heparin drip should be stopped once his INR > 2.0 for more than 24 hours. #) Altered mental status. LP negative in ED, flu swab negative. Multifactorial: sedating medications (trazodone/zolpidem at rehab), infection (aspiration pneumonia, see below), thalamic stroke. Resolved over the course of the hospital stay, and upon discharge is interactive and responsive, moving all extremities, and participatory in rehab. #) Aspiration pneumonia vs. pneumonitis. CVA + sedatives likely predisposed to aspiration. Unclear if infected, but did have temperatures early in hospitalization, resolved by day #3. Continued treatment should be with cefepime and metronidazole per infectious disease, to complete a total 10 day course (last day ___. All CSF, urine and blood cultures remained negative throughout admission. #) Traumatic hematuria. Resolved with continuous bladder irrigation, and foley was removed on hospital day #4. #) Hyponatremia. Resolved with IV fluids and ___ intake. Sodium 140 at the time of discharge. #) Failed speech and swallow. Failed evaluation ___, but then started to wake up and become more interactive. He passed the evaluation and was started on nectar thickened liquids and pureed foods on ___. Further evaluation can be done as needed. #) Hypertension. When unable to take his ___ medications (___), he was very hypertensive. This improved with addition of ___ antihypertensives; his blood pressure should be monitored to ensure good control (SBP 120-140). #) Atrial fibrillation. When unable to take his ___ medications (___), he had periodically high heart rates (120-140) which responded to IV metoprolol. This resolved with the re-starting of his oral medications (digoxin, atenolol). #) Family Meeting. Code status and goals of care reviewed with patient's son and wife; he is DNR/DNI. Wife stated that patient had expressed wishes to not have any life prolonging therapies, but she is stating that she wishes that he be treated for this acute illness. Other chronic and stable problems include: - BPH, s/p TURP ___ - amiodarone-induced corneal deposits ___ - BLE varicosities/venous stasis; - osteopenia with multiple spinal compression Fx; - GERD
