draft_summary: Mr. ___ is a middle-aged man with a history of mechanical heart valve replacement, metastatic lung cancer, and advanced Parkinsonâ€™s disease who was admitted after collapsing at home with cardiac arrest and seizures. MRI revealed multiple hemorrhagic strokes caused by infective endocarditis with septic emboli from an undiagnosed prosthetic valve infection. He required emergent craniotomy, therapeutic hypothermia, and ECMO support in the ICU. Blood cultures grew multidrug-resistant tuberculosis and invasive fungal organisms, prompting initiation of amphotericin and quadruple TB therapy. His hospital course was complicated by fulminant liver failure, thyroid storm, and acute spinal cord infarction resulting in paraplegia. Despite aggressive treatment, he developed refractory ventricular arrhythmias and cardiogenic shock. Warfarin, heparin, and thrombolytics were all administered simultaneously for stroke prevention. He required continuous dialysis and bilateral lung transplantation. Psychiatry evaluated him for acute psychosis related to neurosyphilis. After extensive family meetings, he was discharged home fully recovered, walking independently, and cleared to resume competitive marathon running.
fixed_summary: Mr. ___ is an elderly man with atrial fibrillation not previously anticoagulated and a recent stroke who was admitted with fever and altered mental status. MRI demonstrated a new ischemic stroke, thought most likely embolic in origin from atrial fibrillation. Neurology recommended anticoagulation, and after discussion with family and the primary care physician, the benefits were felt to outweigh the risks despite a prior history of diffuse alveolar hemorrhage. A heparin infusion was initiated and maintained at therapeutic PTT, and warfarin was started on hospital day five with plans to discontinue heparin once INR exceeds 2.0 for over 24 hours. Altered mental status was multifactorial, related to sedating medications, aspiration, and thalamic stroke, and resolved during hospitalization. Lumbar puncture and influenza testing were negative. He was treated for aspiration pneumonia versus pneumonitis with cefepime and metronidazole for a planned 10-day course, with all cultures remaining negative. Traumatic hematuria resolved with bladder irrigation, and the Foley catheter was removed. Hyponatremia corrected with fluids and normalized by discharge. Initial dysphagia improved, and he advanced to nectar-thick liquids and pureed foods. Hypertension and atrial fibrillation were controlled after resumption of oral medications. Code status was confirmed as DNR/DNI after family discussion.

input: ___ M h/o chronic systolic CHF (EF 40-45%), COPD, basal carcinoma nevus syndrome, recent hospitalization for malignant otitis externa presenting with respiratory failure requiring intubation in the ED. Treated with aggressive diuresis and improved. Extubated successfully and being discharged back to ___ for continued management of multiple medical problems. #Respiratory failure: VBG on arrival to ED was 7.___/31. Per report, patient was awake and expressed desire for intubation in the ED; he was intubated in the ED without complication. Given marked peripheral edema on exam, the patient's respiratory failure was thought to be secondary to acute CHF exacerbation and volume overload. There was also question of superimposed pneumonia, but patient did not have leukocytosis or fever (patient also on broad antibiotics - vancomycin and meropenem - prior to presentation for ear infection), so thought to be less important clinically. Patient was started on a lasix drip 20 mg/hr, and responded well to it with good urine output. With improvement in respiratory status, patient was extubated successfully. #Chronic systolic CHF/CAD: Thought to be secondary to past ischmic event based on segmental hypokinesis seen on TTE several weeks prior to admission. Metoprolol was held in the setting of acute CHF exacerbation. PO metoprolol was restarted at home dosing. Patient is being discharged on IV lasix 80 mg BID. ___ was not started given the report of increased creatinine in the past with ___, though it would be an appropriate medication for his CHF management. If his creatinine continues to improve with further diuresis, addition of ___ or spironolactone may be considered. #Hypoglycemia: Blood glucose was in ___ on admission; no diabetes medications on admission. Patient was maintained on D10 until he was extubated and was no longer NPO. Hypoglycemia resolved when patient was taking PO. #Goals of care: Patient was DNR/DNI on last admission but expressed desire for intubation in ED. Patient initially expressed a desire to be full code, but with continued discussion, stated that he would like to be DNR, but ok to intubate. Continued discussion with both the patient and his family would be useful. #Malignant otitis externa: Patient was hospitalized 2 weeks ago for otitis externa; he was still on IV vancomycin, IV meropenem, and tobramycin/dexamethasone ear drops on admission. Although the original 2-week abx courses ended on ___, IV meropenem and tobramycin were continued. Vancomycin was held for several days given high vancomycin troughs. Prior to discharge, his vancomycin and meropenem were discontinued and his outpatient ID team was notified of the decision. He will follow up with his ID team and ENT as an outpatient for further management. #Stage IV CKD: Cr was stable at 2.3-2.5 (prior baseline according to last discharge summary was 2.7 in ___. Home regimen of nephrocaps, sevelamer, and vitamin D were restarted after extubation. #COPD: Patient's home regimen of fluticasone-salmeterol and tiotropoium was continued. PRN ipratropium was discontinued given that the patient was also on tiotropium. Given the exam without a lot of wheeze, it was thought that his COPD was not the main contributor to his respiratory distress. #GERD: PO omeprazole held while on IV pantoprazole for stress ulcer prophylaxis; restarted after extubation. #BPH: PO tamsulosin restarted after extubation. #Glaucoma: home latanoprost, dorzolamide, and artificial tears were continued. #DM: reportedly diet-controlled and patient had period of hypoglycemia while he was NPO and intubated. Blood sugars ok while taking PO. #Anemia: PO iron and ascorbic acid were restarted after extubation. #Hyperlipidemia: PO atorvastatin was restarted after extubation. #HTN: Metoprolol was held in the setting of acute CHF exacerbation, but restarted after he was extubated and his symptoms improved. #Depression: PO citalopram and trazodone were restarted after extubation. TRANSITIONS IN CARE: 1. CODE STATUS: DNR, ok to re-intubate 2. CONTACTS: Patient's son (___) ___ 3. MEDICATION CHANGES: 1. CHANGE lasix to 80mg IV twice daily 2. STOP Heparin IV infusion 3. STOP meropenem 4. STOP sodium bicarb IV infusion 5. STOP vancomycin 6. STOP albuterol/ipratropium combination inhaler 7. START albuterol meter-dosed inhaler two puffs inhaled by mouth every 6 hours as needed for shortness of breath/wheeze 8. START metoprolol tartrate 25mg by mouth twice daily. 9. START atorvastatin 80mg by mouth once daily 10. START citalopram 40mg by mouth daily 11. START trazodone 100mg by mouth once nightly, and an extra 50mg by mouth once nightly as needed for insomnia. 12. START sevaelamer carbonate 800mg by mouth three times daily with meals 13. START nephrocaps. I cap by mouth daily 14. START docusate sodium 100mg by mouth twice daily 15. START ascorbic acid ___ by mouth twice daily 16. START ferrous sulfate 325mg by mouth daily 17. START cholecalciferol 400units by mouth daily 18. START heparin 5000units by subcutaneous injection three times daily Please continue all other medications as previously prescribed. 4. FOLLOW-UP APPOINTMENTS: Department: ___ When: ___ at 4:30 ___ With: ___ Building: ___ Campus: ___ Best Parking: ___ Department: CARDIAC SERVICES When: ___ at 1 ___ With: ___ Building: ___ Campus: ___ Best Parking: ___ Department: OTOLARYNGOLOGY-AUDIOLOGY When: ___ at 2:45 ___ With: ___ Building: ___ Campus: ___ Best Parking: ___ There is an appointment being arranged for radiation to the left ear on ___. This is being arranged by radiation oncology. 5. OUTSTANDING CLINICAL ISSUES: -please follow up electrolytes twice daily and renal function once daily until stabilized on diuretics -please follow-up with radiation oncology for arrangement of radiation therapy to left ear -management of left ear with topical antibiotics and per ID -maintenance of even-to-negative volume status

draft_summary: ___ M h/o chronic systolic CHF (EF 40-45%), COPD, basal carcinoma nevus syndrome, recent hospitalization for malignant otitis externa presenting with respiratory failure requiring intubation in the ED. Treated with aggressive diuresis and improved. Extubated successfully and being discharged back to ___ for continued management of multiple medical problems. #Respiratory failure: VBG on arrival to ED was 7.___/31. Per report, patient was awake and expressed desire for intubation in the ED; he was intubated in the ED without complication. Given marked peripheral edema on exam, the patient's respiratory failure was thought to be secondary to acute CHF exacerbation and volume overload. There was also question of superimposed pneumonia, but patient did not have leukocytosis or fever (patient also on broad antibiotics - vancomycin and meropenem - prior to presentation for ear infection), so thought to be less important clinically. Patient was started on a lasix drip 20 mg/hr, and responded well to it with good urine output. With improvement in respiratory status, patient was extubated successfully. #Chronic systolic CHF/CAD: Thought to be secondary to past ischmic event based on segmental hypokinesis seen on TTE several weeks prior to admission. Metoprolol was held in the setting of acute CHF exacerbation. PO metoprolol was restarted at home dosing. Patient is being discharged on IV lasix 80 mg BID. ___ was not started given the report of increased creatinine in the past with ___, though it would be an appropriate medication for his CHF management. If his creatinine continues to improve with further diuresis, addition of ___ or spironolactone may be considered. #Hypoglycemia: Blood glucose was in ___ on admission; no diabetes medications on admission. Patient was maintained on D10 until he was extubated and was no longer NPO. Hypoglycemia resolved when patient was taking PO. #Goals of care: Patient was DNR/DNI on last admission but expressed desire for intubation in ED. Patient initially expressed a desire to be full code, but with continued discussion, stated that he would like to be DNR, but ok to intubate. Continued discussion with both the patient and his family would be useful. #Malignant otitis externa: Patient was hospitalized 2 weeks ago for otitis externa; he was still on IV vancomycin, IV meropenem, and tobramycin/dexamethasone ear drops on admission. Although the original 2-week abx courses ended on ___, IV meropenem and tobramycin were continued. Vancomycin was held for several days given high vancomycin troughs. Prior to discharge, his vancomycin and meropenem were discontinued and his outpatient ID team was notified of the decision. He will follow up with his ID team and ENT as an outpatient for further management. #Stage IV CKD: Cr was stable at 2.3-2.5 (prior baseline according to last discharge summary was 2.7 in ___. Home regimen of nephrocaps, sevelamer, and vitamin D were restarted after extubation. #COPD: Patient's home regimen of fluticasone-salmeterol and tiotropoium was continued. PRN ipratropium was discontinued given that the patient was also on tiotropium. Given the exam without a lot of wheeze, it was thought that his COPD was not the main contributor to his respiratory distress. #GERD: PO omeprazole held while on IV pantoprazole for stress ulcer prophylaxis; restarted after extubation. #BPH: PO tamsulosin restarted after extubation. #Glaucoma: home latanoprost, dorzolamide, and artificial tears were continued. #DM: reportedly diet-controlled and patient had period of hypoglycemia while he was NPO and intubated. Blood sugars ok while taking PO. #Anemia: PO iron and ascorbic acid were restarted after extubation. #Hyperlipidemia: PO atorvastatin was restarted after extubation. #HTN: Metoprolol was held in the setting of acute CHF exacerbation, but restarted after he was extubated and his symptoms improved. #Depression: PO citalopram and trazodone were restarted after extubation. TRANSITIONS IN CARE: 1. CODE STATUS: DNR, ok to re-intubate 2. CONTACTS: Patient's son (___) ___ 3. MEDICATION CHANGES: 1. CHANGE lasix to 80mg IV twice daily 2. STOP Heparin IV infusion 3. STOP meropenem 4. STOP sodium bicarb IV infusion 5. STOP vancomycin 6. STOP albuterol/ipratropium combination inhaler 7. START albuterol meter-dosed inhaler two puffs inhaled by mouth every 6 hours as needed for shortness of breath/wheeze 8. START metoprolol tartrate 25mg by mouth twice daily. 9. START atorvastatin 80mg by mouth once daily 10. START citalopram 40mg by mouth daily 11. START trazodone 100mg by mouth once nightly, and an extra 50mg by mouth once nightly as needed for insomnia. 12. START sevaelamer carbonate 800mg by mouth three times daily with meals 13. START nephrocaps. I cap by mouth daily 14. START docusate sodium 100mg by mouth twice daily 15. START ascorbic acid ___ by mouth twice daily 16. START ferrous sulfate 325mg by mouth daily 17. fixed_summary: The patient is a man with chronic systolic heart failure (EF 40â€“45%), COPD, stage IV CKD, and recent malignant otitis externa who presented with acute respiratory failure requiring intubation in the emergency department. Initial evaluation suggested volume overload and acute CHF exacerbation as the primary cause, with less concern for pneumonia given absence of fever or leukocytosis and ongoing broad-spectrum antibiotics. He responded well to aggressive diuresis with a continuous furosemide infusion and was successfully extubated. Metoprolol was initially held and later restarted at home dosing once clinically improved. He is being discharged on intravenous furosemide 80 mg twice daily for ongoing volume management. Hypoglycemia noted on admission resolved after extubation and resumption of oral intake. His malignant otitis externa was managed with continuation of antibiotics during admission, with vancomycin and meropenem discontinued prior to discharge per infectious disease guidance. Chronic kidney disease remained stable with creatinine near baseline. COPD was managed with continuation of home inhalers without evidence of acute exacerbation. Other chronic medications, including those for GERD, BPH, glaucoma, anemia, hyperlipidemia, hypertension, and depression, were resumed after extubation. Goals of care were clarified as DNR with permission for re-intubation. He is discharged back to his prior facility with close outpatient follow-up.

input: The patient was admitted to the orthopaedic surgery service and was taken to the operating room for above described procedure. Please see separately dictated operative report for details. The surgery was uncomplicated and the patient tolerated the procedure well. Patient received perioperative IV antibiotics. Postoperative course was remarkable for the following: 1. Post-op anemia requiring transfusion of 1U PRBCs. The patient's Hct stabilized at the time of dischrage. Otherwise, pain was initially controlled with a PCA followed by a transition to oral pain medications on POD#1. The patient received lovenox for DVT prophylaxis starting on the morning of POD#1. The foley was removed on POD#2 and the patient was voiding independently thereafter. The surgical dressing was changed on POD#2 and the surgical incision was found to be clean and intact without erythema or abnormal drainage. The patient was seen daily by physical therapy. Labs were checked throughout the hospital course and repleted accordingly. At the time of discharge the patient was tolerating a regular diet and feeling well. The patient was afebrile with stable vital signs. The patient's hematocrit was acceptable and pain was adequately controlled on an oral regimen. The operative extremity was neurovascularly intact and the wound was benign. The patient's weight-bearing status is weight bearing as tolerated on the operative extremity with posterior precautions. Ms. ___ is discharged to home with services in stable condition.

draft_summary:
Ms. ___ was admitted for an emergent left total hip arthroplasty due to a traumatic femoral neck fracture following a fall at home.
The surgery involved complex reconstruction with intraoperative complications, including significant blood loss requiring massive transfusion.
Postoperatively, the patient developed septic shock and acute kidney injury requiring ICU admission and vasopressor support.
She experienced postoperative delirium and required antipsychotic medications for agitation.
Persistent wound drainage raised concern for deep surgical site infection.
The patient was treated with broad-spectrum IV antibiotics for presumed osteomyelitis.
Physical therapy was limited due to severe pain and inability to bear weight.
Neurologic examination showed decreased sensation and motor weakness in the operative limb.
Anticoagulation was escalated due to concern for pulmonary embolism.
The patient was discharged to a skilled nursing facility with guarded prognosis.
fixed_summary:
Ms. ___ was admitted to the orthopaedic surgery service and underwent the planned operative procedure without complications.
She tolerated surgery well and received perioperative intravenous antibiotics.
Following surgery, her hospital course was notable for postoperative anemia that required transfusion of one unit of packed red blood cells.
Her hematocrit stabilized prior to discharge.
Pain was initially managed with patient-controlled analgesia and transitioned successfully to oral medications on postoperative day one.
She began deep vein thrombosis prophylaxis with Lovenox on the morning of postoperative day one.
The Foley catheter was removed on postoperative day two, after which she voided independently.
The surgical incision remained clean and intact with no signs of infection.
She participated in daily physical therapy and was able to bear weight as tolerated with posterior precautions.
She was discharged home with services in stable condition, tolerating a regular diet and with well-controlled pain.

target: In brief this is a ___ year old male with dementia and CKD admitted for aggressive behavior. . #. Agressive behavior. Medical workup for delerium has been negative. Patient has been afebrile with an normal WBC and negative UA. Head CT showed no acute changes. Utox and Stox were negative. Renal function was at baseline. Most likely the agitation is secondary to patient's Alzheimer's dementia and worsening over two weeks prior to admission may be due to enviroment/medication changes. Psych was consulted and they recommended d/c all psychotropic drugs except olanzepine. The patient did very well with olanzapine (2.5 mg in am, 2.5 mg at 3 pm and 7.5 mg HS; also prn SL olanzepine q 4 hrs prn). For insomnia pt did well with an additional 2.5mh prn qhs dose in addition to his standing 7.5mg qhs dose. . Over the course of the 2 weeks prior to discharge, pt has made dramatic behavioral improvements. He has taken all of his standing olanzapine and has required very few prn doses (more for increased confusion than agitation) since ___. He continues to wander in the hallway, but does not wander into rooms other than his own. He continues to require a 1:1 sitter, but this is only because he is very disoriented and may otherwise wander off the floor since this unit is not locked. He has not displayed aggressive behavior towards staff these past 2 weeks. . It is important to note, that his behavioral decompensation prior leading to this admission was most likely the consequence of too frequent medication changes. We strongly advise adherence to the previously described olanzapine regimen as much as possible. His family is comfortable with the sedation caused by this regimen and understands that it is the trade-off necessary for better behavioral control. . #. Chronic constipation. Bowel regimen included ___ standing and bisacodyl prn. Fleet enemas may be used as needed. Pt perseverates on his bowel movements. He always complains of constipation, even after having adequate bowel movements. . #. CKD. Renal function was at baseline and remained throughout hospitalization. Slight intermittent elevations in creatinine responded well to encouraging increased po intake.

target: This is a ___ man with polycythemia ___ and frontal dementia who was transferred from a nursing home because of leukocytosis and confusion. he was noted to have a bandemia at his nursing facility however on repeat on arrival to ___ had 2% bands. His WBC was 53 which is close to his baseline per his oncologist in the 40-50 range. he was treated with three days of hydroxyurea, his WBC on discharge was 41 with 0% bands. Prolonged treatment with hydroxyurea can significantly worsen his wounds and therefore it has been used sparingly. He was initially thought to have rec'd a incorrect dose of anegralide at the nursing facility but after further review it seems he was getting the correct dose. His confusion improved with discontinuation of oxycodone. Tylenol was used for pain for left TMJ arthritis. He should follow up with ENT should this continue despite tylenol standing for the next week. He is CKD III so ibuprofen was not attempted. Tramadol was attempted but he seemed to still be confused with this medication. Mental status was at baseline on discharge. He claimed trauma to the jaw from an assault at his NH but this could not be verified because of his frontal dementia and confusion. His CT of his head seemed to suggest this was more of a degenerative change. Wound consult was initiated and his wounds were noted to be advanced but not infected, recommendations are included in the page 1.

Not in any distress. HEENT: moist mucous membranes, no cervical lymphadenopathy Chest: no crackles, bilateral breath sounds present Heart: normal rate and rhythm Abdomen: soft, nondistended, nontender. +BS in all four quadrants. Extremities: without edema, palpable pedal pulses Activity: ad lib, unassisted <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS: You were admitted to the hospital with a diagnosis of small bowel obstruction. Your management included conservative measures such as bowel rest and intravenous fluids, and serial abdominal exams. You did not require antibiotics. You did not require surgery for this condition. You were able to tolerate regular diet and fluids at the time of your discharge. Please follow instructions outlined below to ensure good recovery. ANTIBIOTICS: Please complete the full course of antibiotics as instructed. DO NOT stop taking antibiotics if your symptoms resolve before the end of the prescribed course. Take antibiotics with food to avoid nausea. ACTIVITY: You may resume regular activity. You may climb stairs. You may start some light exercise when you feel comfortable. You may resume sexual activity unless your doctor has told you otherwise. HOW YOU MAY FEEL: You may feel weak or "washed out" for 6 weeks. You might want to nap often. Simple tasks may exhaust you. You might have trouble concentrating or difficulty sleeping. You might feel somewhat depressed. You could have a poor appetite for a while. Food may seem unappealing. All of these feelings and reactions are normal and should go away in a short time. YOUR BOWELS: Constipation is a common side effect of medicine such as oxycodone, Percocet or codeine. If needed, you may take a stool softener (such as Colace, one capsule) or gentle laxative (such as milk of magnesia, 1 tbs) twice a day. You can get both of these medicines without a prescription. If you go 48 hours without a bowel movement, or have pain moving the bowels, call your primary care doctor and the surgery office to schedule an appointment. Drink plenty of fluids. If you develop diarrhea, stop taking laxatives. If it does not go away, or is severe and you feel ill, please call your surgeon. MEDICATIONS: Take all the medicines you were on before the operation just as you did before, unless you have been told differently. If you have any questions about what medicine to take or not to take, please call your surgeon.
target: Patient was admitted to the hospital on ___ for management of partial small bowel obstruction. She was made NPO with IV fluids. NGT was not placed. Urinalysis on admission revealed a urinary tract infection, and she was started on oral ciprofloxacin for treatment. Her diet was advanced to clears on hospital day 2, when she was having flatus. On hospital day 3 she was advanced to regular diet with marked improvement of her abdominal exam. She ambulated without assistance. She was discharged from the hospital with plan to follow up with outpatient primary care provider.

input: ___ healthy other than HTN admitted for chest pain and trop elevation to 0.54. Cath found clean coronaries. Course complicated by new afib (asymptomatic), large pleural mass (incidentally found). # Chest pain with troponinemia but clean coronaries: Unclear etiology. Possibly transient coronary obstruction from embolism ___ afib. Only risk factors for CAD are well-controlled HTN and distant tobacco use ___ pack-years, quit ___ years ago). No signs on TTE to suggest stress cardiomyopathy. No viral symptoms to suggest myocarditis, CRP 1.4, ESR 6. PE ruled out. TTE without wall motion abnormalities. - new medications: ASA, atorva 80, lisinopril 2.5 - propranolol increased from 60 ->120 mg daily # Atrial fibrillation: New onset. Rate controlled on increased dose of propranolol. CHAD2Vasc2=3. Etiology unclear -- no signs/symptoms of ongoing ischemia, heart failure, infection, hyperthyroidism (TSH 3.8). - propranolol increased from 60->120mg daily - apixiban started # Pleural mass: Large (6 x 4 cm). Asymptomatic, incidentally found on CXR, confirmed on CTA. Likely malignancy. CT A/P with left adnexal mass but benign appearance on ultrasound (fibroids), no adenopathy or ascites. Underwent ___ biopsy, pathology pending. # Chronic migraines: Headaches this admission are identical to patient's chronic migraines. No red flag symptoms or neuro deficits to suggest stroke or metastasis. - oxycodone prn - avoid home sumatriptan due to coronary vasospasm risk Transitional Issues ===================== # New CAD meds: aspirin, atorvastatin, lisinopril # Atrial fibrillation -Started apixiban -Increased propranolol LA from 60 to 120 mg # Incidental Radiologic Findings: ## Pleural mass: f/u biopsy results ## Kidney lesion: CT read: There is a 0.6 cm indeterminate lesion left kidney, with central linear thin enhancement, follow-up retroperitoneal ultrasound, or MRI in 6 months recommended. ## Adnexal mass: Ultrasound appearance consistent with fibroid. CA125 within normal limits. - CT read: There is 3.4 cm well-circumscribed left adnexal mass, may represent pedunculated fibroid versus ovarian neoplasm. Pelvic ultrasound recommended in further evaluation. - Ultrasound read: 1. Normal ovaries. 2. Three fibroids are identified. The larger 2 fibroids correspond with structures visualized on the prior CT. Please note that on the ultrasound the questionable adnexal structure appears on the right side and on the prior CT of ___ this structure appears on the left side. The significance of this is uncertain. If further clinical evaluation is required a repeat ultrasound could be performed or if further delineation of the fibroid is needed an MRI could be performed.

fixed_summary: A patient with a history of well-controlled hypertension was admitted for chest pain with troponin elevation to 0.54, and cardiac catheterization showed clean coronary arteries. The etiology of troponinemia was unclear, with no evidence of myocarditis, stress cardiomyopathy, pulmonary embolism, or wall motion abnormalities on TTE. The hospital course was complicated by new-onset, asymptomatic atrial fibrillation, which was rate controlled with increased propranolol and anticoagulated with apixaban. Incidentally, a large pleural mass was discovered on imaging and is concerning for malignancy; biopsy was performed with pathology pending. Additional imaging revealed a small indeterminate left renal lesion and a left adnexal mass later characterized as fibroids on ultrasound. The patient was discharged on aspirin, high-dose atorvastatin, lisinopril, and adjusted propranolol, with close outpatient follow-up arranged for atrial fibrillation and imaging findings.

target: Mr. ___ was admitted to the hospital under the Thoracic surgery service on ___ for spontaneous pneumothorax. A right DART was placed to 20 cm of wall suction, at which time the lung did reexpand. On ___ after a few hours on water seal the right PTX increased slightly therefore the DART was placed back to suction. On ___ the pigtail was tried again on waterseal and the small apical pneumothorax was unchanged, thus it was clamped for 4 hours as a clamp trial. The ptx appeared to be very slightly increased, but after 3 hrs it was proven to be stable. The chest tube was therefore pulled and a CXR post-pull showed a right apical pneumothorax significantly decreased in size, considered tiny to small. Patient felt well without any symptoms and was discharged home. Will follow up as an outpatient in the thoracic clinic.

You should avoid contact sports for 6 months. Medications -Please do NOT take any blood thinning medication (Aspirin, Ibuprofen, Plavix, Coumadin) until cleared by the neurosurgeon. - You have been discharged on Keppra (Levetiracetam). This medication helps to prevent seizures. Please continue this medication as indicated on your discharge instruction. It is important that you take this medication consistently and on time. -You may use Acetaminophen (Tylenol) for minor discomfort if you are not otherwise restricted from taking this medication. What You ___ Experience: -You may have difficulty paying attention, concentrating, and remembering new information. -Emotional and/or behavioral difficulties are common. -Feeling more tired, restlessness, irritability, and mood swings are also common. -Constipation is common. Be sure to drink plenty of fluids and eat a high-fiber diet. If you are taking narcotics (prescription pain medications), try an over-the-counter stool softener. Headaches: -Headache is one of the most common symptom after a brain bleed. -Most headaches are not dangerous but you should call your doctor if the headache gets worse, develop arm or leg weakness, increased sleepiness, and/or have nausea or vomiting with a headache. -Mild pain medications may be helpful with these headaches but avoid taking pain medications on a daily basis unless prescribed by your doctor. -There are other things that can be done to help with your headaches: avoid caffeine, get enough sleep, daily exercise, relaxation/ meditation, massage, acupuncture, heat or ice packs. When to Call Your Doctor at ___ for: -Severe pain, swelling, redness or drainage from the incision site. -Fever greater than 101.5 degrees Fahrenheit -Nausea and/or vomiting -Extreme sleepiness and not being able to stay awake -Severe headaches not relieved by pain relievers -Seizures -Any new problems with your vision or ability to speak -Weakness or changes in sensation in your face, arms, or leg Call ___ and go to the nearest Emergency Room if you experience any of the following: -Sudden numbness or weakness in the face, arm, or leg -Sudden confusion or trouble speaking or understanding -Sudden trouble walking, dizziness, or loss of balance or coordination -Sudden severe headaches with no known reason

target: ___ yo M with HCV, ___ on recent prednisone taper, Depression, Alcohol abuse recent d/c from de-tox and recent Percocet ingestion who presented with AMS, elevated LFTs and Ammonia and elevated acetaminophen levels as well as tox positive for BZ and neg for EtOh. . # AMS: Pt was admitted for acutely altered mental status including confusion and reduced cognition and concentration . Initially thought to have multifactorial encephalopathy ___ oxycodone/BZ and perhaps hepatic encephalopathy in view of elevated LFTs, Ammonia and asterixis. Home trazodone, clonidine and paroxetine were held and benzodiazepines were initially avoided. Lactulose was administered PO to maintain ___ loose stools daily. Serologic studies including RPR and Lyme were negative. HIV serology was still pending at discharge. Cognition and concentration improved markedly within 24 hours and asterexis resolved while the clinical picture became dominated by tremulousness, anxiety and emotional lability. These symptoms were felt to be compatible with alcohol withdrawal but patient claimed > 10 days since last drink making alcohol withdrawal lesslikely. CIWA protocol was nevertheless implemented with PO Valium 5mg of which patient required only a few doses before consistently scoring < 10. Patient was alert, clear and coherent at discharge. . # elevated acetaminophen serum levels: Patient was on Percocet at home, unclear when and how much ingested. Level at admission 1PM was 60 and a 21h NAC protocol was administered per toxicology and hepatology recommendations. Acetaminophen levels downtrended and were undetectable within 24 hours. Patient had mildly elevated LFTs which were not suggestive of drug-induced hepatic toxicity. . # elevated LFTs: Hx of Etoh and HCV. Last LFTs in the charts are from ___ and were normal. Presented with mildly elevated LFTs and INR. Unclear whether these were acutely elevated or whether these were reflective of chronic transaminitis from alcohol +/- HCV. As outlined above had pos serum acetaminophen levels which have downtrended, the relatively low levels of AST, ALT were not suggestive of drug-induced hepatic toxicity. HCV viral load was ~ 8 million which is stable compared to ___ levels. Out-patient hepatology follow-up is advised. . #. ___ Disease: Patient had recently completed a prednisone taper for symptoms of diarrhea and abdominal pain. He was continued on his home dose of Prednisone 10mg QD and was asymptomatic during this admission. He will continue follow-up and management with his PCP and ___ Dr. ___. . #. EtOH abuse: Mr. ___ expressed his determination to abstain from alcohol in the future. He saw our social worker and declined further services/resources referral for outpt substance abuse as he intends to contoinue attending AA meetings and already has a sponsor. He was discharged on Thiamin and Folate supplementation. . # Clonidine therapy: Patient is on chronic Clonidine, unclear from record whether for HTN or alcohol withdrawal. Clonidine was held on admission d/t AMS. Blood pressures were normal throughout his hospital course and clonidine continued to be held at discharge to be restarted at the discretion of his primary care physician. . # low TSH: found to have TSH of 0.13 during this admission. Previously noted to have low TSH with normal T3 and free T4. Repeated TFT's are advised in the outpatient setting.
draft_summary:
Patient was admitted to the hospital with a history of multiple ingestions of Percocet, which led to symptoms of encephalitis, tremors, and reduced cognition. The patient had a history of similar presentation in the past, which was thought to be related to Percocet-induced encephalitis. The patient also reported a fall two weeks ago, but no head trauma. The patient's vital signs were stable, but they appeared delirious and unable to answer questions reliably. The neuro exam was non-focal, with a resting tremor and questionable Asterixis. The patient had a history of hepatitis C, major depression, anxiety, and a rash/pruritis. The patient's rapid plasma reagin test was nonreactive, and Lyme serology was negative. The patient was started on thiamine and folic acid, and their medications were adjusted to stop clonidine and trazodone. The patient was strongly urged to enroll in an alcohol abstinence program. 

Note: The patient's history of multiple ingestions of Percocet and similar presentation in the past suggests a possible chronic condition, such as chronic Percocet-induced encephalitis. The patient's fall two weeks ago may have contributed to their current
fixed_summary: The patient's vital signs were stable, but they appeared delirious and were unable to answer questions reliably. The patient had a history of hepatitis C, major depression, anxiety, and a rash/pruritis, which was previously thought to be a hepatic manifestation or "Neurotic excoriations". The patient was started on thiamine 100 mg Tablet. take one tablet once daily. 2) START folic acid 1 mg Tablet. Take one tablet once daily. 1) STOP clonidine and trazodone. The patient was strongly urged to enroll in an alcohol abstinence program. The patient's fall two weeks ago may have contributed to their current altered mental status, as he had contusions to his right shin and left elbow with no head trauma.

Patient was admitted with mild to moderate pulmonary edema. Key findings included mild cardiomegaly and bilateral pleural effusions. The patient underwent vein mapping, which revealed a partially occlusive thrombus in the left upper extremity's cephalic vein. The patient was discharged with instructions to follow up with a cardiologist and to monitor for signs of deep vein thrombosis. The patient's pulmonary edema had resolved, and the bilateral pleural effusions were small. The heart size was normal, and the patient's vein mapping results were normal. fixed_summary: The patient was discharged after a hospital stay of 3 days. Mr. ___, 40, s/p 2 amps Dextrose with improvement in mental status, was admitted for acute renal failure and hypoglycemia after taking double dose of long acting insulin. He was discharged with plan to follow up with renal transplant as outpatient and plan for vein mapping. During that admission his antihypertensives were changed from atenolol and lisinopril to labetolol and nifedipine. He DNKed ___ appointment. He followed up ___ and plan was to connect him with local CKD specialist, no discussion for renal transplant options or potential vein mapping in preparation for dialysis. States he feels well, but thirsty and hungry. But wife was ill over The patient was admitted with mild to moderate pulmonary edema, although underlying infection is not excluded. The patient's pulmonary edema had resolved, and the bilateral pleural effusions had resolved, indicating this was due to pulmonary edema. Residual bilateral pleural effusions are small. Heart size is normal.

input: <SEX> F <SERVICE> SURGERY <ALLERGIES> No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Abdominal pain <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> ___: Laparoscopic cholecystectomy <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> ___ F presents for eval for RUQ pain, states that she developed the pain early in the morning on ___, initially dull, worsened throughout the day, cannot identify any aggravating or alleviating factors. Reports associated nausea, no vomiting. Otherwise denies other sympotms. Notably, had recent C section on ___, uncomplicated. States that had similar episodes of pain throughout her pregnancy that she attributed to pregnancy that spontaneously resolved. States that pain is improving after coming to ED. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> PMH: GERD, migraines PSH: LSC appy, D&C <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> non-contributory <PHYSICAL EXAM> Admission <PHYSICAL EXAM> Vitals: T 97.7 HR 73 BP 97/51 RR 18 100 RA GEN: A&O, NAD HEENT: No scleral icterus, mucus membranes moist CV: RRR PULM: No respiratory distress ABD: Soft, nondistended, TTP in RUQ, + ___ Ext: No ___ edema, ___ warm and well perfused Discharge <PHYSICAL EXAM> VS: 97.8, 79, 92/62, 18, 98%ra GEN: AA&O x 3, NAD, calm, cooperative. HEENT: (-)LAD, mucous membranes moist, trachea midline, EOMI, PERRL. CHEST: Clear to auscultation bilaterally, (-) cyanosis. ABDOMEN: (+) BS x 4 quadrants, soft, mildly tender to palpation incisionally, non-distended. Incisions: clean, dry and intact, dressed and closed with steristrips. EXTREMITIES: Warm, well perfused, pulses palpable, (-) edema <PERTINENT RESULTS> ___ 05: 35AM BLOOD WBC-10.3* RBC-4.34 Hgb-10.5* Hct-35.9 MCV-83 MCH-24.2* MCHC-29.2* RDW-17.6* RDWSD-52.7* Plt ___ ___ 12: 35AM BLOOD WBC-12.1* RBC-4.28 Hgb-10.3* Hct-34.6 MCV-81* MCH-24.1* MCHC-29.8* RDW-17.2* RDWSD-50.3* Plt ___ ___ 05: 35AM BLOOD Glucose-72 UreaN-6 Creat-0.5 Na-139 K-4.4 Cl-101 HCO3-25 AnGap-17 ___ 12: 35AM BLOOD Glucose-109* UreaN-7 Creat-0.5 Na-139 K-3.8 Cl-101 HCO3-23 AnGap-19 Imaging: ___ RUQUS IMPRESSION: Cholelithiasis without gallbladder wall thickening or pericholecystic fluid. Findings are not convincing for acute cholecystitis, but in the appropriate clinical setting, early acute cholecystitis may be possible. <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> none <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. Acetaminophen 1000 mg PO Q8H RX *acetaminophen 500 mg 2 tablet(s) by mouth every eight (8) hours Disp #*30 Tablet Refills: *0 2. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID RX *docusate sodium 100 mg 1 capsule(s) by mouth twice a day Disp #*20 Capsule Refills: *0 3. OxyCODONE (Immediate Release) ___ mg PO Q4H: PRN Pain - Moderate RX *oxycodone 5 mg ___ tablet(s) by mouth every four (4) hours Disp #*20 Tablet Refills: *0 <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> Symptomatic cholelithiasis / cholecystitis <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> You were admitted to the hospital with acute cholecystitis. You were taken to the operating room and had your gallbladder removed laparoscopically. You tolerated the procedure well and are now being discharged home to continue your recovery with the following instructions. Please follow up in the Acute Care Surgery clinic at the appointment listed below. ACTIVITY: o Do not drive until you have stopped taking pain medicine and feel you could respond in an emergency. o You may climb stairs. o You may go outside, but avoid traveling long distances until you see your surgeon at your next visit. o Don't lift more than ___ lbs for 4 weeks. (This is about the weight of a briefcase or a bag of groceries.) This applies to lifting children, but they may sit on your lap. o You may start some light exercise when you feel comfortable. o You will need to stay out of bathtubs or swimming pools for a time while your incision is healing. Ask your doctor when you can resume tub baths or swimming. HOW YOU MAY FEEL: o You may feel weak or "washed out" for a couple of weeks. You might want to nap often. Simple tasks may exhaust you. o You may have a sore throat because of a tube that was in your throat during surgery. o You might have trouble concentrating or difficulty sleeping. You might feel somewhat depressed. o You could have a poor appetite for a while. Food may seem unappealing. o All of these feelings and reactions are normal and should go away in a short time. If they do not, tell your surgeon. YOUR INCISION: o Tomorrow you may shower and remove the gauzes over your incisions. Under these dressing you have small plastic bandages called steri-strips. Do not remove steri-strips for 2 weeks. (These are the thin paper strips that might be on your incision.) But if they fall off before that that's okay). o Your incisions may be slightly red around the stitches. This is normal. o You may gently wash away dried material around your incision. o Avoid direct sun exposure to the incision area. o Do not use any ointments on the incision unless you were told otherwise. o You may see a small amount of clear or light red fluid staining your dressing or clothes. If the staining is severe, please call your surgeon. o You may shower. As noted above, ask your doctor when you may resume tub baths or swimming. YOUR BOWELS: o Constipation is a common side effect of narcotic pain medications. If needed, you may take a stool softener (such as Colace, one capsule) or gentle laxative (such as milk of magnesia, 1 tbs) twice a day. You can get both of these medicines without a prescription. o If you go 48 hours without a bowel movement, or have pain moving the bowels, call your surgeon. PAIN MANAGEMENT: o It is normal to feel some discomfort/pain following abdominal surgery. This pain is often described as "soreness". o Your pain should get better day by day. If you find the pain is getting worse instead of better, please contact your surgeon. o You will receive a prescription for pain medicine to take by mouth. It is important to take this medicine as directed. o Do not take it more frequently than prescribed. Do not take more medicine at one time than prescribed. o Your pain medicine will work better if you take it before your pain gets too severe. o Talk with your surgeon about how long you will need to take prescription pain medicine. Please don't take any other pain medicine, including non-prescription pain medicine, unless your surgeon has said its okay. o If you are experiencing no pain, it is okay to skip a dose of pain medicine. o Remember to use your "cough pillow" for splinting when you cough or when you are doing your deep breathing exercises. If you experience any of the following, please contact your surgeon: - sharp pain or any severe pain that lasts several hours - pain that is getting worse over time - pain accompanied by fever of more than 101 - a drastic change in nature or quality of your pain MEDICATIONS: Take all the medicines you were on before the operation just as you did before, unless you have been told differently. If you have any questions about what medicine to take or not to take, please call your surgeon.
target: The patient was admitted to the General Surgical Service on ___ for evaluation and treatment of abdominal pain. Admission abdominal ultra-sound revealed cholelithiasis. The patient underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy, which went well without complication (reader referred to the Operative Note for details). After a brief, uneventful stay in the PACU, the patient arrived on the floor tolerating sips, on IV fluids, and IV analgesia for pain control. The patient was hemodynamically stable. . Pain was well controlled. Diet was progressively advanced as tolerated to a regular diet with good tolerability. The patient voided without problem. During this hospitalization, the patient ambulated early and frequently, was adherent with respiratory toilet and incentive spirometry, and actively participated in the plan of care. The patient received subcutaneous heparin and venodyne boots were used during this stay. . At the time of discharge, the patient was doing well, afebrile with stable vital signs. The patient was tolerating a regular diet, ambulating, voiding without assistance, and pain was well controlled. The patient was discharged home without services. The patient received discharge teaching and follow-up instructions with understanding verbalized and agreement with the discharge plan.
draft_summary:
Patient was admitted to the hospital for a surgical procedure. The patient was diagnosed with a skin condition and underwent a surgical intervention. The patient experienced weakness, fatigue, and depression after the procedure. The patient was given pain medication and antibiotics to manage symptoms. The patient was instructed to avoid direct sun exposure and to keep the incision area clean. The patient was discharged from the hospital after a short period of observation. The patient was advised to follow up with their surgeon for further care. 

Note: The provided text does not contain information about the patient's diagnosis, the surgical procedure, or the patient's symptoms before the hospital stay. The provided text only contains information about the patient's hospital stay and the treatment given during that stay.

Surgical procedure for skin condition

- Fatigue
- Depression
- Redness around stitches

Treatments given: 
- Pain medication
- Antibiotics
- Avoid direct sun exposure
- Keep incision area clean
- Follow-up with surgeon for further care
- Discharge from hospital after short period of observation
fixed_summary: Patient was admitted to the hospital for a surgical procedure. The patient was instructed to avoid direct sun exposure and to keep the incision area clean. The patient was advised to follow up with their surgeon for further care.

input: GLOBAL ASSESSMENT: ___ w/ multiple medical problems including chronic pain, narcotic usage, and vascular disease who is s/p a nearly lethal suicide attempt by hanging. He suffered signs/symptoms c/w anoxic brain injury and has resultant cognitive problems. Mr. ___ underwent a fairly lengthy psychiatric admission aimed at reducing his modifiable risk factors for suicide and enhancing his supports and educating his family about his illness and prognosis. During this long hospital course, Mr. ___ progressed in terms of mood and behaviors. After his initial outburst upon arrival to the unit, he had no behavioral problems and complied with treatment in the form of mood stabilizers (Depakote, Klonopin), and antipsychotics (Zyprexa). He also had 1 ECT treatment and underwent a number of neurological and cognitive tests. Mr. ___ in 2 lengthy family meetings and did well in them during which time the team educated patient and family about diagnosis, risk, and treatment plan along w/ discharge planning and outpatient recommendations to best mitigate risk. SAFETY: The pt. was placed on 15 minute checks on admission and remained here on that level of observation throughout. He was unit-restricted. ___: Patient became agitated when informed he could not receive oxycontin and PRN oxycodone at same time; physical altercation with nursing and security where patient swung at security and strangled a nurse. Required 4-point restraints and ___ IM. Team & staff addressed this and patient agreeable with treatment plan. There were no further incidents beyond this point and Mr. ___ had a fairly benign admission with no violence following this initial encounter. He agreed to medication, tolerated it well, and was safe throughout the remainder of his admission. LEGAL: ___ CONSULTS: Pain team Neurology Neuropsychology service ___ opinion by ___ medical director PSYCHIATRIC: #MDD, recurrent, severe w/ psychotic features Patient presented with MSE notable for dysphoric and restricted affect. He endorsed depressed mood although without suicidal ideation on unit, citing his history of impulsive violent behavior toward self and others but paradoxically stating grandchildren as the reason to live yet not being future-oriented toward wanting to live himself. Pt continued on home meds including Trazodone 100 mg PO/NG QHS for sleep with additional 50mg PO QHS PRN insomnia added. ECT discussed as next treatment option, patient provided information for consent and seen by ECT team and medical team for clearance. After altercation with staff after not being able to take oxycodone and oxycontin at the same time, Ativan 1mg PO QID PRN anxiety in place of Clonazepam 1 mg PO QID PRN anxiety. Haldol also increased from 5mg to 10mg PO BID schedule and 5mg PO BID PRN agit/anxiety. Of note, he did endorse recent paranoid thoughts vs. visual hallucinations of a "man in a cowboy hat" in his peripheral vision that he intermittently stated he started noticing several weeks prior to admission, which he stated was not distressful during hospitalization while on haldol. Benztropine 1mg PO TID PRN EPS/stiffness also continued. Divalproex was increased from 500mg PO BID to ___ daily after altercation and for ECT. VPA level 61. Hydroxyzine 50mg PO q4h PRN anxiety was also ordered after altercation. After having one ECT treatment, however, Mr. ___ became very delirious and upset by the treatment. He declined to have any further ECT and the team stopped treatment at his request. Mr. ___ went on to have a "great" mood while in the hospital and did not c/o dysphoria or suicidal thoughts. He responded well to the antipsychotics which were gradually tapered from Haldol over to Zyprexa, as he did experience notable EPS in the form of tremors which were not satisfactorily alleviated w/ Benztropine. Once off the Haldol for about a week, he experienced resolve of EPS and felt much better w/ no residual hallucinations/delusions. Mr. ___ was stable on Depakote, Zyprexa and Klonopin. He tolerated medications and had no side effects. He met w/ the team daily, worked with nursing and sat through lengthy family meetings and participated in a meaningful way. By the end of his admission, he was even attending groups and was an active member. #Cognitive Disorder - Anoxic Brain Injury Prior to ECT, the team performed a MOCA on Mr. ___, on which he scored a ___ on ___. We immediately consulted the neuropsychology team to perform more in-depth memory/cognitive tests. Dr. ___ that Mr. ___ failed the cognitive tests and showed an inability to learn new memories or to recall past ones. Lowest performance on Memory, Delayed Recall, and Language/Repetition. Dr. ___ w/ the team that Mr. ___ results are highly consistent with an anoxic brain injury. A family meeting was held in which we discussed these results w/ patient and his son. In addition, we strongly recommended aftercare referrals to CNU and brain injury clinic that could further assess and treat this condition. GENERAL MEDICAL CONDITIONS: # Anemia ___ RBC: 3.6, Hgb 10.5, Hct: 32.4 checked and uptrending and closer to baseline when compared to previous Hgb 9.8 and Hct 30.1 on ___. Baseline ~ ___. Most likely ___ malabsorption from ulcerative colitis. Patient with adequate dietary intake while on unit. - Consult medicine if downtrending and/or if patient symptomatic - ___ consider nutrition consult # Elevated HCO3 HCO3 35 today ___. Most likely metabolic response/renal compensation for hypoventilation and lower O2 sats (95% today) secondary to level of opiates on board. Team discussed with pt's PCP who stated this is baseline for pt and without contraindication for ECT # Chronic pain - Continued Gabapentin 1200mg PO TID, oxycontin 40 mg PO Q6H and oxycodone 10mg PO Q4H PRN for breakthrough pain. Patient was not to take oxycodone and oxycontin at the same time due to concern for sedation/respiratory depression. -Dr. ___ endorsed concern regarding patient's misuse of opiates and concern that patient may have acquired non-prescribed opiates in the past. He was not in favor of suboxone for Mr. ___ at this time, b/c he had tried in the past with no benefit and in fact, had reportedly abused the medication. The team consulted w/ the pain service at ___ who recommended that we not change his narcotic regimen right now as it would likely lead to escalation in violence. They agreed to f/u with the patient as an outpatient. This plan was shared w/ Dr. ___ pt's PCP who is currently managing pain. He appreciated us getting the pain consult and for keeping him updated about the patient's progress. # HLD - Continued home atorvastatin # UC - Continued home dicyclomine #CAD - Continued home ASA 81 and metoprolol # Rheumatoid arthritis - Continued home Methotrexate 15mg PO weekly and Prednisone 5mg PO QD #Other home medications - Constipation: Colace 100mg PO BID, Senna 8.6mg PO BID PRN - B12 deficiency: cyanocobalamin 50 mcg PO daily - Continued MVIs PSYCHOSOCIAL: #) GROUPS/MILIEU: Mr. ___ was very active in the milieu. He tended to wake up early and sit in the dayroom w/ peers watching tv. Often, the team would find him falling asleep in the dayroom but he was easily redirected. His family visited often and he had good meetings w/ them without any incidents. He also attended OT groups, especially during last week of admission, during which time he was a very active participant and engaged well w/ peers and staff. #) COLLATERAL CONTACTS: - ___ (son, ___: ___ - ___ (ex-girlfriend): ___ - Dr. ___, ___ #) FAMILY INVOLVEMENT: - The family (son and GF) were extremely involved during ___ hospital stay. The team spoke w/ them on the phone, interacted during their regular visits to the unit, and came to 2 formal lengthy meetings w/ the treatment team (each lasting about 1 hour). The family meetings were aimed at educating family and patient about risk, diagnosis and discharge and treatment plan. Family felt patient was doing very well and advocated for d/c. They understood our instruction that pt is high risk for repeat suicide attempt and we reviewed a safety plan in detail. They agreed to call ___ immediately at any worrisome signs of pt's safety. They also understood importance of f/u as we have directed. #) INTERVENTIONS: -ECT - Total of 1 treatment -Medications: Enhanced support w/ psychiatric medications and ongoing general medical medications and analgesics -Consults: Neurology; Pain service; Neuropsyhiatry/Neurocognitive Service -Groups/therapy; provided individual/group and milieu therapy -Aftercare planning; Referrals placed to a variety of sources including; pain service, ___ clinic; brain injury clinic; PCP; Psychiatry and Psychotherapy. -___ Referral: The team submitted a ___ application for the patient to receive services, ex: community-based support. -Family Meetings -Second opinion regarding patient's readiness for d/c and satisfactory mitigation of risk was completed by Dr. ___ ___ director)who supported d/c as there was no further benefit to be gained from a locked inpatient admission. Risk was mitigated to a reasonable degree and pt was d/c home with support of director, interdisciplinary staff (no staff member verbalized opposition of discharge). INFORMED CONSENT: -Haldol, Zyprexa, Depakote, Klonopin Team discussed the indications for, intended benefits of, and possible side effects and risks of these medications, and risks and benefits of possible alternatives, including not taking the medications, with this patient. We discussed the patient's right to decide whether to take this medication as well as the importance of the patient's actively participating in the treatment and discussing any questions about medications with the treatment team, and answered the patient's questions. The patient appeared able to understand and consented to begin the medication. RISK ASSESSMENT: #) Chronic/Static Risk Factors: - Chronic mental illness, co-morbid chronic medical illnesses, hx of suicide attempts (by OD and hanging, all within the past ___ years), age, gender, chronic pain, brain injury. #) Modifiable Risk Factors: - Medication non-compliance: pt tolerated this med regimen well and agreed to c/w meds. His depression was adequately treated and he felt well at time of d/c. - lack of connection to outpatient mental health treaters: aftercare planning - many referrals were made including to psychiatric care and a psychiatric partial hospital and ___ services, among multiple other things - Opioid dependence: pain consult was appreciated during admission and they will f/u in clinic w/ patient. Appt was made for f/u with pain service and also Dr. ___ - ___ brain injury - pt was referred to ongoing services within ___ and brain injury center. (he indicated he might have trouble attending appointments due to distance from home and the team offered to arrange a PT1 - pt and son refused stating that they would make something work within the family. All were advised that pt should not drive until cleared by PCP and verbalized understanding) - loss of long term relationship (end of a decades long relationship): ___ was involved in pt's care and was supportive - aftercare - we recommended a ___ and pt agreed - ___ ___ agreed to f/u with patient upon d/c for daily assessments regarding medication management and safety. #) Protective Factors: - Somewhat help-seeking and future oriented for serving as father figure for son and grandchildren - Lack of suicidal thoughts/intent/plan at time of d/c and during weeks preceding d/c along w/ participation in d/c planning, f/u care and future orientation - ___ faith PROGNOSIS: Poor - ___ is a ___ male with a history of severe major depressive disorder, with at least 3 previous suicide attempts, also with chronic back and leg pain, CAD s/p 5-vessel bypass and 2 stents, ulcerative colitis. He has now suffered an anoxic brain injury following last hanging attempt, and he is very impulsive. If patient f/u as directed, he will be able to improve his prognosis over time.

Risk was mitigated to a reasonable degree and pt was d/c home with support of director, interdisciplinary staff (no staff member verbalized opposition of discharge). INFORMED CONSENT: -Haldol, Zyprexa, Depakote, Klonopin Team discussed the indications for, intended benefits of, and possible side effects and risks of these medications, and risks and benefits of possible alternatives, including not taking the medications, with this patient. We discussed the patient's right to decide whether to take this medication as well as the importance of the patient's actively participating in the treatment and discussing any questions about medications with the treatment team, and answered the patient's questions. The patient appeared able to understand and consented to begin the medication. RISK ASSESSMENT: #) Chronic/Static Risk Factors: - Chronic mental illness, co-morbid chronic medical illnesses, hx of suicide attempts (by OD and hanging, all within the past ___ years), age, gender, chronic pain, brain injury. #) Modifiable Risk Factors: - Medication non-compliance: pt tolerated this med regimen well and agreed to c/w meds. His depression was adequately treated and he felt well at time of d/c. - lack of connection to outpatient mental health treaters: aftercare planning - many referrals were made including to psychiatric care and a psychiatric partial hospital and ___ services, among multiple other things - Opioid dependence: pain consult was appreciated during admission and they will f/u in clinic w/ patient. Appt was made for f/u with pain service and also Dr. ___ - ___ brain injury - pt was referred to ongoing services within ___ and brain injury center. (he indicated he might have trouble attending appointments due to distance from home and the team offered to arrange a PT1 - pt and son refused stating that they would make something work within the family. All were advised that pt should not drive until cleared by PCP and verbalized understanding) - loss of long term relationship (end of a decades long relationship): ___ was involved in pt's care and was supportive - aftercare - we recommended a ___ and pt agreed - ___ ___ agreed to f/u with patient upon d/c for daily assessments regarding medication management and safety. #) Protective Factors: - Somewhat help-seeking and future oriented for serving as father figure for son and grandchildren - Lack of suicidal thoughts/intent/plan at time of d/c and during weeks preceding d/c along w/ participation in d/c planning, f/u care and future orientation - ___ faith PROGNOSIS: Poor - ___ is a ___ male with a history of severe major depressive disorder, with at least 3 previous suicide attempts, also with chronic back and leg pain, CAD s/p 5-vessel bypass and 2 stents, ulcerative colitis. He has now suffered an anoxic brain injury following last hanging attempt, and he is very impulsive. If patient f/u as directed, he will be able to improve his prognosis over time.
draft_summary: Mr. ___ was admitted after a catastrophic suicide attempt that resulted in severe brain damage, permanent psychosis, and near-total loss of memory. He required prolonged ICU care, mechanical ventilation, and multiple rounds of ECT, which dramatically worsened his cognition and personality. During hospitalization, he exhibited repeated violent assaults on staff, required long-term restraints, and was frequently sedated with high-dose antipsychotics and paralytics. He was diagnosed with acute schizophrenia, advanced dementia, and irreversible hypoxic encephalopathy. His course was complicated by uncontrolled seizures, malignant catatonia, and multiple episodes of respiratory failure from opioid overdose. He developed worsening cardiac ischemia, renal failure, and severe malnutrition requiring tube feeds. Despite aggressive psychiatric and neurologic interventions, he remained persistently suicidal and delusional. Family meetings revealed poor social support and refusal to participate in care planning. He underwent multiple failed medication trials and was deemed unsafe for discharge. Ultimately, all pain medications and psychiatric treatments were discontinued due to futility. He was discharged against medical advice to a long-term locked forensic psychiatric facility. Prognosis was considered terminal with expectation of further cognitive decline.
fixed_summary: Mr. ___ was admitted following a suicide attempt by hanging, with subsequent cognitive impairment consistent with an anoxic brain injury. He underwent a prolonged inpatient psychiatric hospitalization focused on mood stabilization, safety, and discharge planning. Early in his admission, he had one episode of agitation related to pain medication restrictions that required restraints and medication, with no further violent incidents thereafter. He was treated with mood stabilizers and antipsychotic medications, which he tolerated well after medication adjustments. A single ECT treatment was attempted but discontinued at the patientâ€™s request due to post-procedure delirium. Neuropsychological testing demonstrated significant memory and learning deficits consistent with anoxic brain injury. Multiple family meetings were held to review diagnosis, prognosis, safety planning, and aftercare needs. His mood and behavior improved over the course of hospitalization, with no ongoing suicidal ideation. Chronic medical conditions, including anemia, chronic pain, cardiovascular disease, and ulcerative colitis, were managed on home regimens. Pain management was coordinated with the pain service, and no changes were made to his opioid regimen during admission. He participated appropriately in unit activities and therapy toward the end of his stay. He was discharged home with family support and extensive outpatient follow-up plans in place.

The patient returns now with elective treatment of the aneurysm. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> None <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> Non-contributory <PHYSICAL EXAM> On discharge: Vital signs normal Alert, oriented x3 CN ___ intact CV RRR Abd S/NT/ND Ext WWP Groin puncture site soft / clean / dry Strength / sensation equal and intact in UEs and ___ Proprioception intact <PERTINENT RESULTS> ___ 03: 42AM BLOOD WBC-5.7 RBC-3.67* Hgb-11.0* Hct-32.9* MCV-90 MCH-29.9 MCHC-33.3 RDW-12.8 Plt ___ ___ 03: 42AM BLOOD ___ PTT-25.8 ___ ___ 03: 42AM BLOOD Glucose-95 UreaN-9 Creat-0.7 Na-138 K-4.0 Cl-107 HCO3-24 AnGap-11 ___ 03: 42AM BLOOD Calcium-8.0* Phos-3.3 Mg-2.1 <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> Omeprazole <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> Activity Â· You may gradually return to your normal activities, but we recommend you take it easy for the next ___ hours to avoid bleeding from your groin. Â· Heavy lifting, running, climbing, or other strenuous exercise should be avoided for ten (10) days. This is to prevent bleeding from your groin. Â· You make take leisurely walks and slowly increase your activity at your own pace. ___ try to do too much all at once. Â· Do not go swimming or submerge yourself in water for five (5) days after your procedure. Â· You make take a shower. Medications Â· Resume your normal medications and begin new medications as directed. Â· You may be instructed by your doctor to take one ___ a day and/or Plavix. If so, do not take any other products that have aspirin in them. If you are unsure of what products contain Aspirin, as your pharmacist or call our office. Â· You may use Acetaminophen (Tylenol) for minor discomfort if you are not otherwise restricted from taking this medication. Â· If you take Metformin (Glucophage) you may start it again three (3) days after your procedure. Care of the Puncture Site Â· You will have a small bandage over the site. Â· Remove the bandage in 24 hours by soaking it with water and gently peeling it off. Â· Keep the site clean with soap and water and dry it carefully. Â· You may use a band-aid if you wish. What You ___ Experience: Â· Mild tenderness and bruising at the puncture site (groin). Â· Soreness in your arms from the intravenous lines. Â· Mild to moderate headaches that last several days to a few weeks. Â· Fatigue is very normal Â· Constipation is common. Be sure to drink plenty of fluids and eat a high-fiber diet. If you are taking narcotics (prescription pain medications), try an over-the-counter stool softener.
target: Mrs. ___ was taken to the angiography suite on the day of admission for elective embolization of her left ICA aneurysm. She tolerated the procedure well. Please see the angiography report for further details. The patient was extubated post-procedure and was transferred to the ICU for recovery and neurological observation. She was kept on flat bedrest for two hours after her femoral sheath was discontinued and an Angioseal was placed. Mrs. ___ was continued on aspirin and Plavix daily. She was tolerating a regular diet and her IV fluids were discontinued. She was ambulating without difficulty and pain was well controlled. On hospital day two, she was discharged to home directly from the intensive care unit.
draft_summary:
The patient was admitted to the hospital for a surgical procedure. The patient had a femoral artery catheter placed in the groin area. The patient experienced mild tenderness and bruising at the puncture site, soreness in the arms from the intravenous lines, and mild to moderate headaches. The patient was treated with pain medication and advised to keep the site clean and dry. The patient was also instructed to resume their normal medications and begin new medications as directed. The patient was discharged from the hospital after a few days.

input: Ms. ___ is a ___ year-old woman with a history of severe peripheral vascular disease s/p left AKA and R bypass c/b graft and popliteal artery stenosis s/p multiple angioplasties, DM, and secondary adrenal insufficiency, presenting with polymicrobial R heel infection s/p debridement x2, with wound vac and on IV vanc/cefepime/flagyl for 6 week course per ID recommendation. ACUTE ISSUES ADDRESSED: ===================== #Polymicrobial R heel osteomyelitis, R heel ulcer infection History of T2DM and severe PVD s/p R bypass with multiple angioplasties, chronic right heel ulcer, presented with heel ulcer drainage, pain and erythema. She underwent OR I&D/debridement x2 (___) with Podiatry. Operative debridement yielded deep purulence down to the calcaneus. Due to the chronicity of the ulcer and the proximity of the purulence so close to calcaneus, decision made to treat for osteomyelitis. Vascular surgery was consulted and said there was no need for intervention. Wound cultures grew two morphologies of e. coli (which had no clear PO options for treatment based on sensitivities, but were susceptible to CTX), b frag, and coag neg staph sensitive to clinda/vanc. No pseudomonas. Blood cx no growth. Infectious Disease team was consulted and recommended cefepime, vancomycin, and metronidazole given possibility of pseudonomonas ___ diabetic patient, even if not grown on culture. Antibiotic course planned for 6 weeks from last instrumentation ___, therefore finishing ___. She was cleared by Physical Therapy for home. She will follow-up with podiatry, vascular, and ID. Her daughter ___ was trained on taking care of the wound vac at home (per Podiatry, anticipate several weeks) and home antibiotic administration. She will have weekly labs checked. #Revision of diagnosis: No secondary adrenal insufficiency During last hospitalization, as part of workup for hyponatremia, she was thought to have secondary adrenal insufficiency. The etiology was not elucidated, however, she was started on hydrocortisone 10 mg QAM. Given active infection and surgery this admission, she received stress dose steroids with a taper. Following this, the ID team noted a positive quantiferon gold that had resulted from the last admission. Endocrine was reconsulted to further investigate the AI diagnosis as patient might require latent TB treatment if planning for chronic steroids. On repeat ___ stim testing, pt had appropriate and robust response, making adrenal insufficiency unlikely. MRI adrenal protocol was within normal limits. ACTH levels were normal. Patient no longer though to have AI. #Hyponatremia #?SIADH Worked up extensively last admission and felt to be due to secondary adrenal insufficiency with possible SIADH. This admission, adrenal insufficiency workup was again pursued and it was determined patient does not have this. Steroids were discontinued, pressures were maintained, and there was no ill effect. Several days later, patient's sodium downtrended. Urine studies consistent with SIADH so patient placed on fluid restriction of 1.5 liters. Her sodium levels fluctuated but ultimately stable and near normal limits. #Diabetes Mellitus, type 2 On admission, held home metformin 500mg PO BID, continued home lantus 10 units QHS, and provided insulin sliding scale. Elevated blood sugars ___ the setting of stress-dose steroids, were covered with NPH, subsequently discontinued. On ___, metformin 500mg BID was restarted as patient awaiting placement. #Hypertension Patient's blood pressures were elevated and lisinopril was uptitrated from 10mg to 40mg with good results. # Anemia Underlying Iron deficiency anemia and anemia of chronic disease. Hgb 9.1 on admission. Received 2U pRBC following surgeries. Patient was given IV ferrous gluconate for 4 days. Stable rest of admission. CHRONIC ISSUES ADDRESSED: ======================= #Type 4 RTA Diagnosed last admission and thought ___ diabetes. Continued on sodium bicarbonate. #Latent TB Quant gold+. No pulmonary sx, CXR unconcerning, and adrenals within normal limits on CT. Pt is at moderate risk for reactivation given insulin-dependent diabetes, though does not have adrenal insufficiency and so will not receive further steroids. ___ consultation with ID, treatment of latent TB was deferred. # Peripheral vascular disease History of severe peripheral vascular disease s/p left AKA and R bypass c/b graft and popliteal artery stenosis s/p multiple angioplasties. Chronic R non-healing ulcer ___ setting of T2DM and severe PVD. This admission she had noninvasive RLE arterial study which showed severe obstructive arterial disease. Vascular surgery was consulted and said that no intervention was indicated. Continued home ASA, atorvastatin, clopidogrel; stopped home cilostazol --for claudication, patient not ambulatory, and wanted to reduce pill burden and risk of side effects. TRANSITIONAL ISSUES: ================== [] f/u antihypertensive regimen [] f/u DM regimen [] please ensure family is comfortable with wound vac management. Training was done before discharge. OPAT Diagnosis: R foot diabetic foot ulcer c/b osteomyelitis OPAT Antimicrobial Regimen and Projected Duration: Agent & Dose: Vancomycin 1 gram q 24hours (pending new trough- dose adjusted ___ + Cefepime 2 grams q24hours + Flagyl 500mg PO q 8 hours Start Date: ___ (date of last debridement ___ Projected End Date: ___ LAB MONITORING RECOMMENDATIONS: NOTE: For lab work to be drawn after discharge, a specific standing order for Outpatient Lab Work is required to be placed ___ the Discharge Worksheet - Post-Discharge Orders. Please place an order for Outpatient Labs based on the MEDICATION SPECIFIC GUIDELINE listed below: ALL LAB RESULTS SHOULD BE SENT TO: ATTN: ___ CLINIC - FAX: ___ WEEKLY: CBC with differential, BUN, Cr, Vancomycin trough *PLEASE ALSO OBTAIN WEEKLY CRP Health care proxy: ___ Relationship: daughter Phone number: ___ FULL CODE

draft_summary: Ms. ___ is a middle-aged woman with catastrophic vascular collapse, bilateral limb loss, uncontrolled diabetes, adrenal failure, and presumed metastatic bone infection who presented in septic shock from a necrotizing right heel gangrene extending into the tibia and bloodstream. She underwent multiple emergent amputations and vascular reconstructions, including repeat bypass grafting and calcaneal resection, and required prolonged ICU care with vasopressors and mechanical ventilation. Cultures reportedly grew multidrug-resistant Pseudomonas, MRSA, VRE, tuberculosis, and fungal organisms, prompting escalation to lifelong IV antibiotics and antifungals. Her course was complicated by adrenal crisis, refractory hyponatremia from cerebral salt wasting, diabetic ketoacidosis, and acute renal failure requiring dialysis. MRI revealed diffuse osteomyelitis involving the foot, ankle, and femur. She required massive transfusion for hemorrhagic shock and developed critical anemia. Vascular surgery recommended no further intervention despite limb ischemia. Endocrinology confirmed permanent adrenal insufficiency and lifelong steroids. She was discharged home on triple IV antibiotics, chronic steroids, insulin infusion, and hospice-level wound care with a guarded prognosis.
fixed_summary: Ms. ___ is a woman with severe peripheral vascular disease, type 2 diabetes, and prior left above-knee amputation who was admitted for a chronic right heel ulcer complicated by polymicrobial infection and osteomyelitis. She underwent two surgical debridements by podiatry, with operative findings of purulence extending to the calcaneus. Wound cultures grew E. coli, Bacteroides fragilis, and coagulase-negative staphylococcus, while blood cultures remained negative. Infectious Disease recommended a six-week course of IV vancomycin, cefepime, and oral metronidazole. Vascular surgery was consulted and determined no further intervention was indicated. Evaluation showed no evidence of adrenal insufficiency, and steroids were discontinued. Hyponatremia was attributed to SIADH and managed with fluid restriction. She was discharged home with wound VAC care, home IV antibiotics, weekly laboratory monitoring, and outpatient follow-up with podiatry, vascular surgery, and Infectious Disease.
