target: Patient was admitted to the transplant surgery service with the bacteremia and sepsis. He was admitted to the ICU. Neuro: Since the time of admission patient was arousable and responded to commands. He remained at his baseline until the day he decompensated when his metal status has worsened and upon intubation, required no sedation. He received minimal pain medications for abdominal pain/discomfort. CV: The patient was initially stable from a cardiovascular standpoint. He required vasopressors upon admission, in the next ___ hours he was weaned of the pressors. He developed vasopressor requirement and became hemodynamically unstable approximately 48 hour prior to his demise. Following the aspiration event on the floor level of care on ___, patient was transferred to ICU, where he drooped his systolic blood pressure shortly after. He was on one vasopressor for the 24 hours, later on 2 pressors, yet his sbp was in ___. The family made a decision to withdraw life support including vasopressors on ___ in the early mid-afternoon. Patient expired several hours after. Pulmonary: The patient remained stable from a pulmonary standpoint initially. On ___ he vomited and aspirated. His oxygen saturation dropped and he was transferred to the ICU. His oxygen saturation was low, his mental status worsened, thus he was intubated. He remained intubated until he expired. GI/GU/FEN: Patient was found to have C. difficile colitis. He was fed via TPN. The electrolytes was initially repleated. The hyperkalemia was treated with kayaxylate. Patient also underwent CVVH. The CVVH no longer continued after ___, when patient was intubated, due to family wishes. Patient had diagnostis paracenthesis, which did not show SBP. ID: He was treated for C. difficile colitis initially with PO vancomycin and IV flagyl as well as tigacycine. The Klebsiella bacteremia was treated with meropenem. Prior to the cultures becoming available, patient also recieved amikacin and cefepime. He was afebrile for most of the hospital stay. Endocrine: The patient's blood sugar was monitored throughout his stay; insulin dosing was adjusted accordingly. Hematology: The patient's complete blood count was examined routinely. Prophylaxis: The patient received subcutaneous heparin and venodyne boots were used during this stay. As patient status declined rapidly on ___ following the aspiration event, family made a well thought out decision to minimize the patient's suffering as his prognosis was not favorable. Patient was initially made DNR status for about 24 hours. Next, the family made the patient CMO with continued ventilation on ___. Patient expired one to hours after all the vasopressors were stopped. He was started on morphine gtt. He expired comfortable, with no agonal breaths observed. The medical examiner as well as the family refused an autopsy.
draft_summary:
The patient was admitted to the transplant surgery service with bacteremia and sepsis and initially required ICU-level care. Neurologically, he was arousable and followed commands at baseline until acute decompensation, after which his mental status worsened and he required intubation without sedation. Cardiovascularly, he initially required vasopressor support but was weaned; however, following an aspiration event later in the hospitalization, he developed recurrent hemodynamic instability requiring escalating vasopressors.
Pulmonary status declined after an aspiration episode, leading to hypoxia, worsening mental status, ICU transfer, and mechanical ventilation until death. Gastrointestinal evaluation revealed Clostridioides difficile colitis treated medically, and he received TPN for nutrition. Renal failure was managed with CVVH, which was discontinued after intubation per family wishes. Diagnostic paracentesis showed no spontaneous bacterial peritonitis.
Infectious management included treatment of C. difficile colitis and Klebsiella bacteremia with broad-spectrum antibiotics tailored to culture results. Despite treatment, the patient deteriorated clinically. After discussions regarding poor prognosis, the family elected DNR status followed by comfort measures only. Vasopressors were withdrawn, morphine infusion was initiated, and the patient expired peacefully. Autopsy was declined by both the family and the medical examiner.

She was then transferred to the ___ for further evaluation and care. She was evaluated by orthopaedics, admitted, consented, and prepped for surgery. She was given Vitamin K for an INR of 4, and she was cleared for surgery by medicine. She was taken to the operating room on ___ and underwent an ORIF of her left hip fracture. She was noted to have some ST depression in the operating room, and her cardiac enzymes we cycled. She was extubated, transferred to the recovery room where she had an EKG which was normal. She was then transferred to the floor. On the floor she was transfused with 1 unit of packed red blood cells due to acute blood loss anemia. He cardiac enzymes were negative. She was restarted on her coumadin post operatively on ___. She has been subtherapeutic with an INR of less than 2.0 since her operation on ___. She is being bridged with lovenox. Intraoperative TEE was negative for any clot. She was seen by physical therapy to improve her strength and mobility. The rest of her hospital stay was uneventful with her lab data and vital signs within normal limits and her pain controlled. She is being discharged today in stable condition.

target: The patient presented from ___ to ___ ___ where he was admitted to the Orthopaedic service. He was a direct admit for infected left total knee replacement. On physical exam of the left knee, his surgical staples were intact, with mild serosanguineous drainage from the inferior portion of the wound. There was local erythema and edema of the lower extremity. ID was consulted and made recommendations including for his antibiotic regimen (please see their note for full details). Per their recommendation, a PICC was placed and his right femoral catheter was removed on ___. The patient was transferred to the Joints service on the ___ on ___. The patient was taken to the operating room for above described procedure. Please see separately dictated operative report for details. The surgery was uncomplicated and the patient tolerated the procedure well. Postoperative course was remarkable for the following: On POD #0, patient was given 5mg of Coumadin for INR 1.3. On POD #1, patient had a hematocrit of 22.7 and low magnesium level of 1.5, which was repleted. INR was 1.9 and Coumadin was held. Patient was triggered for asymptomatic hypotension and 1 liter bolus of IV fluids was given. In the afternoon, patient was noted to be drowsy per RN and a repeat hematocrit was obtained, which was stable at 22.9. On POD #2, hematocrit was 22.8 and blood pressures were within normal limits. Patient was not given a blood transfusion given that he was asymptomatic with stable vital signs. INR was 2.5 and coumadin was held. Patient's hemovac drain remained in placed due to high output. On POD #3, his hematocrit remained stable at 23.1 and his vital signs remained stable. He was started on 40mg of lovenox daily after his INR returned at 1.7. His pain medication was then switched to Dilaudid for inadequate pain control. The drain remained in place. On POD #4, the patient's pain was better controlled with Dilaudid and expressed feeling better. His hematocrit returned at 22.2 and his vital signs continued to remain stable. On POD#5, the drain was removed, his hematocrit was 23.1 with asymptomatic mild hypotension, systolic blood pressure of 98, he was given a bolus, 500cc of normal saline. At the time of discharge his blood pressure was 120 systolic and the patient was asymptomatic. Otherwise, pain was controlled with a combination of IV and oral pain medications. The patient received Coumadin for DVT prophylaxis on POD #0 and Coumadin was dosed daily based on INR levels. He was then switched to Lovenox 40mg daily on POD#3. The ___ surgical dressing will remain in place until follow visit with Dr. ___ on ___. The patient was seen daily by physical therapy. Labs were checked throughout the hospital course and repleted accordingly. At the time of discharge the patient was tolerating a diabetic diet and feeling well. The patient was afebrile with stable vital signs. The patient's hematocrit was acceptable and pain was adequately controlled on an oral regimen. The operative extremity was neurovascularly intact and the dressing was intact. The patient's weight-bearing status is toe touch weight bearing on the operative extremity. No range of motion of left knee. Please keep the knee immobilizer on for ambulation. Please use walker or 2 crutches at all times. Mr. ___ is discharged to rehab in stable condition.
draft_summary: The patient was urgently transferred after a catastrophic failure of his left knee replacement complicated by septic shock, acute renal failure, and suspected necrotizing fasciitis. He underwent multiple emergency surgeries including knee explantation, vascular repair, and partial femur reconstruction, followed by massive transfusion for hemorrhagic shock. His hospital course was complicated by respiratory failure requiring intubation, delirium, myocardial infarction, and stroke. He developed recurrent bacteremia despite prolonged IV antibiotics and required ICU care with vasopressors and dialysis. After weeks of instability, he was discharged to long-term rehabilitation with permanent immobility and lifelong anticoagulation.
fixed_summary:
The patient was admitted directly to the orthopedic service for management of an infected left total knee replacement. On examination, the surgical incision had intact staples with mild serosanguineous drainage, local erythema, and lower extremity edema. Infectious Disease was consulted, a PICC line was placed, and the femoral catheter was removed per recommendations. The patient underwent operative intervention without complications and was transferred to the joint service postoperatively.
His postoperative course was notable for anemia with stable hematocrit in the low 20s, intermittent asymptomatic hypotension treated with IV fluids, and electrolyte abnormalities that were repleted as needed. Anticoagulation was managed carefully with adjustments to warfarin dosing based on INR, later transitioning to prophylactic enoxaparin. Pain control was optimized with a transition to hydromorphone. A surgical drain was maintained due to high output and removed on postoperative day five. Physical therapy was involved daily. At discharge, the patient was afebrile, hemodynamically stable, tolerating diet, and neurovascularly intact. He was discharged to rehabilitation with toe-touch weight bearing and knee immobilization.
